I've played this game through end to end twice on PC. The "New Game+" feature allows you to start a second, harder replay with all of the weapons etc. from the first run.  Absolutely THE best apocalyptic Zombie game, story, and scenery ever created.  

As a Pacific Northwesterner, I find there are constantly places in the game I go to where I see something familiar, and have a WHOA moment that a famous waterfall or some other unique REAL place is actually on my screen and incredibly accurate.  (Like a certain bridge and double falls.  You know the one.  That poor lodge.)

Overview:  Motorcycling throughout central Oregon trying to help friends, save the world, find your girl, and rid the world of THEM.  Which unfortunately includes very realistic end-of-the world psychological impact, like fringe groups.  They are either trying to survive by theft and murder, trying to convert you to their pro-zombie cult, or trying to force you to join their mock militia with a crazy man.  All of them want to kill you and the other groups.

A disease has transformed normal people to mindless packhunting carnivorous 'freaks.'  There are hordes of them.  In advanced difficulty, hundreds and hundreds of them.  Let me officially say i hate the caves. BUT we're supposed to. 

Those moments are accented and crescendo'd by the musical score. WOW.  The mood the composer and sound people created when around freakers and hordes is terrifying, effective, and accurate / appropriate for the situation.  You never hear 'scary music' unless there is an 'oh crap' situation about to happen.  

Audio is critical in this game, including the sounds of the freaks, their voices.  Creepiest is the freaker girl who hums all the time.  Until she sees you...

AND i haven't mentioned your dead wife who you SWEAR isn't dead and keep searching for.  Due to possible evidence.  Is she alive? And if so, is she normal still?

About the slow start: SOME reviews say the game starts slow.  I can't imagine how you could start this game and this story by dropping right into the fray.  I believe they do an amazing job, as they build the characters, storyline, atmosphere, location, mechanics, etc. buy having you run missions for ingredients you may need, along with some cut scenes and interactions.  Meanwhile you watch your friend get sicker.  This first hour of play is designed to highlight the friendship you have with him, some history between them, and add the annoyance of the freakers, along with get used to locations, learn about camps, etc.

Once you meet the NPC recurring character LISA, everything hits like a kick in the gut.  The surprising emotional impact of this piece of art is astounding.  Once the game is over, you can keep playing the open world doing side-missions and discovering places.  I always do.  Big disappointment for me? not being able to truly interact with my NPC peers after the storyline is over.  In other words, i am disappointed that it is over.  It has a wonderful ending, but like any really really good movie, you don't want to leave, neither the world or the characters..

Motorcycle mechanic is great, especially having to repair and refuel frequently.  Great physics.  Hunting is also there and satisfying, as is the plethora of weapon types and creative explosive devices, with a little crafting  (i love the attractor bomb myself for horde-plosions).

The story, the interactions, the over-the-top character acting.  Absolutely love and relate to Deacon.  

As a Pac NW person, this game scratches every itch, many of which i didn't even know were there.

Cheers guys, congratulations.  5 stars, One of the best games I've ever played.  196 hours on record. Probably starting playthrough 3 soon.

Bend Studios, want 6 stars?  Create Days Gone 2, with co-op. OH and please do a movie.

NPC's randomly teleport, randomly spawn, cutscenes happen out-of-order, dialog happens out-of-order, your character may just drop dead because you stumbled on a rock, your bike might randomly throw you off because it hit some tiny piece of geometry, enemy AI may just spin in place, interactions might get stuck, LOD changes might stop working, things may just not render in at all... the list goes on.

Title: Days Gone: A Thrilling Ride Through the Apocalypse

Days Gone delivers an adrenaline-pumping journey through a post-apocalyptic world that will leave players on the edge of their seats. Set in the stunning and perilous Pacific Northwest, this open-world adventure is a triumph in survival gaming.

One of the most remarkable aspects of Days Gone is its vast and meticulously crafted world. From dense forests to abandoned highways, every corner of the map is teeming with life, both human and infected. The dynamic weather system adds another layer of immersion, with rainstorms and fog dramatically altering the landscape and gameplay.

The heart and soul of Days Gone lie in its gripping gameplay mechanics. As protagonist Deacon St. John, players must navigate through hordes of ferocious Freakers while scavenging for resources and completing missions. The combat system is both intuitive and satisfying, offering a variety of weapons and tactics to dispatch enemies with precision.

Beyond its intense action sequences, Days Gone also shines in its narrative depth. The story of Deacon's quest for redemption is compelling, filled with poignant moments of loss and resilience. The emotional journey is further enhanced by stellar voice acting and captivating character development.

However, despite its many strengths, Days Gone does stumble slightly in its storytelling execution. While the overarching narrative is engaging, there are moments where pacing issues and predictable plot twists detract from the overall experience. Additionally, some side quests feel disconnected from the main storyline, leading to a sense of disjointedness in the narrative flow.

Despite this minor setback, Days Gone remains a must-play title for fans of survival and action-adventure games. With its breathtaking world, thrilling gameplay, and emotional storytelling, it stands as a testament to the power of immersive gaming experiences. Strap in, gear up, and prepare to embark on an unforgettable journey through the apocalypse.

Days Gone tries to play into the survival genre but does so very poorly. The game loop is neither fun nor realistic, and succeeds only in being unnecessarily frustrating and immersion breaking with silly gimmicks like 'tracker mode' that highlights items in your immediate area. 

There are arbitrary game mechanics that simply don't work. For instance, you can find all manner of weapons out in the field, but unless you purchase them from a camp, you won't be able to retrieve them from your gun locker for reuse. 

Melee weapons like machetes and axes have such low durability that they break after only a few hits, forcing you to find another. Likewise, your dirt bike will run out of gas every two minutes, and require repairs every 5. It's not that finding things in the world is particularly difficult -- there are things all over the place. It's that the gameplay loop is arbitrary and forced. It feels more like padding to make up for the lack of gameplay than anything else.

The AI is pretty poor as well, with enemies losing you in a foot tall bush when they're three meters behind you. Not to mention the fact that you're having a full-on conversation over your walkie talkie while they search for you. Yea right. And the 'zombies' appear to spawn out of nowhere in all directions. You'll never feel like you've cleared an area. 

The environment is completely drab and sterile, constantly raining as part of the forced ambiance, as you ride your fuel guzzling dirt bike along a predetermined mini-map path to your next objective a few hundred meters away. And there's nothing like a big "Leaving Mission Area" warning plastered over your screen as a reminder that the devs are in control here, not you. 

There are so many better game options out there that don't force players into an inescapable box, that I can't recommend playing this one. And while the game may get better over time as some reviews have pointed out, why should I have to wait for a game to get good? It should be good from the start.

I definitely recommend this game to any one a fan of zombie shooters and open world action/survival.  I am definitely a fan of zombie genre, and the zombies in this game are well done.  Not slow, meandering corpses (though that is the definition in some cases), these not-undead creatures are challenging. The game mechanics forces you into a run/duck scenario when the hoard is stampeding you and, what makes it fun, are the strategic environmental 'traps' you can use to your advantage, requiring some cunning and some strategy.  Overall well done.

UPDATE:  On first review, I gave my initial impressions and I will update this review to conclude this is probably the most underrated game I have played in quite some time.  The game released to unrelenting poor reviews which perplexes me, I found most of the criticisms to be off-base or flat out wrong.  I stand by my original impression, now being about 1/2 way through the game.    The story had me in the beginning, and I did not find it slow or cliche' as many reviewers did (I feel the negative criticisms of the story has more to do with the lunatic politics of the time rather than actual quality of story telling).  The world is detailed and beautifully rendered.  The game play is varied and enemies are diverse -- from zombie nests, to marauders, snipers, and hordes.  The crafting/survival elements are well balanced, not overtly complicated, and adds to the story/environment.  I do appreciate the skill tree and the progression system is well intertwined into the world and story progression.  I, frankly, rank this up there with the genre greats like L4D2 (though a completely different gaming approach, I am enjoying it as I did L4D2) or the Resident Evil type games.   I particularly like the zombies, the behavior, the models, skins and looks... contrast that to the cartoonish look of Back 4 Blood zombies... ugghhh. 

I for one vote for a sequel.  I would love another game of this.... just superb.  Playstation exclusives are incredibly good and since I do not like console gaming and do not own a PS4 or 5, I am glad Sony ported this over... well done.

Update 2:  Finished the game.  If you go through the main story threads, and skip the camp jobs and bounty hunter missions (which is hard to do since you need to build camp trust and credits to proceed), you can count on 40-50 hours of game play, if you play out all the details more like 60-75 hours of game play.  It does not matter, all I can say is WOW.  One of the best stories and finishes to a game, loved it all.

Now that I've completed the main story (secret ending not included), I can safely recommend this game. The characters are mostly well written (Colonel Garrett notwithstanding) and superbly well acted. The combat works well enough not to be a nuisance, but it's not smth to get addicted to either.

The main thing that sets this game apart from The Last of Us is that it's an open world sandbox adventure. So if you're tasked with clearing a group of human enemies, you can just draw a zombie horde to them and have the horde do all the dirty work for you. Which is extremely fun. The AI is pretty stupid for the most part, but not to the point that it ever breaks the flow of the game.

The open world is extremely pretty to look at and the dynamic weather and day/night cycle add to the experience. Except for the snow, which pales in comparison to 2016's The Division. It looks serviceable, but it's nowhere near as atmospheric.

There's a secret ending which I won't spoil here, but you gotta clear every single last horde on the map, of which there are a lot, to unlock it. Which might not be worth it, knowing that it baits a sequel which Sony has denied. But if you enjoyed the horde clearing in the main story, then it's a good excuse to revisit the game from time to time for an hour or two.

Last words: Block the game executable in your OS' firewall to stop Sony from spying on you.

If you're in the market for a single-player experience that immerses you in a post-apocalyptic world filled with danger, brotherhood, and the raw thrill of survival, "Days Gone" is a game you can't afford to miss. At its core, this game is an ode to the survival genre, delivering an unparalleled story that grips you from the slow burn of its beginning to its intense, heart-pounding conclusion.

The game sets you loose in a vast expanse of Oregon's wilderness, a backdrop that's both beautiful and merciless. The sense of freedom you get riding your bike across this open world is unmatched. It's not just about the ride; it's about the survival, exploration, and the stories that unfold on this journey.

Combat in "Days Gone" is a testament to the game's attention to detail and its dedication to delivering a visceral experience. Whether you're swinging a melee weapon or firing a gun, the combat feels grounded and satisfying. The inclusion of craftable traps and items adds a layer of strategy that elevates encounters beyond mere brute force, making each confrontation with the undead a thrilling test of wit and will.

Speaking of the undead, facing down hordes of zombies is as exhilarating as it is challenging. It's a feature that will test your mettle, keep you on your toes, and offer the kind of satisfaction only found in overcoming overwhelming odds.

I'm running this masterpiece on an i9-13900k processor with 64GB of RAM and an Nvidia RTX4070 TI, and the performance is flawless. "Days Gone" is exceptionally well-optimized for PC, ensuring that your journey through the apocalypse is as seamless as it is enthralling.

In conclusion, "Days Gone" is a 10/10 in my book. It's a game that demands patience at the start but rewards you with an experience that's as profound as it is thrilling. It's not just a game; it's an adventure that tests your spirit, challenges your skills, and ultimately, tells a story of humanity at its most raw and resilient. Don't just play it; live it.

Took a chance on this game because Darth Maul (Sam Whitwer) is the central protagonist.  This game took me 66 hours to complete.  Played it on hard difficulty. No regrets.  Learning curve was hard, but fun.  The game is an amazing balance of hope and hopelessness, love and jump scares, friends to foes, foes to friends; just amazing writing.  

Many of the twists were predictable, but I didn't care because t;he twists gave me what I wanted/needed and allowed for closure, and kept me from resenting the game.  So, thank you to the writers that chose the paths you did.

That said, I don't see replay-ability in this game and I think you have to love it once for what it was, and then walk away, and remember it fondly.  Un-like MW3, CoD and the like that have tremendous soul-crushing replay-ability.  

I'm not one to watch all the cut scenes, but I found myself becoming emotionally invested in the main characters, their backstories, and their story arcs.  

Build up your bike for speed and performance, unlock character trees offering a myriad of abilities, or build zombie wrecking melee weapons that would earn you a war crimes trial.  So awesome.  So graphic. 

Nom Nom. 

There is a buffet of firearms for Primary, Secondary, and 'Special'.  Probably a thousand or so different firearm combinations to fit every gamer play style.   Ranged stealth assassin? Sure.  Bruiser Juggernaut? We can do that too.  Shotguns everywhere? Done.

I'm generally hard on games, and seem to have high expectations that few games can live up to.  

This game exceeded expectations. The writing staff, the programmers, the actors and their co-workers really have created something special here.

Fully, and emotionally, endorsed.

Note -- Things I would like to see from this game - online co-op, and/or closed map pvp against zombies and players, freestyle compound building similar to fallout 4, but with the ability to grant compound abilities through structures like in State of Decay.

I've played quite a few zombie games in my time but Days Gone was on a level I couldn't have predicted. I thought it'd be good from the high praise and ratings but not THIS good. If you're more into the "pick up 'n shoot without a strong narrative" type of game, you may want to stay clear of this one as it's a long game with an amazing story to tell. The story and cast are so well written I'd even recommend this game to RPG/JRPG players. Aside from 1 or 2 bugs I've nothing bad to say. Controls feel really good, the music score is great, combat is thrilling and varied, the PC port is near flawless and runs with the grace of a gazelle.

The story is a LITTLE slow to start but it's worth it. It's a long game so let it set itself. I've never played a zombie game before where my sense of purpose in the world was this grand. I played the game on Hard difficulty and it wasn't really tough at all, but as an RPG player I love to level grind so maybe I was just always OP. Hordes are really something else, but I found that even the biggest hordes could be brought down with some basic planning, either entirely through stealth or a full on frontal assault. Some of the ways I beat certain hordes honestly felt like cheating lol, like I discovered an exploit. I put off playing this game for a while cuz I thought it'd be good but mostly the run of the mill. Boy was I wrong. Best zombie game I've played thus far.

I've played the first two hours on steam, played a few hours on ps4 and watched a few hours of gameplay so Ill give an initial impression and then update later:

The zombies:This game has original and interesting zombies, they're fast which might put a lot of people off but the game balances that quite well by making them easy enough to outsmart... albeit a lot of the time you outsmarting the zombies is more like just figuring out the limitations of the games AI and using that to run rings around the zombies. I think overall the zombies are decent and more consistent that a lot of other games. I am surprised though that the zombies wern't patched after release once the developers saw how easily us players can take advantage of flaws in their pathfinding, line of sight and world interactivity protocols (or whatever AI programming is called). Im a relative noob and my tactic with them is to get up high and knock them repeatedly off a ledge as they climb up one at a time.

The cutscenes: Voice acting is good, script seems actually well written, grounded and not too cliche or over the top like a lot of games nowerdays but Immediately the thing that'll stick out like a sore thumb for gamers is the lack of seamless transitions between cutscenes and gameplay. Its almost like the team who did the cut-scenes were told that the game engine could handle seamless transitions but it only became apparent after all the cut-scenes were coded that the game engine couldn't so they just filmed cutscenes and then stuck them awkwardly into the game by cutting to black and hoping the scenes match up with what you were doing. These awkward transitions are very distracting and break all the tension and the annoying part is that most of the early cutscenes are just unneeded as a voice over would have achieved the same things.

The gameplay: The core game looks and feels great its like a blend between dying light and The last of us. 

Ubisoft inspirations take so much away:  there are some questionable design choices beyond the core mechanics which cheapen the experience unnecessarily like the fact that the bike has a arcade game boost and drift buttons, there are farcry style influences awkwardly placed everywhere the worst of which are the settlements with ubisoft style generic shop and service NPCs stalls everywhere with absolutely no soul or sense of reality. I think this producer just figured that that is what people like, I actually think if theyd kept things simple and concentrated on the story and core gameplay people would have ate it up.

Bugs and gamebreaking mechanics: There are a few bugs and poor coding here and there but nothing that would have caused many complaints day one of release. But we re sitting here some 4 years after the game was released and from what ive seen barely anything was addressed. There are a lot of stutters, weird glitchy movements and transitions which arnt too bad but one big gamebreaking design choice everyone needs to know about is the game giving you a manual save and a quicksave which appear to work no matter what youre doing (the game literally does look like its saving) but they only work when youre next to a bed or your bike. if you save and quit after a long gaming session but not next to a bike or bed you will not notice that the game hasnt actually saved and  you will be reverted back to the beginning of your current mission with nothing retained at all. The fact that 4 years later there is still a save button in the pause menu is mental, there should be a save button on the motorbike and the beds and nowhere else.

I think if they had not used pre filmed cutscenes (and used live in engine cutscenes like every modern game), got rid of the ubisoft-isms, the random zombie nests and other weird repetitive side objectives, fixed the bugs, listened to the fan feedback and gave the settlements a more natural survivor feel instead of the soulless Ubisoft settlement approach, this game would have been a chart topper and I can now see why people speak about the potential of this game more than how good it actually is, because it is actually good. And I look forward to exploring it in its entirety.

Buy this game knowing that you will need to work around its flaws to love it.

1. Story
How to begin this chapter. Story of days gone is phenomenal. I love it. It’s full of plot-twists, hatred, love....it has everything. It is definitely the strongest aspect of the game. I’ve never played a zombie game which has as great story as Days Gone (yeah it’s true I did not play many Zombie-story-driven singleplayer games buuuuut it doesn’t matter) What I particulary like about the story are the plot-twists mentioned earlier. They are extremely unexpected. I had no idea that the story will take this turn and this will happen. I managed to predict it in couple of games which I’ve played before. So thumbs up Bend Studio. Story begins with the 2 bikers – Deacon St. John who is the main protagonist of Days Gone, his friend Boozer and a Deacon’s wife Sarah. It’s directly during the start of the zombie apocalypse in Oregon. Sarah get’s stubbed by little infected child and Deacon and Boozer are looking for help for Sarah. They manage to find a NERO helicopter, Nero Stands for - National Emergency Response Organization, and Deacon with Boozer puts Sarah in that helicopter to save her. Unfortunately they can’t go with her because there are only 2 free places which one of them is for Sarah. So Deacon as the best husband ever prefers bros before hoes. He goes with Boozer who is also injured but it’s not that critical as Sarah is. Then Deacon and Sarah agree on meeting in a refugee camp and after this, the chopper leaves. After this prologue the game officialy starts. The story continues 2 years forward to present day when both Deacon and Boozer don’t believe that Sarah had survived the flight. I am not going to continue, don’t worry I don’t want to spoil you the beauty of Deacon’s adventure.
2. Quests
So basicaly quest are devided in 2 main lines. Just like in any other open world game, there are main quests and side quests. Main quests are really nice, they are varied and are not that repetitive or at least it seems to me that way. But I can’t say this about the side quests. There are varius of side quests from destroying enemy camp to looking for a hostage and so on. These quests are repetitive and they are called jobs. In Days Gone there are several camps that will offer you these jobs and when you complete them you’ll earn some trust and some camp credits. Higher the trust the more and better items you can buy with these camp credits. Each camp has it’s own currency but don’t get me wrong it’s easy to see how much camp credits you have in each settlement it’s not confusing at all. Okay enough about the camps let’s go back to the side quests. Like I said they are repetitive and there are so many of them I don’t even have idea how many of them I’ve completed. If you are grinding only these before main line you might get bored but when you mix it, it is tolerable and you’ll probably don‘t to get bored by them. 
3. Combat and upgrades
There are 3 different types of combat. Combat against human enemies, combat against freaks (those are the zombies in Days Gone’s terminology) and fighting the animals. There are various type of different enemies from each of these groups. The most challenging is fight with freaks. You can meet many and when I say many I mean many freaks together and this is called a Horde. In the earlier stages of the game they’ll kick your ass with no problem but further it’ll became easier and easier to hunt them down. But you can still be stupid asshole like me and still get killed by them. Jk they are pretty challenging even in end-game, speaking mostly about the bigger Hordes. Human enemies are in some way special too. They set up ambushes and if you don’t pay enough attention, you can end up directly in their trap like I did several times. They are not difficult to defeat but they can shake with your health and resources. They also settled down in many camps around the map. I don’t have any problems with enemies and their AI but sometimes they act stupidly and really weird. I‘ve spoken about the combat but I haven’t told you yet how to upgrade Deacon to kill enemies easier and faster. Deacon can be upgrading by 2 different ways. The first one is often used and it’s via perks. Each perk need to be purchased by skill points. You can earn skill points after required amount of XP. You can earn XP by doing main and side missions, killing enemies and other stuff. Does it sound too complicated? Don’t worry you’ll understand it when you’ll dive into Days Gone yourself.  Anyway these perks will make your life easier in the Wilderness of Oregon. There is also another way to upgrade Deacon. That is via NERO injectors which you can find in NERO camps scattered around the map. When you find an injector you can upgrade health, stamina or a focus. So they are basicaly passive skills. You may ask what a Focus is, aaaaaaand that’s a really nice feature. When in combat you can press a button and time slows down for some time and you can aim for heads more easily. But not only Deacon can be upgraded. You can also upgrade his best friend, his bike. Bike can be upgraded in certain settlements. Bike is used to travel around the open world of Oregon. Speaking of travelling......
4. Game World
Game world is extremely and I really mean extremely huge. It’s filled with various activities from destoying bandit camps, burning out freaker nests to killing hordes. What I really like about the game world activities are the random encounters you may face when driving from point A to point B. You may found some people in need and when you help them you can send them to camp you have previously discovered and you’ll receive some trust points or camp credits. These encounters are really nice part of open world and they keep it a little more alive. What also keeps the open world alive are random ambushes like I mentioned earlier. I bet you’ll definitely get ambushed at least once. It’s great way to keep the world more alive.  If I should say something about the world itself I would definitely say that it’s various and vibrant. There are many types of biomes, from Oregon’s forests through destroyed areas to snowy regions. I loved just driving aroung and experiencing the beauty of the world. The Bend Studio did amazing job in this part.
5. Audio, Optimization, Graphics and bugs
This side of days gone is also on really high level. I don’t have any problems with these aspects of the game. It runs smoothly, I think only once in 50 hour playtime I experienced FPS drop, apart from this I haven’t encountered any lags or FPS drops. As for graphics I have no problem with it. It looks really nice and like I mentioned earlier I really enjoyed driving in this world and graphic side was one reason why. Audio is also great I don’t have any problems with that I genuienly enjoyed auditional aspect of the game.  As for bugs I haven’t encountered many. Sometimes I managed to see really really stupid NPC but it did not happened often. I haven’t experienced any crashes or game breaking bugs which completely ruined my experience.
6. Final Verdict
Days Gone is really solid and decent game experience. I really enjoyed it. At the first I was not sure if I should buy it or not but now I don’t regret the purchase. It was worth it. Really amazing game with great graphics, audio, emotional story, great enemies....I could be talking about the possitives so long. There were also some negatives like stupid AI bugged enemies............ or the game missions sometimes seemed unneccessary, like just to be there. But these mistakes are just a little scratches on this amazing title and I rate it 9,5/10. I recommend you to play even now in 2024. You will not regret buying and experiencing Deacon’s adventure.

[h1]TL;DR - Days Gone is a time waster [/h1] 

[b]Overview:[/b]
- This is an old PS4 game from 2019. If you want to experience mediocre open world games made back in those days, this game ticks all the check box. 
- However this game aged like milk. For today's standard of gaming, this game is really boring, lackluster, and straight up felt like a chore.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- Great graphic and sound effect. Picturesque landscape and scenery.
- Realistic looking humans, zombies, animals, vehicles etc.
- Good combat mechanism. No bullet spamming like most zombie games.

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Inconsistency in every aspect. As if the game is made by different teams and then patched together with a duct tape, or - the developers suffers from ADHD or bipolar disorder. 
- The main character personality is just weird. Sometimes he is kind and attentive, sometimes he is a A-hole for no reason, sometimes he acts like he is a badass, sometimes he acts like he is sad for no reason. Yeah I get it, he behaves like this because he thinks that he lost his loved one due to his mistake. But the moment I start emphasizing, boom! random cringey A-hole moment! It's like trying to yawn after a long day only to get b-tch slapped out of nowhere. 
- The flow of the game is horrible. One moment you are having extremely intense combat with zombies, struggling to survive. One moment you are doing stealth trying to avoid getting spotted. One moment you are running around from point A to point B with literally nothing in sight. One moment you get ambushed out of nowhere. One moment you are savaging for craps. One moment you get hit with cheap jump scares. One moment you are hit with some random dialogue/cutscenes with forced slow walking. One moment you are running around again. And worst of all, the transitions felt extremely forced and inorganic. 
- Speaking of running around, this mechanism is literal time waster and act as a filler to artificially bloat the game length. Running 400m with nothing interesting along the way, just to reach a destination for something to happen, is just not fun. Sure there are zombies along the way but things are only interesting for the first couple of times. From there onward it's just felt like repetitive filler quests.
- Scavenging and crafting - insert monkey see monkey react meme here. All you do is hit right stick, interact with everything that pings. And no you can't ignore this feature because if you do, you'll be missing out on ammo, scraps or even healing items. 
- Incredibly slow pacing. Friend's arm hurt > find medicine > got interrupted by some NPCs. More than thrice. > go to some random camp > smash some zombies > run back. Entire process took 1.5 hours. If this isn't tormenting I don't know what is. From most reviews, it will take around 60 hours to complete just the main story. If I were 5 years younger I would probably have the patience for this nonsense. But today, hell no, I have better games to play.
- Camera follow player is on by default. Fortunately I googled and found the solution to turn this off. However I suffered from motion sickness and nausea within the first 30 mins in game. No idea how people enjoy the default settings but everything I do, shakes the camera. Run - Camera shake. Shoot, bullet recoil - Camera shake. Roll - Camera shake. Got hit - Camera shake. The entire experience was beyond frustrating.
 
[b]Conclusion:[/b]
- Below average game. Don't expect GTA, RDR or even Assassin Creed experience because this game is no way near any of those. Hell even death stranding, a game with literally a handful of NPCs, is more interesting than this crap. 
- Combat is fun and intense for the first 5-10 times. Then it gets repetitive and old very quickly. 
- At 75% discount, this game is still not worth it. Won't recommend it even if the discount is at 100%. No, even if you pay me to play this, I still won't.

This game is fantastic for so many reasons. It has a tremendous amount of high points and far-in-between low points spanning across its jam packed main campaign.

I went in thinking this game was going to rely 100% on zombie hordes based off all trailers, clips, and screenshots I saw, but with a lackluster campaign in return. I was very pleasantly surprised at how wrong I was on that.

The main character is super likable and has you rooting for him right away. Which I can’t say for most games I’ve played. I actually felt bad whenever things wouldn’t work out in his favor throughout the campaign. This also applies for the majority of the side characters. Even if they weren’t all “good guys,” most of them were really well written and still had qualities you didn’t hate.

The map is deceivingly large. At times it feels dull because the flat colors and (obvious) apocalyptic setting, but with unexpected zombie encounters and additional encounters, it doesn’t make it a chore to travel and found myself only using fast travel twice during my whole play through.

The individual zombie types and hordes were easily some of best zombies in comparison to anything I’ve played in the past. Their mechanics are designed to perfectly match the game’s pace and areas. Each horde was unique and every one of them made my heart rate get up with adrenaline.

The campaign is a treat. It’s very rare that a main campaign is so full of missions with a high completion time frame. I picked this up on sale and couldn’t believe how much of a game I got for the money. One of the few single player games in modern time I could have justified paying full price for on release day.

There’s only two reoccurring downsides that I kept being reminded of…The first is how unnecessary a lot of the actual campaign missions are. Which I realized is a pretty common gripe while scrolling through negative reviews for the game. So many times I found myself annoyed by driving across the map just to get a cutscene. This sort of thing happened constantly and it became annoying very early on. 

My second biggest downside is the overall ending arch to the campaign. The actual conclusion to the story is great. But the process to get there is grueling. More times than I could count I would feel like I was wasting so much doing nothing in order for the ending to be milked as slow as possible. The entire last section of the game took me around 5-6 hours to complete because of all the extra hoops you have to jump through. This was definitely my biggest complaint from the entire game. But even then, I’m not too upset because the ending paid off.

If you’re a fan of zombie/apocalypse games, this is an absolute must play. If you are looking for a game that you can get at a low sale price and get the most value for your money, this is your game. I highly recommend across the board.

TLDR -  Days gone offers a great story but its gameplay is in need of refinement and variety. 

The good
Having grown up around bikers and motorcycle clubs ( MC going forward ) and a big fan of Sons of Anarchy I was pretty surprised to see a story driven zombie game featuring a 1%er enforcer named Deacon as the story's protagonist the game somewhat revolves around the MC obviously being a zombie game society as we know it has collapsed so you won't be riding with everyone but you do get one of my favourite supporting characters Boozer a Sgt at arms who acts as the yin to Deacon's yang. You get lots of great moments with these two weather it be Deacon & Boozer reminiscing about the past with the MC or people they used to know and coming to terms with some of the difficult choices and not to mention trauma both of them have had to endure throughout their two years on the road their sense of brotherhood with each other is unmistakable. In summary, regarding the story it does it's job well characters are well written sometimes they are a bit irrational or even walking stereotypes just for the sake of progressing the plot but the game's story heavily leans on drama and it works well. I was a bit sad to see you can't customize Deacon in any way but you can pimp out your bike with better parts and different paints which was pretty cool the game also looks pretty good for a ps4 game maybe not as sharp as other games that were coming out when Days gone did but not bad for a console first game. There is so much more I could talk about regarding the story because it really is good but I want to keep this review spoiler free but to wrap up I got to praise the game for it's music choice the soundtrack is good but in one specific ride with Boozer it's a pretty emotional one and you get Jack Savoretti's soldiers eyes which really nails the moment home for sure one of my favourite rides of the game

The bad
The #1 biggest criticism I have for this game is it's draconian and invasive privacy policy not only does it take system information which I would be fine with but even in the "limited" data collection it states that it can look and save anything from websites and passwords and even record your keystrokes while the game is running. And the reason for all this? just to make sure you are not aimbotting or otherwise cheating in a singleplayer game it makes even less sense because not to say that I made use of this but some simple googling will show you an abundance of cheats and mods for the game from places like WeMod. The word is this crap can be blocked via firewall but sadly for me the game would CTD when I did so I had to put up with it but if you do buy the game I 100% recommend that you atleast try. Another big criticism I have is the game is very repetitive even during story missions you'll be doing jobs that would normally be a side gig stuff like bounty hunting or clearing out infected nests for example and it just makes the gameplay feel like a slog after 20 hours of doing this kind of thing I was burnt out and had to give the game a break you feel this the most in the third major part of the map by the time you get to it you've most likely done just about everything the previous parts had to offer and this map expansion opens up and not only adds a bunch more meaningless stuff ( in terms of story ) but it adds more to the areas you have already beaten ( horde killing ) I for one had zero motivation to do any of it and just did the story missions which already have this side content in them to begin with. I'm also gonna briefly touch on horde killing because it is such a pain to do and you have to do it for some story missions and it is awful you basically have to kill 100+ zombies who once they hear you fire a single round are gonna come running at you like the dinner bell just rang you also have limited stamina meaning once they start swarming you it's over the only way you really can beat them is by planing a bunch of resource which can be hard to find heavy equipment like traps and spamming molotovs like your life depends on it and even after all that there still will be quite a few stragglers I really wish they did literally anything else. Another minor gripe I have is the bike it still feels really slow after you get all the upgrades and have nitro considering how much ground you have to cover in the game I really feel that a more substantial speed boost is needed I do think they did this because some parts of the story are just radio calls that you do while you are travelling but out of those specific circumstances it does feel like a slog.

Although it starts slow and clumsy, Days Gone gradually builds into one of the better open-world post-apocalyptic zombie games. The story gets stronger in the back half too, built around some good relationships that have subtle interactions and excellent acting. Boozer and Deacon’s friendship can be appreciated due to their equally stubborn behavior. Flashbacks of Deacon with his wife also work quite well at giving players context. A gentle scattering of poignant story moments, sometimes found in the side quests, also elevate the narrative. Gameplay wise the motorcycle is central and its piecemeal upgrades provide a gentle sense of rewarding progression, much the same as the character upgrades. The roaming hordes of undead “freakers” are to be avoided early, but eventually you’ll need to take some down and these initial fights against hundreds of surging foes are frantic, relentless and absolutely enough to differentiate it from similar titles.

There aren't very many "outlaw" motorcycle games. LucasArts' Full Throttle was amazing in 1995, GTA4 The Lost and the Damned was pretty good (if short), GTA Online's Bikers stuff is okay. But there are almost no others that exist.

Days Gone is a great one for that Outlaw Biker vibe. 

The story is gripping, voice acting on point. Upgrading/customising the bike gives a great sense of progress. More to the point, the bike *feels* like riding a motorcycle.  Nearly every other motorcycle game feature crotch rockets. I want that lean-back LaZBoy feet up deep throttle rumble.

There isn't much for group riding like GTA's games. And I friggin' HATE zombies. I wouldn't normally *play* a game that had zombies as such a major component of the story, let alone the game. 

But Days Gone *felt* like being a lone biker making his way in a hostile -- and still beautiful -- environment, struggling between hope and cynicism, giving up on his humanity or doing the right thing. Imperfect, kind of a dick, but not, you know, a terrible person deep down. 

When the motorcycle is hibernating in storage, waiting for spring, Days Gone scratches that itch for me. Worth it.

This game blew me away right from the beginning. I usually only play a game for an hour, put a review out so everyone can see the first thoughts/opinions from the get go, but good lord I couldn't put this game down. I had to be pulled away. This is the zombie game we didn't know we needed. It has a slight Last of Us feel to it, but open world. It is amazing, I spent three hours just roaming around doing optional objectives because they were so intriguing.

Edit:

After finishing the game, I can say hands down that this is a serious, hidden gem. It has a heavy hitting, sad, loving, pain inducing story line that keeps you wanting more and more. Top 3 of my personal favorite games of all time, and even after completing the game I have actually continued on to 100% it, and then actually play through New Game+.

The developers also added story lines that continue even after the main story ends. Hands down, a phenomenal game. A must have.

Edit 2: 

I've decided to finish up my platinum trophy for this game, which requires me to beat the game on the hardest difficulty (and to play new game+) and I have some things I'd like to add. This game suffers a lot from really bad transitions. 

Cut scenes don't last very long in one spot. It'll fade to black and skip ahead a little bit which feels like they didn't know how to transition it. For example, in The Last of Us, a cut scene would lead you directly into the next part, no skipping, its cinematic. This game does the opposite. You'll be in a flashback and then 6 things will happen in a matter of 30 seconds with how much it skips around.

Another issue with the game is the dated missions. A lot of chase missions which would be fine if this game was a PS3 game, it's not a deal breaker but you can definitely tell that this game isn't going to hold up very well in the long run.

           The story starts out a little bit of a drag, but it's definitely worth sticking around to unlock better gear and the game opens up a whole lot more.

There's no better feeling than going from sticks and rocks to weapons of pure destruction. Finally getting to take on massive hordes of enemies you spent the early half of the game running from. 

            This is also definitely a game to start off playing on medium to harder difficulties, when its too easy it really takes away a lot from the games ability to make you really question whether or not your prepared to take a long trip or take on this camp you're going to attack. Being stuck out without fuel after an ambush really makes you feel like your fighting just to survive, and i think games that do that are often way more fun than a game that instantly gratifies you with all the weapons and ammo you need. 

I recommend it to people who like a good run and gun zombie shooter.

How to not be invaded by Sony's data stealing/tracking antics guide.

Windows 10/11
Press Windows Key to open the search bar.
Type "Windows Defender Firewall" and press Enter.
Navigate to Outbound Rules.
In the Windows Defender Firewall window, click on the "Advanced settings" option.
Select "Outbound Rules".
Select "New Rule" on the right side of the panel.
Keep "Program" selected, hit next.
Find "Days Gone" file path and copy and paste it into the "This program with" box, Exp: D:\Steam\steamapps\common\Days Gone. Hit "Next".
Select the "Block the Connection" option
Then Select all options of "Domain", "Private" and "Public". Hit "Next".
Name your rule "Sony can eat a fat D**k" then press "Finish".

And there you have it. Sony can no longer track or "steal" your data. Cheers.

This game is absolutely worth your time. Even if it's not on sale. It's a great game!

It's well made and the story is interesting with some surprises along the way. I also quite like the characters. The game is good-looking and most of the game mechanics are surprisingly fun although they do tend to repeat themselves.
But I don't really mind that. The activities themselves are well designed, and repeating them is no problem. Actually I would be sad if they weren't repeated as there are many, many ways to approach each of them. So the game basically gives you that opportunity for experimentation.

The voice acting is a bit wonky, especially for the main character of Deacon. He will often speak very loudly in a context where it doesn't fit very well. He also seems overly agitated and yabbers on about nothing when you basically just want him to shut up. I mean, he'll be happily yelling on the radio during a stealth segment with enemies 2 meters away. Luckily they don't hear it, but it makes for some odd situations that breaks the immersion a bit.

I feel like Deacon's voice acting is good. It just seems like he wasn't given proper direction when recording the lines.

The progression system is pretty nice. Also like upgrading my bike. The world is decently intriguing to roam around in and, as mentioned, the story makes me want to keep playing.

There's a great sense of progression to the gameplay as well. As you get better weapons and grow stronger physically you'll be able to take on more threatening enemies. And more of them at a time.
This plays well into the progression where you will sort of start out by being scared of even a single zombie. And as you get further along single zombies and even bigger groups becomes more of a puzzle in the sense that you can take them out, you just need to use the right tools for it. That's really cool!

[h1][b]Content[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 20/20[/b]

Days Gone is an open-world game that - depending on the percentage of completion, collectibles, and side activities - has a playtime of 40-70 hours. New Game+ adds another playthrough of playtime. In addition to the extensive story mode, the challenges game mode offers extra content.

[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 15/20[/b]

Gameplay-wise, at first glance, Days Gone is yet another survival open-world game set in its vast and repetitive open world. However, its uniqueness lies in a few key areas. Besides the usual shenanigans of these games, including a crafting system and other mandatory elements, the motorbike rides are probably the most underrated piece of its gameplay. As for the traversal, I'm happy to say that it doesn't take days to get anywhere and riding that motorbike is delightful. Fast traveling is a thing, and it consumes about the same amount of gas as if you were riding it yourself.

The gameplay in the open world revolves around maintaining the bike and filling the gas tank, as it's the sole thing that can save your life. Thankfully, it's possible to refuel in various locations, including camps and gas stations. So, gas isn't as scarce as you might think at first. There are tons and tons of police cars around the world that contain ammo in their trunks, so the ammo isn't as scarce. However, all this changes with higher difficulty levels. One thing that doesn't make much sense is that a remote forest in the middle of nowhere got so much police attention after the outbreak. I know it's a mechanic to help the player find ammo, but were these many police cars necessary? Other than that, I don't have complaints about resource looting.

As for the rest of the gameplay, there are these infestation areas and nests you must burn, enemy camps you must clear, Nero upgrade stations to visit, hordes to take out, etc. There are also friendly camps where you can upgrade your bike and weapons, purchase ammo, etc. The random activities that regularly pop up are mostly repetitive side hustles that I ignored completely for the most part. The whole gameplay loop is quite repetitive, as you'd expect, and there isn't anything special about any activities you do outside the main missions. The most enjoyable thing for me in Days Gone is shooting. Every single weapon in the game is satisfying to shoot. Hitting a headshot at a range with a rifle feels special, and shooting a few enemies in cowboy style using focus mode in close combat is as much fun. It's just pure sex if you ask me. The gameplay portion does require some getting used to. The main character also feels too heavy to control sometimes.

[h1][b]Presentation[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 13/20[/b]

Let me start by saying that the graphics are decent, but don't expect anything groundbreaking found in other PlayStation exclusives. There are plenty of locations that you must stop by and appreciate. I like it when a game offers carefully designed environments, and Days Gone excels at it in some ways and fails in others, making it a mixed bag. As for the sound quality, the soundtrack pieces are memorable, and the overall sound effect quality is also nicely done. The ambient sounds make you feel like you're there in person. The only thing that could've been better is the sound of zombies. At times, they sound like someone put a sock inside their mouths.

The animation work is another segment worth discussing, as it lacks quality. The overall movement feels satisfying, the cutscenes are of acceptable quality, and the bike you get to ride feels nice, but that's pretty much it. Character animations are static, and none have their "own" unique kind of movement, which is expected for this type of game and considering the publisher in question. The less significant nameless characters are almost identical to one another. Some games have specific animations for certain characters, making you believe they're real people. Days Gone feels like a AA (double-A) game aiming for AAA (triple-A) greatness. The rest of the animation work is acceptable, except the horde moments - which look like a swarm of ants running at you instead of zombies.

[h1][b]Story[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 14/20[/b]

The main problem with Days Gone and its storytelling is the pace and how everything starts bombastically and slows down too much for my taste. After the get to know the game part, it felt like nothing was happening for a good while. I was ready for the game to start throwing little bits and pieces of something bigger at me alongside exploration and stuff to keep me engaged, but it never happened in the way I expected. The repetitive side quests didn't help either, and I won't even begin to mention the average job the game does of introducing certain characters. There's a considerable lack of detail outside the most important stuff. The first few hours revolve around a great introduction and story missions that add depth and interest.

However, everything that follows feels more like a filler than a proper story unfolding. The constant tease of something bigger takes away from the overall experience and constant traversal from point A to B - "just" to unlock a new mission that is very much the same and as empty as the previous one, only in a different location. Sadly, I found most of what the game offers besides the main story missions boring, as there was nothing of value added to the overall experience. Yes, the game throws some intriguing side quests here and there that keep you curious, and the world exploration is inviting, but after a certain point, it gets too much to handle. After a while, and once quite a few of these side missions left me empty-handed, I stopped expecting anything special to happen.

It might be me not liking the slow and methodical approach or expecting too much too soon. But then again, I enjoyed other slow games. Its slowness didn't leave a good first impression on me, but I'm also not asking to see the ending. At least give me a reason to continue. About two-thirds (hours later) into the game, something big happens, and I was back aboard the hype train I jumped off after the introduction. The story eventually gets to the point where it should've started after the introduction. The only sad thing is that it might be too late for the real story to start unfolding this late for some people. In the end, if you ignore all the quirks at the start, it's worth dealing with all that lackluster pacing as it gets repaid in some sense later on. It could've been as half as long and it'd be perfect, as the stretching doesn't help it by any means.

[h1][b]Technicalities[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 18/20[/b]

If an open-world game like Days Gone uses UE4 - performance issues are a given. However, this one ran flawlessly for me, except for a few minor issues. As for the rest of this so-called PC port, the game runs perfectly and scales nicely across various hardware. There is no stutter, only the slow down at points during bike riding. It's very noticeable and feels like the game slows down to 0.5 speed. Other than this, thankfully, there are zero low points to report.

[h1][b]Final Verdict[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 80/100[/b]

Days Gone is yet another survival open-world video game worth playing that lacks the proper story pacing found in other AAA games of this caliber. I'd say Days Gone is like that one girl you have a crush on, and no matter how much you love and attention you give her - she won't give in until later on. As if that's something you're willing to tolerate until (and if) the hook-up eventually happens, that's up to you. I'm glad we got Days Gone on the PC - as it's a far better experience with all the unique PC features. I consider this one of the weakest and lowest points of PlayStation exclusives' storytelling. However, it's got its strong points worth playing through for.

[h1]A Ride That Doesn’t End[/h1] 
Days Gone is set in post-apocalyptic Oregon two years after the start of a pandemic that turned a portion of humanity into vicious zombie-like creatures. Former outlaw-turned-drifter Deacon St. John discovers his wife Sarah, having been assumed dead, may still be alive and goes on a quest to find her.

Hello friends,

Today i will review the game Days Gone. Days gone is a post-apocalyptic game based after a zombie/virus infection ruins the world. It is quite open world and there are many things to do around the beautiful world. The mountains and areas your character play in is very pretty. There is also great storyline that takes place around the world. There are also multiple storylines to play, which includes side missions. There is also a motorcycle the main character can equip different parts on to customize their motorcycle. At first, where you can explore will be a small area due to not having enough gas for the bike, but once a player upgrades their bike, the world becomes much bigger to explore. For those who like a difficult curve, there is also more difficult modes in the game, including Challenge Mode. Challenge mode lets you do set missions to get patches for main game playing to help you in the main storyline. Anyways, here are my PROS and CONS list:


PROS:

- A beautiful massive open ended world to explore.
- Ability to earn levels and open skills.
- Ability for player to customize their bike to different specs.
- Mutliple storylines and many side quests.
- Challenge mode and more difficult levels in case the game seems too easy.
- Post game quests to explore more of the world.
- Works with controllers. I am using a ZEN black switch controller.
- It works on windows 11 OS.

CONS:

- Some pop in graphic issues when loading areas happen.
- Some minor bugs found in the game, such as sometimes when killing monsters, they float in the air, or look like they are standing up.
- A serious bug happened to me. Basically, it did not load the ground geometry correctly. I did fix it by putting my graphic settings to low, shut down the game, restarted it, and played thru the section and it fixed it. You can find the bug here: https://steamcommunity.com/app/1259420/discussions/0/3053986162866724340/

Recommended game. The game actually reminds me alot of the MAD MAX game. Although the settings are different in both games, they both have that feel that is similiar in each game. If you personally like post apocalytipc open world games where you can explore while riding a bike around, this is your game. If the price is too high, consider buying it on sale. I bought it for 13.00 US dollars during the winter sale.

[h1]It's great. Probably a solid 8/10 for most people. [/h1]
[hr][/hr]

The game is a great length, I have 100% for all stories/sides and around 75% of the collectables (some don’t show on the map so I cba finding them), and that took around 40 hours. It doesn’t feel too short but manages to not overstay its welcome.

Admittedly it takes a while to get going, with the first few hours being fairly slow paced but it soon picks up and maintains a solid stride until the end.

Characters and voice acting are generally great, Rikki, Boozer and The Colonel stand out, but the quality is strong across the board. Every character serves a purpose - they are well written and have believable motivations.

The world is beautiful, it's no RDR2/Cyberpunk, but visually the game looks great. Lighting can be a little buggy sometimes, particularly in caves but this is a minor issue.

The port is one of the best from the PS collection, minus the occasional gamespeed issue (one section near the end of the game caused time itself to slow down if I angled the camera a certain way). Around 90FPS on a 3060Ti, maxed out at 1440p with no noticeable dips.

Killing the hordes is crazy fun, and I’m amazed at the technology behind it. It’s Hitman levels of crowd density, it looks and plays fantastic. 

And now the bad...

Deacon aims like a moron. Seriously. This is a third person shooter where the main character naturally has zero idea how to accurately fire a gun. HE WAS IN THE ARMY!!! This isn’t really an issue against freakers, but against human enemies it’s actually very frustrating. There are some perks you can unlocks as you progress through the game that slightly improve this but it’s still not good enough. Gunplay in general annoys me, not because it’s bad (as much as I’m complaining it’s actually fine), but because I really wish they went in a different direction with it. I spent half the game really wishing it had more of an Uncharted shooting style. There is no hipfire, and when you’re being chased halfway across Oregon by 300 freakers, you really want to be able to keep some movement speed up whilst shooting. Instead you have to awkwardly stop, turn, aim and then shoot. It really feels like a missed opportunity here.

The game can sometimes feel like it’s actively trying to wind you up. You go from a cutscene, into a 20 second long forced slow walk scene, then straight into another cutscene multiple times in this game. I have no idea why they did this. It’s also pretty buggy, enemies often clip through the ground, physics go wrong all the time and freaker AI can often be stumped by knee high walls. Pathing for all characters in the game is pretty bad, friendlies can easily be blocked by Deacon, and they make no effort to go around if this is the case. Deacon himself often walks in circles when trying to interact with people or pick up collectables, as the game does a terrible job at trying to get him in the correct position for the interaction. 

There is also a distinct lack of variety in both mission design, and map design. Story missions suffer less from this, but if you’re 100%ing like I did, some of the side missions can feel very repetitive. Go to place, kill humans come back. It also seems to force you to repeatedly pick these missions up from the quest giver for no logical reason. Deacon has a radio, and it’s used throughout the story – characters radio Deacon, telling them to come see them, rather than simply giving the details of the quest immediately. It feels a bit like padding the runtime, and it isn’t needed. This game is good enough and it isn’t necessary.

I always rant more than I need to and make it sound worse than it is. It’s really good and it’s a clear recommend for me. I liked the story, shooting freakers is great and I always felt the need to keep coming back to it.

I really, really, really wanted to like this game (as you might guess, since I played it for 130 hrs), but in the end, no.

Pros: 
1)Setting, scenery and stuff. It was really pretty. I like how most of the landscape looks and works. I like the changing seasons and variable weather.
2) I generally play a stealth character and MOST of this game lets me do this. I can kill most hordes by careful mining of an area and leading them to their doom. I love that I can sneak up and shiv a critter. Awesome. I like that I can sneak fairly near a nest and not trip the monsters.
3) The crossbow. I do 90% of my killing with this. It's AWESOME.
4) Bikes. Good plan. They go almost anywhere and you can do your own maintenance.
5) The setup makes sense. I love it when the internal logic works.

CONS
1) Data mining. I had no idea how bad it was when I set the game up. These people want ALL your data? All your passwords? Why? Parameters for a program have to be consciously decided, so it's no accident that they want to know literally EVERYTHING you do. I have a problem believing this is benign.
2) Your decisions are unimportant. No matter what you do, you will play the game they way they want. None of your decisions matter. You're a rat in a very limited maze. Believe me, if I could have popped Skizzo 5 minutes after I met him, I would have. Nope. He lives until the STORY says he dies. Want to tell Iron Mike he's a short sighted idiot? Nope, you play it out how they want you to. In this area Mass Effect is still god. The only decision you get is 'do I kill this zombie now or in five minutes'.
3) I get the concept of resource management, but dudes, you can't go a mile on a full tank of gas on a MOTORCYCLE? Seriously? Are you stupid? Do you people ride at all? You can go more than a mile on a QUART of gas, never mind filling the bike from a 5 gallon can. And the headlight? Great that you can turn it off, but it shouldn't turn itself on EVERY TIME. Yes, the light is minor, but so is a thorn in your shoe; it's tiny, but constantly annoying.
4) Ammo. I can only carry about 30 rounds for the rifle, 20 for the pistol and 8 for the crossbow. That's just stupid. Ffs, they make these cool things called POCKETS now. Flipside: you can carry 6 landmines, 6 proximity mines, 6 molotovs, 6 grenades, etc, etc, etc, which is also silly. It's... unbalanced. I can't carry stuff I use every 10 seconds, but I can carry tons of stuff I don't.
5) This is the one that destroyed it for me - THE HORDES REGENERATE. I was just at the saw mill where there is a huge horde. I had snuck in about 6 times and mined every flat surface. Now, the mines only go off if you're close enough for them to register on your radar, so I waited until the horde was home and cruised up on my bike. The mines went off. There were still several hundred zombies left. I set more mines and had them chase me through them. The mines went off and killed more. I got away on my scooter, rolled around and came back maybe 10 seconds later. THERE WERE NO CORPSES AND THE NUMBER OF ZOMBIES HAD NOT DIMINISHED. WHAT'S THE POINT IF YOU CAN'T EVEN KILL THEM? So, if the sawmill is so necessary that it has plot armor, why not put it somewhere that justifies monster immortality?
6) Quoting another reviewer; everybody's an a**hole. Everybody. I get that life's tough in the apocalypse, but damn. I don't want to do missions for any of these people. Your choices are literally work for the slaver, the militant thief, or the psychologically damaged idiot. At least with the slaver and the thief, survival is job 1, and they don't trust anyone equally. The PDI trusts both the thug whom he knows is out to destroy him, and the local insane terrorist organization. And Rikki... She supposedly rode with Deacon and Boozer in the earlier days of the disaster, but now she's surprised that you want to kill a bad guy, she's shocked that you want to be rid of the lunatics that kidnap people and torture them to death? Half the time she acts like she wants to play games with her girlfriend and make her jealous by how she treats you. Rikki's a hose-bag-moo-cow who needs a brains transplant from someone with sense. AND YOU HAVE NO CHOICE BUT TO DEAL WITH THESE PEOPLE.
6) The wolves. yeah, they're not hard to kill, but they're going to hit you no matter what you do. If you're already swinging the machete at their furry faces and they decide to jump, they hit, you don't. 
7) I really wish I could hit the thing I'm pointed at. 
8) How in the name of bhudda can I shoot a guy eight times in the chest and he keep coming? If he's that ripped on drugs, he shouldn't be able to fire a weapon accurately, or maybe not be able to fire one at all.

[h1]A slow burning masterfully crafted game[/h1] that hooked me in after some time and I couldn't drop it for real. It's got a lot of things correct and it's sad that we won't be getting a sequel for the time being.

Progression feels very satisfying. You are very weak at the start and you are afraid of hordes and getting shot. Overtime the main character psychologically advances whilst your stats and skills are getting advanced in a parallel, creating this doubly satisfactory game play loop. Aside from main char and the close friend, char progression could be done better. It feels like some of the chars' story lines got left hanging. Conclusion and path to it from the start feels satisfying enough. It could be easily followed by a sequel due to ending cliff hangers, it's got some good writing with some plot twists.

[b]Bike[/b] is  perhaps the best thing in the game. It feels realistic and fun to drive around and you get a deep customization system for it ranging from noise suppression to avoiding water damage and storing more ammunition.

My personal favorite thing about the game is the [b]random events[/b]. You can witness a great deal of random mayhem while driving around. In one occasion I lured a Breaker into a camp but I didn't know there was a Screamer zombie awaiting us. She screamed and called in a small horde then a black bear and a wolf pack joined the fight. All of these encounters being non scripted and organic is the peak point of this game along with displaying massive hordes with good collision.

Human enemy [b]AI[/b] is average at best but it doesn't apply to Freakers ( zombies you might call ). These guys can flank you, avoid molotov fire and cut path to reach you while being able to dodge bullets. It's fun to deal with giant horde of zombies coming at you while you try to set traps and mow down with your hit and run guerilla tactics.

[b]Gun play[/b] is good. Weapon sounds are loud and impactful. There are a ton of weapons and you need to grind to get them by completing story lines or building camp trusts. 

Watching sunset in a deserted area while hearing wolves howling birds chirping checking your surroundings for a potential stalker is a great feeling that this game achieves giving to you. If you like some open world story driven tense adventure game with slow burning fuel, this game is for you.

[h2] Make the game even better for yourself [/h2]
[b] The game has a great set of mods available. 
Do you find the game too easy? Install some mods ranging from increased freaker counts to decreased ammo to massive hordes. 
Do you want the game to look better? Install those amazing reshade mods that make the game look stunning. 
Do you want to make Deacon look like a special forces unit? They got that too along with a ton of weapon skin mods and various changes.
Just google it and you'll find what you want.
[/b]

[h3]”Nothing says true love like dog skulls”[/h3]
Days Gone is an open-world post-apocalyptic zombie game with survival elements. It's a LONG game. At the time of this review, the 68.7 hours I have in the game is a single playthrough doing only the main story with a fair number of extras.

You'll take the role of Deacon St. John, an abrasive character for sure. The game throws you not only into an active virus outbreak that leads to a zombie apocalypse, but into Deacon's relationships with a number of people. People he seems to not have the greatest history with — “burned bridges”. He's also stuck on his lost love, two sentiments I identify with more than I care to admit in my real life. Ultimately, this makes him slightly unlikable. That combined with the game's length makes this a game for people looking for a certain experience.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3144447687

[h3]My bike, my bike, my kingdom for my bike![/h3]
Being reductive, this game feels a lot like Death Stranding meets Far Cry. But I don't think it would be inappropriate to draw comparisons to Red Dead Redemption 2. 

Your bike is your lifeline. It's how you travel, it's how you save. It will literally save your life. Fast travel is allowed if you have the gas and the path is not obstructed by things like infestation zones. Otherwise you need to get around without it. The bike does need gas to function but this is relatively trivial as an aspect of the game's survival traits. For one, gas cans respawn and do not run out of gas. And gas pumps are still active in this time, it's only been a few years. When I first started playing, I became rather anxious thinking I'd need to be constantly concerned about gas. You're always getting something as well. Killing stray zombies (freaks) or marauders will earn you XP to upgrade Deacon's abilities. The freak ears and other zombie types can also be sold to camps for credits and that will also build trust. 

You do need to be careful however, ambushes can happen out of the blue. Not only this, but the gunfire or explosions can cause more freaks or non-infected wildlife to show up. Wolves, bears, mountain lions. The game can go from 0 to 100 real fast.

Your bike can be upgraded upon building trust with camps. As a drifter, you're able to go out on missions for a number of camps and establish more trust within them. You'll earn both trust (a type of XP really) and camp credits to refill things like ammo. Other resources can be pilfered out in the wild. You'll learn where to find certain types of resources as well — scrap can be found in almost any vehicle if the hood is still shut, gas cans are usually found around industrial vehicles such as tow trucks. Ammo can usually be found in police vehicles, medkits in ambulances — things you'd expect. 

Much like Death Stranding, while you aren't a “Porter”, you are effectively playing that same role within this world. You'll learn the map and better ways to navigate it to perform the tasks the camps want. Bounty hunting, horde killing, resource retrieval and more.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3144447046

There's also a bit of conspiracy if you investigate the NERO checkpoints and go down that path. 

[h3]The Gist[/h3]
I think this game appeals to a rather specific audience. It does have multiple endings and there's a TON to do in this game. Granted, it can be a tad grindy. But the gunplay is great, the bike riding is great and I personally identified with Deacon in a number of ways. More prudently, if you feel... lost in your real life, this game might be the exact thing you need to distract yourself for a time.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3144448670

If this game came out eight years ago, it might've been hailed as a masterpiece. But in 2023, it's just a mess. Everything feels outdated, from the story to the gameplay. Playing it is like slogging through an endless bore, way longer than it should be. I started annoyed, ended up bored, and wondered why I bothered.

The whole game is basic, boring, and feels like stuff we've seen for the past ten years. Nothing's new or interesting. The story is like a cheap zombie movie, super predictable, with characters that are more like cardboard cutouts than real people. The cutscenes are like a bad PowerPoint with constant fading in and out, making it hard to get into the game.

They hyped up the open-world thing, but it's a letdown. Just a big, empty space with the same tasks over and over. Clearing zombie nests or fetching supplies gets old fast. The missions feel like a never-ending cycle of boring. And the motorcycle rides? Seriously, what's the point of an open-world game when all you do is ride a noisy, clunky bike that handles like a messed-up shopping cart? Riding through the same dull landscapes gets real boring.

Now, the AI – it's a joke. Humans and animals act like they're in a comedy show. Human AI is so dumb, it's hard to believe. And animals? Wolves, deer, bears – that's it. Hunting them down feels more like a chore than survival.

And why does everyone in this game ride a big, loud, gas-guzzling bike in a world that's gone to hell? Like, is everyone suddenly a biker? No one uses a four-wheel vehicle in this game. I write this review after completing the story in 65 hours (took my time) but i still have some hordes and probably a last mission. Why i'm writing this before completely finishing everything? Just a little patience and you'll find out.

In my books this game is a 7/10, maybe 7.5. So you get an idea of my ranking God of War, Witcher 3 are a 10, Horizon zero dawn is a 8.5. 

I really loved this game. The idea is awesome, the story is captivating even though sometimes slow still loved it. I took my time and explored everything and enjoyed it very much. 

So why 7/10? Don't get me wrong this game could have been easily a masterpiece but i think someone at sony or whoever was in charge just pulled the plug at some points. They decided enough is enough. This reminds me of Cyberpunk at launch ... great but full of bugs and clearly unfinished. Sadly Days Gone is the same. What bugs you may ask ... Well deers flying, bike flying, bike stuck, crows stuck in the air, everyone flying, zombies running suddenly jump in the sky, getting stuck in nothing (literally i was walking and got stuck), getting stuck in a tree, falling off the map, crashes over crashes and so many more.

Then there are the little things that are not bugs but clearly give a vibe of bad planning like you could put a truck between two rock but you can't pass between them, you can press "E" to talk with someone and you spin around over and over and over and over again like 20 times before finally talking. Pressing E to get on bike fast but game doesn't let me. Climbing is allowed only on certain things even though in the situation you can climb on and in 65 hours there were so many moments i was like "wtf dude seriously" ... Clearly the game is very rough around the edges. Many tweaks should have been integrated but sadly that wasn’t what happened.

Then there's the difficulty which is too easy. I played directly at HARD2 and it's just a normal in comparasion with other games. I think it needed a tweak or new diff like nightmare or something.

Then there's the side quests or camp mission which are the same mission over and over again. This makes the difference between a masterpiece and just a good game. There are some quests when Deacon saves someone and they have a little chat and tease like they know eachother but you never met that person and you will never meet him/her again. I mean what a waste when you could implement the camp quests to be like bonding with the people in the camp but no. I think one of the only ones that mattered was when Manny from copeland was kidnapped but it was not enough. What a wasted opportunity. Just go and kill some people with no context and nothing to add to the story.

Then there's the walking during a quest when you have to walk at snail pace. We all hate that but happily that doesn't happen too often.

Then there's the fact that you can lose content without warning. The devs decided that doing a useless camp quest is more important than some side quests (marked with white) that actually give you an useful insight into Deacon. WTAF! What i mean by that is camp quests stay on the map and you can do them but white ones that usually are really important to the character dissapear. Pay attention at the quests! if you see a white one go do it because if you do something else that white quest can dissapear.

If you take your time exploring and you played a couple of games you’ll get a feeling that the game is not finished and i don’t believe for a second that a team that wrote the main story so well, that implemented a zombie survival game so well would, by choice, leave the game as it is. Many substories are left untold and those that are told feel like there was many more to be said. I don’t know how to explain it but this is the feeling that i got.

Even with all of this i loved the game!!

Oh, i almost forgot, why i’m writing this before finishing everything? BECAUSE IT CRASHED WHEN I WAS FIGHTING A HORDE ... AGAIN!!!
