Days Gone has the potential to be a good game, but has too much flaws and unpolished aspects to be recommended wholeheartedly.

Having played Days Gone to its completion, Days Gone shines the most in the early game where implementation of resource scarcity really makes you struggle to survive, but falls off when you realize it doesn’t have a lot of variety to offer, from its modes of gameplay to its variety of enemies, just repetition upon repetition upon repetition until you get sick of it by the end and finish it out of sunk cost obligation.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Gameplay in Days Gone mostly involves clearing an area of people, clearing an area of the infected, and a [b]LOT[/b] of long tedious motorcycle rides (for survival difficulty).  Having completed the game in survival mode, I do not recommend other play it for their first or subsequent playthrough beause the game isn't well designed to be played without the minimap/compass UI.

[h2]Enemy Variety[/h2]
I like the basic Swarmer infected, which are comparable to Lycans From Resident Evil 8, but do not like that Bleachers are basically Swarmers with more HP, or that Reachers are basically Swarmers with more HP and occasional zoomies, then there are Screamers which basically just summon 5 Swarmers. Days gone really struggles in its enemy variety; you don't really have unique strategies for unique infected variants, because they mostly act like tankier versions of the basic ones, you 1) dodge roll attacks and 2) shoot them in the head. 

The more-HP-and-damage ethos doesn’t just end with Swarmers, because infected wolves and bears are simply regular wolves and bears with more-HP-and-damage, with the same shitty wolf/bear startup attack animations that is more-or-less unreadable.

Human "marauders" factions are basically the same but in 3 different flavors,  sometimes with armor and helmets in the late game. Clearing with "marauder camps" is very comparable to clearing camps in Far Cry 3, or Tomb Raider, where stealth kills is an option or go in guns blazing.

[h2]Gameplay modes[/h2]
Stealth in this game is also comparable to Far Cry 3, but implemented poorly due to how fuzzy viewcones width and length are, the short duration from being noticed to a game over screen when detected in stealth sections.

Footprint tracking was a dull gameplay element in Witcher 3, it is also a dull element here, and arguably repeated way too much. Someone also forgot to change the color of footprints from white when you’re tracking on white surfaces like snow or brightly lit dirt paths.

There is a lot of motorcycle riding in Survival difficulty, which isn't great to control with mouse and keyboard (or controller, I suspect), and jumping off ramps isn't fun (no mid-air maneuvarablility, no backflips, and damage upon landing). There's no speed gauge UI to actually show speed gain from activating the nitro, and bike chase combat is basically just waiting for crosshairs to shrink.

Clearing Hordes are initially exhilarating but becomes a testament that even the best part of the game, will become tired and forgettable if you have to repeat them dozens of time with little variation.

Weapon balance is mostly skewed towards Assault rifles, SMGs, and machine guns which has high fire rate and ammo capacity, with sniper rifles having niche uses for distant humans and high HP infecteds, and the pistols, shotguns, and bowgun being next to useless in comparison.

Crafting is pretty barebones, and hardly becomes interesting with occasions where have to make a choice on two different tools you want sharing the same limited ingredients.

[h1]UI problems & general lack of polish[/h1]

The trigger zone for interactibles such as bike repairs, bike fueling and NPC interactions being finicky and annoying 

The game menu is a nightmare, good luck inspecting the collectible file you just found in there. 

The equipment wheel is another set of nightmare from the accursed realm that is console gaming, 

Also due to being a console game, some actions are bound to the same button such as reloading and switching with ground weapons, the 4 throwable explosives you have need to be shuffled with one key, then the same for 4 distractor items, and 3 land mine items.

The minimap is too zoomed in and doesn't show how far [?] events are from the player, the main map doesn't show anything that is shown in the minimap. The minimap also fails to show things you might be searching for such as generators, fuel cans, or those f@cking 7 polystyrene cups, along with the next tracking point-of-interest sometimes.

enemies sometimes freeze in space, swarmers sometimes have pathing errors and get stuck on walls or other geometries

Conversations sometimes overlaps and gets jumbled up between: Radio conversations, Radio Free Oregon, background characters talking, walk/ride n’ talk sections, NERO recorders, etc.

Conversations can be missed because they are cut short by area triggers. Sometimes the area trigger is placed a few meters of you, which means you get about 5 seconds of conversation before it is cut off.

Unintentional triggers for moving down ladders, moving under low gaps, moving across narrow gaps

No animation-cancelling for animal skinning or bunker hatch opening 

On one occasion, I attempted to escape a horde in a cave after the NPC on radio warned me that a horde was coming my way and told me to get out, the game pulled the “leaving mission zone” crap on me and forced me to kill the horde.

On another occasion I cleared a cave of human anarchists for the “just doing my job” mission, after which the game spawned an entire horde out of thin air right in front of me as soon as the mission was over.

Neither the map nor minimap showing the tunnels when you’re within cave systems.

Having to wait a couple of minutes out on the road before having to go back to the same quest-giver, rather than the quest-giver giving your next mission while you are right in front of him

 [h1]Story & characters[/h1]
Days Gone has a linear story structure where you can’t role-play or make meaningful choices impacting relationships or the fate of settlements. I’m generally fine with this in the same way I’m fine with Far Cry 3 and Resident Evils’ railroad linearity, but you should be aware that this isn’t your Fallout 1&2 type RPG where you travel to different towns and influence their fates and get to make decisions.

The story/writing & characters of Days gone is generally adequate… in the early sections, but kinda falters in the last act where certain pivotal events are really dry and underwhelming, and in the very last section pulls some tropes which degraded the story telling for me.

There also an underlying elements fo hypocrisy and lack of self-awareness for Deacon and the settlements when they are thieves (ScAvEnGiNg), mass murder camps that they come into conflict with (via You),  Spies (Deacon in last act), and oppressors to some degree, being work/slave camps leveraging safety and food; which is understandable if food and human labor is scarce in the post-apocalypse, but you do also keep finding plenty of mushrooms, berries, herbs, and deers as you ride around, along with wolves and bears that commit suicide by charging at you to their demise.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Overall, Days gone feels like a amalgamated reconstitution of systems from other games to make something painfully generic and unoriginal, from open world maps filled with enemy camps to clear, a half-baked crafting system, stat upgrades & skill point allocations, terrible stealth sections, repetitive footprint tracking sections, underdeveloped animal hunting, and the occasional uninspired bike chase sections. Where it takes from other games, Days Gone often does not improve upon them, and often makes it worse than its contemporaries

I had been looking at this game for a long time, and finally gave into buying it. However after 3 hours, I refunded it again, since it came with a variety of issues... And no, I'm not talking about performance, which btw I can't address it since I have a RTX 4070...

1. BUGGY TELEPORTING ENEMIES

NPCs are BUGGY! During the 3 hours I played, I experienced zombies and enemy humans teleporting randomly, as if they "had to reset themselves". One moment you are carefully watching a enemy sneaking around a truck, ready to attack him when he gets around the corner, and POOF he is gone... :/ Same goes for zombies btw, which also teleport completely away, or stutter about the place...

I don't think I have to explain why teleporting zombies, is a BIG mood kill in a zombie survival game...

2. WEIRD STORY PACING

This one really got to me... And honestly, I'm one of the last people to complain about story in a game... :/ During the intro, you[spoiler] save a radio tower [/spoiler], and after the mission you call various NPCs over your radio on your bike... And HELL breaks loose... ':D 

Imagine 6 random conversions, QUICK FIRING after each other so fast, that you have NO clue which conversation is relevant to which... I was left COMPLETELY lost, to what to do next... I had been given 6 different stories and objectives, and had no idea which mission progressed which story...

Clearly the pacing of the missions have not been taken into consideration... At that isn't all! D: RANDOM cutscenes will SLAP you in the face, in WEIRD inconvenient moments, that feels completely unnatural... As well as almost as if there is a 10sec time skip, between gameplay and cutscene...

The game... is WIERDLY build up in how story is delivered, in what I can best describe as "non AAA quality"... As if a small indie studio with inexperienced people, made the story flow design.

3. ENEMY AI

I don't know about everyone else... But when I saw trailers and gameplay of this game, I imagined this "flowy" enemy AI design, where a horde chased after you, made to feel alive and full of ragdol type characters... 

That is NOT how it feels, when you actually play the game.

Enemies, whether human or zombies, have the same 2-3 animations when they run at you... :/ Which SLAPS you in the face with a "you are playing a video game" feeling... Again, just like with teleporting zombies, it breaks immersion A LOT.

4. CONCLUSION

I was looking forward to this game, but it wasn't at all what I had expected... :/ It is NOT a polished experience, and it does NOT feel "alive" like something like The Last of Us does, when it comes to the games story and flow... 

Buy it on sale. Not for full price.

This game is one of the best story games I have played. Most of the main and side characters are funny and interesting with unique personalities and traits. Graphics are great and it runs well. The massive zombie hordes are an actual threat and can end you quickly if you aren't prepared.  While there are the typical open world copy/paste side activities like clearing bandit camps, zombie nests and collecting NERO injectors, I find them all fun even if they are often seen as repetitive and annoying. They really nail the bike mechanics and overall feel. Constantly having your bike with you makes it become a part of the player, and although not as in depth, reminds me of Horses from Red Dead Redemption 2 except you don't constantly talk to your bike and pat it on the head. 

This is one of the first games besides The Last of Us that really does the post apocalyptic atmosphere right. There are corpses, zombies attacking AI survivors/wildlife and traffic jams all over. Accidents and hazardous conditions like flooded roads, roads destroyed by mudslides, roads blocked by trees or vehicles plus many other set pieces can be seen throughout the massive open world map. Combined with the soundtrack it gives you a creepy and unsettling feeling. I've gotten side tracked time after time to look at many different aspects of the environment. Bend did a really good job at creating an immersive world. There is a photo mode as well, which only makes the number of times I get sidetracked worse for me.

My only gripe? The stupid, and very unnecessary data collection policy. Sony this is a single player story game, there is literally nothing you need to collect data wise. I don't care if its "anonymous", its a problem and needs to stop. I'm not going to trust a corporation when they tell me my data is "anonymous". While I would really suggest that the data collection is removed from the game, I am well aware Sony wont do it. 

Overall besides the data collection bullshit, Bend Studios did a fantastic job here, and this makes me really happy to see what other PS-exclusive titles will be making their way to Steam. 8.5/10.

Didn't have the occasion to play it on release. Bought it out of curiosity. Reviews from the press back in '21 exagerrated a lot of aspects of this game out of spite for the whole "hollow Open World" craze.

In summary ? It may be the best Far Cry/Ubisoft "go everywhere and do/collect stuff" game out there. Easily surpassing comparable games. The story, albeit formulaic, is pretty interesting too. It's thanks to the storytelling and the narrative design as well, which managed to immerse me without making me feel like completing secondary missions like I would do my chores. The clear 3 Act structure also kind of feels like playing a trilogy/duology in a single game, thanks to the separate storylines. Although the game clearly was thought as the start of a saga, it feels pretty complete and don't really makes you mad about the cancellation of the sequel.

On the other hand, gameplay is a mixed bag. There are a lot of nice ideas that just feel wasted. Zombies ("Freakers") are a joke at best and infuriating at worst: Hordes are fun at first, until you realize that running and gunning while throwing the occasional is preferable to setting up traps and using your environment. In the same way, difficulty settings feel tacked on and worsening the experience instead of enhancing it: "Survival" in particular removes general Quality of Life features such as Fast Travel or the HUD without giving clear alternatives, like visual cues for life outside of the screen flashing red when near death... All the while not removing any of the cheesy running & gunning strategy.

The worst offender there are probably the challenge mode, which has the potential to make you actively hate the game if you try to 100% achievement complete it. They are clearly a poorly planned afterthought tacked on a game that was definitely not designed for that kind of gameplay (especially not on the Steam Deck, on which they constantly crash).

All in all, Days Gone is an imperfect but still greatly enjoyable experience, with an interesting story and setting and gorgeous visuals. I'd still recommend it for those who want a proper "Walking Dead-esque" experience.

Note: Apparently, the data collection in the game is ... wild, to say the least. Other reviews cover it extensively. So, be warned.

Rev up your engines and brace yourselves, fellow gamers, because we're diving headfirst into the wild, untamed world of survival and mayhem. This game isn't just a joyride; it's a heart-pounding, gut-wrenching roller coaster through a post-apocalyptic landscape that'll leave you on the edge of your gaming seat.

Visually, it's a feast for the eyes. From lush greenery to the cracked roadways, every pixel feels like it's been handcrafted to perfection. From sun-scorched dunes, arid expanses to desolate highways, each locale meticulously designed to convey a sense of both beauty and decay. The world isn't just a backdrop; it's a character, constantly evolving with dynamic weather that adds a layer of immersion you won't see coming. 

Your ride-or-die companion in this chaos? A protagonist whose journey is as kick ass as the combat encounters. With a performance that's more than just lines on a screen, you're not playing a game; you're living a gritty, emotional saga in the midst of a world gone mad.

Story-wise, it's a wild ride through loyalty, betrayal, and all the juicy drama you'd want in an apocalyptic epic. Your choices matter, and the consequences hit hard, turning the game into a gripping narrative where you're not just a player but a survivor fighting against the odds.

Gameplay? Hold onto your controllers and keyboards. Your bike isn't just a mode of transportation; it's your lifeline. Navigating through hordes of freakish enemies is a dance of bullets, explosions, and adrenaline-pumping escapes. It's like a symphony of chaos, and you're the rockstar orchestrating the madness.

In a sea of post-apocalyptic titles, this one's a standout. Whether you're a seasoned apocalypse veteran or a newbie to the genre, this game is your golden ticket. Get ready for a wild ride, where every decision is a game-changer, and survival isn't just a goal—it's a way of life. Welcome to the apocalypse, gamers; it's time to own it.

The open world aspect kind of ruined the story for me. Up until the ending I was going to not recommend the game. For most people if you can get through the main story, the open world aspect works flawlessly.

I wanted to love this game so bad, and I kind of do in spite of its flaws. Love, and hate title for me.
**some potential spoilers**
The graphics are freaking amazing! Movies and Games always make me wish I could afford a house in Oregon or Washington.

The Fear was real the first time I tried this game, but when I actually started getting decent I was knifing, using the pistol, and able to conserve ammo most of the time for Hordes.

The beefy boys although annoying and bugged out a few times were so freaking fun. There hits did not feel cheap. What did bother me is their health level. Of course it made sense but still did not feel fair because the lower level zombies kind of ruin the fun of the beefy boys with their jank.

For such a diverse game, and being located in Oregon I was expecting more diversity than what we got. Yes this is still the best game and story i've read in a long time in regards to Diversity, but Deacon or even Boozer could have been anything but white. They clearly realized this mentioning Deacon does come off as racist but is not.

I kind of wish we could have customized Deacon to are liking and made the choice ourselves to have other romances and have that affect Deacon's relationship with Sarah. I get why they did not do it still wanted it though.

Not a single person recognizes how good Deacon is at taking down the Hordes BS! The man has killed thousands of zombies nearly clearly the entire half of the state, including Ambush camps and the freaking Reapers by his freaking self! And no one acknowledges it? Are you freaking kidding me? The only person that kind of does without saying anything is Lisa.

Things ruined by game logic: If a person takes a baseball axe to the face either better be dead or on the ground. If a person gets shot with a sawed off or pump action shotgun in the leg or body better be on the ground and unable to get up.

Zombies are fiction as of right now, so to each their own; It will always bother me when basic zombies can climb, open doors, and move fast. Story somewhat makes it work.

Even though the story explains it the Zombies having an attack at all feels like total crap. Now if it was just the extra creepy beefy boys than I'd be more understandable. But when I died because the zombies were given cheap shots (I rolled away and they still make contact pull me back to the horde) broke my immersion more than once to almost rage quitting.

Maybe a person problem: I was expecting the Nero sites to make Deacon almost super human. Border line zombie speed, and strength. Would have explained him not needing to eat ever and be able to take down the 50+ let alone the 100+ Hordes. At the end of the day Nero sites are useless. If you git good like some say you could beat the entire game without them.

Guns are broken as H***. The only guns that did not break my immersion were the most powerful weapons in the game. If the damage output was better the gunplay would be better than every Rockstar game ever.

Sniper Rifle is also kind of broken. If you know anything about guns they might break your immersion. From a certain distance they don't hit the target and the target may or may not acknolwdge it.
Late game Deacon (before end game) at least for me became super buggy for some reason. The zombies as well.

Stealth is absolutely freaking broken. When it does work it makes you want to do it more and you will end up realizing how broken it freaking eyes. The stupid eye will be grayed out and the Ambush camps (bandits basically) will still be aware of your location even if you move.

Why the actual heck is every single person Deacon comes across is so good at hand to hand combat and darn near John Wick level marksman? These are supposed to be people who just so happened to survive out of sheer luck and I call bull crap. The snipers especially. Three or four I understand. When I realized every single Ambush camp sniper and melee fighter (clubs no guns) were experts being able to eventually dodge Deacon's blade it broke my immersion to almost rage quitting.

Holy Crap the ending made me love the characters that struggled to make me like them through 80% if not 90% of the story. For the longest time I was like why should care about any of these people that were being mean for zero reason to Deacon. Even after they did have a reason it was feeling 100% unjustified. If you think Deacon deserves because of the reasons given think about all the work he puts in them doing what they did is 100% justified. 

Everyone wants something from Deacon and Boozer who do what is demanded of them without true lip. And when Deacon and Boozer need something they get real lip. No wonder Lisa. Lisa is my favorite character who was almost ruined story wise because they needed more shocking drama similar to Walking Dead back in the day, and I almost rage quit the game just like I quit watching Walking Dead for the same reason.

I honestly can't recommend this enough. It was a shock how good it is. It was 12 dollars. Probably the biggest bang for my buck I've gotten in a long, long time.

Now, some problems here. The UI is manageable but glitched a time or two. A restart fixed it.

Some of the mechanics or gameplay elements are poorly implemented. These mechanics are good in concept, but failed in execution. An example would be certain 'mystery events' that you encounter. Without giving too much away, suffice it to say that sometimes an 'event' happens, your map alerts you, and by the time you get there it's already happened and congrats - you did not save the people or do the thing you were supposed to because you're a slow ass motherfucker (I guess?). No, it does not matter that you literally drove your bike over cliffs to get there.

The game can easily be placed, in concept, among Red Dead and Witcher 3. You play a social outsider. But Days Gone feels far more novel and niche - a biker in a post apocalyptic hellscape is a surprisingly unique framework that doesn't require the magical hand waving of fantasy nor the archaic mythology of the wild west.

I will say that 'hordes' are an annoying but unique, interesting, and enjoyable situation you have to deal with at times. Now, I did say annoying, and I meant it, but I recognize that my dislike of the mechanic does not necessarily mean it's a bad mechanic. But anyway, the mechanic had its place in the game and worked well.

The main story is great. The cinematic elements and their attending soundtracks left a deep impression on me as the player. I can really tell that the devs wanted to make excellent tonality, and they succeeded.

The characters and their voice acting are amazing, each showing not only depth and uniqueness but dynamic progression. 

The narrative design work is peppered throughout in a pleasing, consistent fashion that rewards the grind you have to do at times. 

A small number of the side quests are genuinely interesting, though most are quite repetitive - but this is a trope of the open world genre, I think.

The drive mechanic is fun (I'm bad at it). 

The weakness is the UI, which at times feels built 'too much' for console. Crafting is overly simplified and yet somehow obnoxiously necessary. The weapons are tiered - meaning that cool gun you like won't mean shit in the next area, so why buy it? The faces of some of the characters are weirdly blank during some of the cut scene dialogues - not sure why. 

8/10 - this game deserved a better rep than it apparently got in 2021. Not even sure how I missed it back then. Hope a studio picks it up to do a sequel. Wish I had Musk money, I'd do it in a heartbeat even if sequels tend to fall short of their predecessors. Some things should just be made even if it can't live up to its origin (I'M SORRY DAD).

Was looking forward to this game for several years but put off on it due to poor initial reviews in 2019. The PC Steam release worked well for me with little to no issues. Got this at a big year end discount <$20 so it was definitely well worth the money.

STORY:  The story is great, character building and emotions are realistic for a post-apocalyptic setting. People grow apart, undergo traumatic events and change or stay true to themselves. The protagonist resonates with me a lot.  

VISUAL/AUDIO:  Not quite there compared to Red Dead Redemption 2 (RDR2, 2018), but that's an incredibly high bar. Still pretty decent, the light effects from dusk through dawn are great. Night visuals and the starry sky are awesome.
No dizziness for a 3rd person perspective, although it can get annoying in enclosed spaces due to field depth issues. 
Kudos to the voice actors and animation, their voice acting and facial expressions are pretty on point. 
Gotta hand it to the sound effects team. The zombies groans/screeches/grunts/etc ALWAYS make my skin crawl through the game, akin to hearing someone scratch a blackboard with fingernails. Ugh.

GAMEPLAY/MECHANICS:  Some survival mechanics are a chore and somewhat pointless, especially scrapping for materials. Unsure why there's lengthy animation sequences needed for some tasks (getting meat from game). RDR2 had an extensive sequence of skinning animals to promote realism, since that fit the theme of the time. Sticking a hunting knife into a bear or deer in Days Gone to gain a sliver of meat is stupid.

Tons of buildings littered throughout the world, but majority are useless. Would be nice if we were rewarded for combing through all of them with special upgrades, but it's just more of the same, and items get replenished every so often. Eventually you get all you need from camps and ignore all the random loot lying around, which makes them pointless midway through the game.

Fighting mechanics are decent, feels a lot better than RDR2, but human AI is pretty dumb. Hordes do always keep the tension up given the swarm tactics. Wish there was a way to up the number of zombies. Difficulty level just caps them at Hard II. Survival mode seems to only remove the HUD which makes it annoying rather than difficult.

I’m aware I do not have a lot of hours logged here at the time of this review but I did play through the game originally on PS4 when it first came out. Thrilled it’s on PC. 
First off, this game is not the Last of Us, so I’d kill those expectations first. I’d give the story and story telling about a B- overall but that doesn’t mean I don’t want more. There’s enough (story) here by the way that could have probably filled two games or one and a dlc, but to me I take that as two for the price of one.
Its open world mechanics aren’t exactly anything new. They do give you a motorcycle to navigate the world easier which can be upgraded and the map is huge and fortunately feels varied despite all of it basically being based on US west coast forest. Some of the recurring side events (and some story ones) I did find very repetitive which is about the only thing I am not looking forward to on a new play through.
Deacon the main character is a positive standout which is a huge plus, much credit goes to the actor playing him. I never even found his consistent mumblings to himself to get old despite the 20+ hours of gameplay. In fact all the performances are pretty solid.
The zombies (freakers) hordes are far and away the best mechanic of the game and there’s plenty of encounters to keep them threatening. It’s (in a good way) quite jarring to stumble upon an army of them unprepared. I remember these hordes were used for marketing the game and ultimately is what makes the game standout from the other apocalyptic zombie games. Time will tell how long that lasts. I think as other future games implement similar mechanics into their games Days Gone will lose some of its novelty.
This is a big reason as to why the game  just really needs a sequel. The developers need a real chance to follow up with what this world really can be. It’s set up for it. I can’t help but think of Mass Effect; if we only had the first game we would’ve only had a taste of what could have been. Fortunately Mass Effect 2 came out and made the series what it is.
This game needs to be a series. It needs its Mass Effect 2. It would become great.
Overall, 8/10. Highly recommend.

I really enjoyed this game in the beginning. Graphics are good, gameplay is fun and zombies pose a real threat. I really want to recommend the game, but the short list of pros is where it ends. 

1. 90% of this game is cinematics. Granted its an interesting story, but too many times, at the end of a long play session I just want to save the game, but have to sit through the rest of a cinematic that just takes way too long. Maybe its a personal thing, but I just don't enjoy games that have to tell long drawn out stories. If I wanted a good story I could watch Netflix.

2. Some glitches in the game like trying to select a throwable and it won't select it on my character after countless tries. Meanwhile I get battered by zombies or zombie birds while trying to select molotoves which I know I have because my weapon wheel shows I have 3/3 in inventory. The same thing with trying to throw rocks to distract enemies. I think I have the rock selected because I clearly selected it, only to throw a damn smoke grenade. 

3. Positioning to open up cars hoods, trunks, doors etc requires having to have the character in an exact spot before the animation gets triggered, usually ends up fiddling constantly with WASD keys. Its ok while not in the heat of battle but when you're in a hurry it often leaves you vulnerable. 

4. You need to have enough time set aside to play. An hour session really only leaves you about 10% of actual game play while 90% of it is spent in dialog with other NPC's. And God forbid you have to be near your bike to save the game. Not sure if thats a shortcoming on the devs part or just some silly joke. 

I've got almost 30 hours invested and I do want to see how the story ends on my own without watching any videos. But this will be my only play-through and then its getting uninstalled as I just don't see this game as anything that has replay-ability. 

If you enjoy story driven games (which I get, some people do), then by all means get it. However, I can't give this game a good recommendation. Its got good gameplay elements for sure, but it should be the majority of your time spent playing, not sitting back at your pc watching character/NPC dialog.

As I played this game through the first time, I couldn't help but compare it to Red Dead Redemption 2, and by the time I finished that playthrough, I came to realise I like this game more than RDR2.

Not because the characters are better, because they aren't, or the graphics are prettier, because they also aren't, or the world is larger or more interactive, because none of that either.

But the gameplay does nearly everything RDR2 does, except in a simpler, not over-animated way, and the simplicity is what makes this game great. You have survivor camps instead of towns, simple barter and upgrade systems, fast travel that uses petrol. You have a bike instead of a horse.

Lots of side quest lines, lots of activity on the map, lots of opportunities to loot, explore, and scavenge. Main story line is a kinda 'TESCO Value Walking Dead' at bits, but isn't bad at all, keeps you engaged on long term, I actually cared how the characters end up or if they survive or not.

The bandits and wild animals I worried in Red Dead 2 got replaced with zombies. From child-sized to massive mutants that survive multiple headshots, from small groups to vast screaming hordes of hundreds. Nobody can prepare you for the first fight with a horde.

Of course, there are still bandits.
And wild animals. And zombie wild animals (OH GOD, THE BEARS)

The greatest adversaries are the infected and religion instead of the law and capitalism like in RDR. Sadly lacking survival system, though, but big open world, investigation missions, bounty hunting, zombie hunting, animal hunting, picking flowers and making your own crossbow bolts like a big boy. 

Incredibly simple and easy looting/crafting dynamic, lack of tuberculosis, decent melee, good ranged combat. Traps, bombs, explosives, the environment can all be utilised to take out the infected, and humanity's oldest and worst enemy: other humans.

I can't say a single thing I don't like about this game, even it's poorest qualities are mid at worst.

Worth full price.

Just 3h in and I'm certainly glad I waited for a sale to buy.  A break from the standard zombie formula, I thought exploring the beautifully rendered PNW on my custom adventure bike would be engrossing with a somewhat forlorn but hopeful ambiance.  Instead, the world is pointlessly and inexplicably overrun by zombies; seriously, the zombie population density in the Oregon wilderness is higher than pre-outbreak modern NYC.  It makes no sense.

The characters are as unlikable as they are 1-dimensional, leaving you incapable of empathizing with any of them.  It seems like every 30 seconds somebody is calling me on the radio to tell me their problems, often the same person two or three times in a row.  Of course as soon as that's done, another poorly executed post-apocalypse prepper radio program comes on that you skip as soon as your finger can find the correct key.  I cannot recall how often I was just saying "shut up" at the screen.

The "ambiance" around other NPCs, such as in the initial settlement you use as a base of operations, is reminiscent of Skyrim, and not in a good way.  It's arrows to the knee times a hundred.  Every time you turn, the nearest NPC or two are commenting on you, and you automatically respond as only a tortured, emo, 1-dimensional, backwards-baseball-cap wearing 1%er stereotype would deem appropriate.

Being left in peace to explore the world is extremely rare, and when it does happen, you unfortunately discover just how empty the world is, not simply of people, but of stories, lore, and imagination.

These shortcomings are exacerbated by the many niggling little mechanical annoyances.

Like many (but not all) 3rd person perspective games, Days Gone has a setup where, shortly after you've stopped actively changing your view while driving/riding, it will turn back towards the direction of travel.  In order to keep your eyes on something to the side or behind you, you have to first move it into view, and then constantly jiggle or adjust the mouse to prevent the game from automatically recentering.  If you're a game developer reading this, take note: It's not welcome.  Stop screwing with my view after I've put it where I want it.  I know how to turn it back if I want to, believe me.

Random encounters can interfere with scripted missions, causing you to lose them and restart the mission, which may also force you to listen to a not insignificant amount of dialog.  I had to play the first bike chase (I'm assuming there are more to come) no less than three times after getting too far away from my prey.  The first time, it was because the game decided to randomly spawn wolves on top of me as soon as the NPC appeared, knocking me down and delaying my pursuit just long enough to prevent catching up.  The second time, the wolves did not appear, but the person I was tasked with chasing collided with my parked bike as they rode past, spinning it around and knocking it over.

The activation controls are horribly wonky within the world.  You hold down the key, a circle builds up, and if you're lucky the action you're trying to accomplish will take place.  More often than that though, you don't start in precisely the right position, so you'll be slowly moved towards the correct spot while the circle fills, after which you'll stop and the activation icon will remain until you release it and start again.  Of course you'll hear Manny comment once again how he didn't know it was your bike, because hey, he hasn't told you that 3471 times already this visit.

Finally the save "mechanic" is inexcusibly lame.  It's not classic Resident Evil lame, but it's lame.  You can only save near your bike, or near a bed.  You can't just save "anywhere."  This is so intolerably lame that I just can't express it.  I can save wherever I want in a 12 year old game like Fallout 3, but not here in the PNW.  Gotta be near the bike.

Maybe some day I'll reinstall this game and give it another chance, but for now, it's uninstalled with barely 3 hours in.  It's unfortunate I didn't really figure all this out in the first two hours, so I'd have a chance at a refund.

Note to Steam and different game devs: This sort of experience is why I refuse to buy any games that are not at least 35% off, and while I wait for most of them to be 50% off or greater.  Since you won't allow a secondary (read: used) game market for digital games, meaning I cannot resell them to recoup some of the expense, I'm forced to just wait until they go on sale.

Days Gone is another zombie story led simulator, Your basically playing Deacon st John, a lone wolf who is trying to keep his friend alive after the initial "outbreak".

The game does not tell you much until about ten hours into playing it, which seems an odd choice of playstyle. Deacon's girlfriend gets stabbed during the outbreak, but her whereabouts are left a mystery, as to Deacons memories of the past two years, which you will not see till you play the game further on. Again this seems to give the game a poor way to start and play, but as you explore, the game evolves further as to the chaos of the last two years. It also explains the expired day counter which is on the main menu. 

Your basically learning more about the "outbreak" and why the area is so infested with zombies. You need to get out of the area alive, but things simply do not go your way, your bike is stolen for parts, you have your injured buddy and not much to heal him. You will face hordes of zombies, ambushes, people with agendas, mad survivalists to name a few problems.

Emergency government triage teams infest the area as well, covertly looking for answers too, as to why the zombies are so aggressive, usual governmental conspiracy cover up story. You will also face other surprises along the way, such as wolves, some bad luck and many other obstacles before you can leave this town for good. 

There are a few tutorials to get you started too, basics in movement, gameplay, weapons, crafting and how to upgrade your skills, however the game places a lot of limits on what you can carry initially and what you can craft at the start of the game, which leaves you really equipped very bascially at the start. You will spend half the game foraging for items to be able to use most of the weapons you craft or find, that you can only store half and carry even less.

Ammo, arrows, med kits, scrap for repairs, all need to be found. You can barter for some of these items, but you need to exchange missions and/or trade animal furs/zombie ears if you want to get anything meaningful. You also have transport in that you have a bike too, but its often the first thing that gets damaged or targeted, you will need to keep it repaired and fuelled if you want to get around the area map.  

The game looks nice, there are day and night cycles, although the time only appears on the map screen, which is a little inconvenient, also night time is a bit brighter and looks a lot like day, so you may want to adjust the gamma or use the darker night mod to truly inspire the terror of exploration in the twilight hours.

There are also weather patterns with sunny spells, rain and windy showers, all render quite nicely. The graphics are suitably somber in places and music plays differently depending on the perceived danger you might be in. Deacon can sometimes move fairly slowly at the start so its up to you to find upgrades and skills that make his abilities better, that also includes the bike as some "secret" items are dependant on your bike being able to traverse large gaps with nitrous boosts. (which of course you need to barter for). 

There are also collectables to be found, herbs, stims, magazines, recordings, but a lot is just used for trust levels so you can barter, the rest is basically junk unless your an avid collector for game completion. The zombies themselves all vary in designs, some will run away from you, some wont, some will leap on you, it varies.

People on the other hand seem intent on harming you mostly, ambush you at every opportunity on the highways, beware of traps. A few people will help you for a price too, its upto you to work out who and when. You can turn some of this to your advantage with a well placed arrow that causes a bit of chaos, people/zombies will then turn on each other sometimes if you get the right equipment and you dont blow yourself up in the process. 

Saving the game is a bit of a mixed bag, you need your bike or a bed, so if you leave it behind you may find yourself missing out on a long save. Fast travel will not work on an area you have not cleared in terms of nests, so only works when your bike is close and will cost you money and gas as well. Speaking of time, you can fast forward time by simply going to bed, night turns to day, day turns to night. This affects zombie behavior as during the day they are weaker, night time you are more likely to get your head ripped off. You do get xp for killing zombies and missions, but weapons have limited uses, so choose wisely. 

There are plenty of missions to accomplish, side and minor quests to help you on your way, some are hidden deliberately, but keep an eye out for downed choppers, medical sites, these sometimes offer permanent bonus stims that you can boost Deacon's health and stamina with, (amongst other things). Be aware even these missions may contain some form of "trap", in that you need to look before you leap (so to speak), Some missions are timed, some are opportunistic and can disappear if you do not investigate them. 

It is at this point you begin to realise this game plays out a lot like another zombie survival game, state of decay. It is also at this point you realise the limits of this game, combat is fairly okay, but no weapon blocking, you can dodge or knock zombies down (with the right skills invested of course).

You can find encampments (some are not friendly!) and trade for missions, these are used to get better weapons, seems each camp has a speciality in terms of weapons/engine parts, so it encourages exploration. This does mean your constantly on the lookout for fuel, but the main highway has other pitfalls when you traverse it.

Some missions can be a little frustrating as your weapons and certain options are deliberately disabled by the story telling, Apparently scientists are immune to bullets, so you cant kill them, just observe. lots of loading segments in some sections, small persistant movie interruptions for a pc game this can be a bit jarring. (clearly console ported) and quite annoying at times. 

Weapons decay in durability  can often catch you out in the middle of a fight, your bike falls apart over time with damage, you need to constantly scavenge and refuel for items to use. Items are scattered everywhere so you can usually find everything you need generally, its just the constant foraging that starts to get boring after a while, your weapons durability drops so fast too, so your constantly fixing them. It becomes a drag to play for longer periods after a while, because your not really doing anything in the game. It does make makes missions seem a lot longer than they probably are.

Speaking of missions they are varied, but some are timed, place restrictions on what you can and cannot do, you have all this freedom and then the game takes it away from you very quickly for ridiculous reasons. oh an apparently wolves can rip you off a moving vehicle at a 100 miles an hour, hmm okay.  I am invested in furthering the story, but sometimes I just want to save the game and exit for a bit and take a break.  The story itself seems absent till about  ten hours in, then suddenly you figure out what is going on partially,  once you get past that, things get interesting. Nest hunting is a tad dull and predictable, but necessary if you want to unlock fast travel points.

I would still recommend the game, but I would wait till its on sale, the genre has already been done before several times. Night times need adjusting as they are far too bright. Also some quests disable fuel requirements for storytelling, how convenient.

Pros: The game has some beautiful graphics, varied playstyles, melee or ranged combat, crafting, etc.

Cons: Story does not kick in for quite a long while, can put people off playing, repetitive gameplay can get boring in long sessions.

If you're okay with that then it's pretty good but if not you could easily skip it and not miss out on much. There is a lot of content if you're okay with very repetitive open world segments with little variation but if you don't you will get bored of it fast.

Days Gone (5 out of 5 stars).

Days Gone is an entertaining and fun open world action horror adventure game that follows a bounty hunter Deacon a drifter. Deacon is a drifter that is struggling for survival in a post apocalyptic world that's infested with infected with zombie like people, bad guys who are trying to survive, and a cult that are disturbed and insane. Days Gone is a fun game. I had trouble getting into it when I first started.

The graphics were a bit iffy at first. The opening cutscene cut right into the chase without you being emotionally invested into the characters. The opening scene of Deacon, and his wife Sarah, and Boozer who are trying to escape a war torn city. As the infected population is increasing. Two years later, Deacon is on the search for Sarah. While him and Boozer are drifters from one camp to another. Just doing their camp chore work. Such as looking for a guy who went awol. Or helping them defend their camps from other bad guys or cults. I think the first half of the game is hard to get into. Cause the missions were repetitive and similar. After Deacon comes across Iron Mike's camp. The plot finally starts making progress with its storyline. With Iron Mike's camp facing against the threat of Skinners cult group. And Deacon conflicted with where his loyalties lies.

The game is fun after getting past the first half of the game. Driving your bike in the open world is fun and scary at times. You may come across bad guys who will plan traps to get you off your bike. Or the scary threat of running into a horde of undead. Which is like a scene from World War Z movie. As an army of dead are chasing after you. You better hope you wont fall off your bike or drive into a dead end.

The missions become fun after a while. Your character goes on a rescue mission to rescue one of their own. Or planning a defense mission on trying to save your camp. I enjoyed the main missions more. The bounty hunter missions was becoming repetitive. Finding the guy you need to go after and it always ends in a motorcycle bike chase. Which is boring.

It is a long game if your trying to do the main missions. Like I said the first half is slow moving. It eventually picks up. And you can not put the controller down after that. The plot is good. Deacon is on the search for his wife. While the side missions of Deacon getting information from a guy in a research facility. Informing him about the undead. Which gets really good in the end. Plus there is a secret ending foreshadowing what is to become if a sequel happens.

The graphics get better throughout the game. The details of the open world. The game play is fun. It does get annoying when certain guns are weaker than others. Like you need to buy an upgraded weapon for certain enemies. Which means you have to do the optional missions to build your camp trust.

The story is good. Slow at first but ends in a fun action packed way. I would love to see a sequel from this game. And see where the story goes next.

Overall, Days Gone is a good action packed fun game. It has some intense and scary moments of being chased or the thrills of fighting other bad guys in this open world. The first several missions are repetitive and boring.

I have played countless zombie-survival games, and found them to be not up my ally. But this game has to be an exception. This game is nothing like most, if not all the zombie-survival games out there. It's well designed, mechanics are flawless, story is engaging, open world is absolutely perfect, and the story/missions are NOT repetitive.




-I typically play zombie-survival games for max of 4-8hrs before giving up for good due to lack of interest. But NOT this game! 33hrs into the game and I still haven't thought of giving up. Not even for a second. In fact, if I had more time, I'd be playing more.


-The open world is just stunning, and I found it to be more alive than GTA5, Assassin Creed's open worlds. This quality of the open world encouraged me to keep exploring, and not use fast travel.


-I have NEVER found myself so invested into a story of a game like this one. Matter of fact, I haven't had to skip the in-between story for once.


Bottom line: THIS IS THE BEST $49.99 I'VE EVER SPEND ON VIDEO GAME. WITHOUT A DOUBT I'D HAVE NO ISSUE PAYING $80 FOR THIS GAME EITHER. I HOPE TO SEE Days Gone 2 SOON!!!

Days Gone is an Action/Open World with zombies as the main theme but the centre of the story is the main character: Deacon trying to find his wife that he saved at the start of Zombie outbreak. Entire story or at least majority of it is focused on a journey of Deacon, trying to discover what happened to his wife.

Game looks like pretty generic console/sony style game: Great visuals, in my opinion outstanding dubbing and open world with many side activities to do. That would be a greatest bait in gaming history.
Under some boring chores, exhausting early game, Days Gone hides an absolute gem of a game. 

Let me tell you, despite not being a huge sport/car games fan, I absolutely love gameplay loop that follows motorcycle. During early game you really have to watch out for fuel as this is your main form of transportation. Upgrades are meaningul and customization is quite huge for something that is addition to the main gameplay.
Zombie Hordes are terrific, they can easily clap you even on easy difficulty and there is no Skyrim bullshit that lets you solo whole camp without using brain cause you are high level.
Characters are quite memorable, Deacon will often comment situation, he can be scared, sad and in despair, no Hero Journey bullshit, he often seems realistic. I expect someone facing a horde of zombies to curse under the nose. 

Soundtrack is perfect and ride to the new location will leave you speechless. Chase music still plays in my head rent-free. 

Overall it is literally a Geneva Convention Violation that we did not get second part because of reviewers with brain cells equal to Game Journalists. Solid recommed, especially if you can get it with discount.

This game has moments of greatness. Its best when the characters, especially your main character isn't talking. Its best when the game is quiet and you're looting, sneaking, planning your escape or assault, and carrying it through. 

The not so great parts of this game, for me, might not turn everyone off but it does for me. I dislike the characters so far, the voice acting is pretty rough on Deek and unfortunately he narrates everything you're doing: if you get a headshot your character literally says "mm good, headshot." That may not sound too bad but there isn't a moment in this game where Deek isn't talking/thinking for the player.

Another aspect of this game I don't like is the cringe dialogue. The characters seem to be conservative libertarian types which I tend to butt heads with. And since I can't relate much at all with them I have a hard time getting invested in the story, especially when the voice acting is so inconsistent with its quality. 

The game itself runs well, with no FSR or DLSS I might add. The world is very nice looking with lots of foliage and detail, however the interactivity is lacking. You can vault over walls and obstacles but occasionally you'll come across a wall thats just as tall or shorter than walls you've vaulted over before but for whatever reason you can't over this or that one. Your character also sometimes wants to bug out when trying to open a car's hood while standing too close to a wall. Overall, the way your character controls is pretty okay but its not perfect. 

The driving is nice and neat, I like that quite a bit but because this is a zombie world, gas is limited so just be aware of that and get off the bike when you can afford to. This game wants you to conserve your resources. 

I've tried this game over and over, twice on steam, twice on console. I've wanted to like this game but unfortunately the clunk and the cringe keeps me from its potential. Hopefully you'll have a better time than me. This is definitely The Last of Us for conservatives, but one thing this game has over The Last of Us is that this game runs on PC and the other one was a horrible mess by a bad porting studio.

SPOILER: You don't get to kill the main bad guy. He's protected by cutscene armor the entire game. When you finally face him it's a silly mini game that is easily won. Roll towards him. Then you kill him in the end game cutscene that follows. He's not even a great villian. He so obviously betrays you at some point in the game and despite being a supernatural tracker/bounty hunter you never go after him. It's not even an option. Which brings up how cheesy and predictable the story is. Nothing you haven't seen before. On top of that you are constantly interrupted by getting attacked by random shit even when you're already in combat. Ex: Wolves spawning, running up and biting you in the middle of gun fight. The game constantly gets in the way of it's own immersion and gives you much less agency than you think you'll get in an open world game. It never really felt challenging as much as annoying. Also too few buttons do too many things. How many times have you tried to jump and rolled instead or vice versa? This can be super frustrating when that gets you seen (while in stealth), hit, or even killed. 

Edit: With some after thought, I added a bit to the rant above and wanted to add some Pros because there are some fun concepts in the game. Which is why I bothered playing it till the end and why I was so disappointed overall. The side missions you do outside of the main story, though repetitive at times, are the best part of the game. Burning nest, stealth killing a camp of ruffians, tracking clues, fighting the hordes, etc. The action can feel rewarding when the game doesn't get in it's own way. The upgrade system is simple but works well.  Riding the bike around the wasteland can be pretty fun as well. All of that adds up to you becoming one of the most badass characters you'll play in a game. If only the main story reflected that and the game play wasn't ultimately frustrating.

Days Gone is more than a game; it's an emotional experience that leaves an indelible mark on the soul. In a medium often criticized for its detachment, Days Gone stands as a testament to the potential of video games as a powerful storytelling platform. 

It's a journey through the depths of sorrow, the heights of redemption, and the flickering flame of hope that refuses to be extinguished. This is not just a game to be played; it's a story to be felt, an emotional odyssey that resonates with the very essence of what it means to be human.

As the credits rolled on my journey through Days Gone, I found myself yearning for more. The game's rich narrative, well-developed characters, and the immersive world they inhabit make a compelling case for a sequel that could further elevate this post-apocalyptic saga.

Whether or not we will get a sequel for Days Gone, I probably need therapy after witnessing what Deacon went through.

After 35 hours of play I can tell you that this game is a mixed bag.  Can't recommend it because it is SO broken.  Dialogue is pretty bad sometimes, story is lack luster, characters are a bit flat, custom bike skins but cannot change clothes ever even in torrential rains or inches of snow.  Lots of awkward transitions as you show up to your objective but they want it at a different time of day so the camera pans to the sky and you watch as the sun flys by and then your character does the thing, over and over and over again.  Kinda broken gameplay there fellas.  The worse bug I've found is trying to rescue three hostages kneeling on a rope bridge, killed all the bandits but there was a horde hibernating in a cave below which gave off an enemy warning on minimap, so I couldn't ever rescue the guys they just wouldn't stand up for me.  saved and loaded and the horde was still there but the guys vanished, aka the reward for doing the mission.  This has happened twice before but only with a single hostage that refused to be rescued even though no enemy can be found remaining anywhere.  Really ruins the experience.  Could have been a good spin on the Red Dead Redemption type gameplay, but feels like they released it about 30% complete.  It's passable and the combat is acceptable once you turn off the aimbot helper.  Combat felt challenging on hard mode when the game begins but after you hit level 15 or so your character feels pretty overpowered.  Would like to see a survivor mode version of this game that requires food and drink.  The story here is very linear even though there are three big camps so far that each have missions for you.  Still just forced from one zone to another along their storyline, instead of it feeling like the player is in control of where the story goes.  Replay-ablity is what you want, and a player driven storyline would essentially be very different each time you played through.  
And whats the deal with collecting ears... seriously don't they know there are TWO ears on each of these heads...

4 out of 5 Stars for me (with mods, without is a mere 3)
What this game is about is a solid story and fun with killing zombies.
What this game is not about is survival and crafting.

I think half of the game's success is related to the character (an outlaw) and the other to the mass killing of hordes (once you complete the game). 
It is a fun game. Nothing more. But I very much like the fun of it.
It is strongly entertaining but it is ultimately boring.
The difficulty only comes from the scarcity (of resources), absurd spawns and difficulty (you can be one-shot-to-the-chest  killed on Hard II but an human enemy can withstand 5-6 bullets from AK-47).
The AI is stupid and only dangerous on highest difficulty because of the abysmally overpowered enemies.
The crafting is a joke (very few craft items). 
There is no survival (no food or drink, no diseases).
The vanilla bike tank is a joke. You can drive your bike for a mere 2 miles! (with a mod 6-8 miles) 
The combat (melee especially) is one of the worst I have experienced in a decade. 

But as I have already mentioned, if you accept the above limitations and flaws (which I did before buying) and are all about killing zombies using a cool outlaw character then go for it.

Just remember to use mods (like Weapon Enhancement Project, 2x Engine Speed, Improved fuel tank mod, Throwables x3 etc.), they do make a hell of a difference.

Would I recommend it despite its flaws? Absolutely yes!

There are two main types of story driven action/adventure games like this:

1: You are in control of your character the entire time. The story unfolds around you as you play but you never loose control of your character. You are your character. Games like Doom, Half Life, Prodeus etc

2: You're playing an adventure soap opera where you control your character in between cut scenes. Some games only have a few to add to the story while some games seem to be more about the cut scenes with some BS for you to do in between.

I would softly recommend this to anyone who enjoyed the Left 4 Dead series and/or Red Dead Redemption II. Days Gone feels like someone watched Sons of Anarchy and The Walking Dead at the same time and figured they should replace Daryl Dixon with Jax Teller. The game makes the most of revisiting certain locations at different plot points, but also misses some opportunities by putting a lot of effort into designing a location that ends up simply being a place to fight a horde (I'm looking at you Sawmill). Most of the story is pretty enjoyable, especially during the early and mid game. The highlights for me are the Boozer storyline and everything involving the Rippers. You should be able to guess the "great reveal" of the infection's source well before the characters arrive at it. The ending is relatively satisfying but it won't blow your mind or resolve every storyline. I also thought it was kinda dumb that nobody figured out why Deacon was in the Army camp considering it's tattooed on his goddamn neck.

I really enjoyed running down bounties, clearing out enemy camps, fighting zombie bears, and killing my first horde after spending most of the game simply running from them. The NERO camps and stealth missions escalate well in terms of difficulty. The only thing I consistently hated was showing up to a certain spot to complete or start a mission, but accidentally triggering a cutscene for a completely different mission that I'd end up being locked into. Maybe also the increasing distance of shops from the entrance of a given camp as the game went on.

There are some minor annoyances regarding the scaling of the crafting system and discovery of recipes in regards to the pacing of the game. For instance, by the time I find the recipe for poison arrows, I hadn't been using the crossbow because I already had access to a .50 sniper rifle. As convenient as it is to be able to carve up some new arrows whenever you need them and not have to buy a new silencer every time you touch camp, there's no way I was going back to the bow in terms of range and damage. I also wish I'd been able to craft some of the best melee weapons in the game instead of simply feel lucky to find them, on top of being afraid of permanently breaking them.

The biggest single letdown for me was probably being plot-stripped of all my weapons because my character keeps saying how he wants to kill the big bad traitor with his bare hands (then they have a knife fight that ends up feeling like it's over too quickly). I understood having to sneak around and get my weapons back whenever I was captured, and probably enjoyed it most of the time. I didn't really understand making me earn all this camp trust and credits to buy the best weapons in the game only for the game to take away my agency as a player at a crucial moment. 

Misgivings aside, it's a game with largely enjoyable combat mechanics and character dynamics. As I write this, it's on sale for an extremely reasonable price of $12.49.

Two years ago a virus was unleashed that caused infected humans to devolve into powerful, unthinking, violent savages that brought civilisation to it's knees. Deacon St John was caught up in these events, and was separated from his wife Sarah after putting her on a rescue chopper as the doodoo was beginning to hit the fan. 

In the years since then Deacon came to believe that Sarah had been killed, and subsequently became rather cold-hearted and hardened in his grief. Getting by as a ruthless bounty-hunter, a chance encounter with the man who helped rescue his wife, whom Deacon had presumed died at the same time, makes him question whether Sarah is alive. 

He sets out to try and find her, but that's not the only part of his past, good or bad, that is resurfacing. It's not just hordes of brutal mutants he must face in pursuit of the truth, but also cannibals, murderous bandits who he may, or may not, have screwed over or killed some of them, and an insane cult that worship the mutants. 

There's plenty of things ready to throw a spanner in the works as Deacon searches for clues as to whether his wife survived.      

'Days Gone' isn't a particularly original game in either its mechanics or its storytelling, but it is fun to play and the narrative is engaging. Just as something unique can still be a load of old arse, this is derivative and yet it is so slickly done that its inspirations pale by comparison.

There's many influences you can pick from it, as it combines the open-world design of Far Cry with a fun way of getting about on your motorbike, added to the visceral action and set-pieces of The Last Of Us. The game offers incredibly snappy 3rd person melee and ranged combat, but also has very decent options for a stealthy approach. 

It's also somewhat of a horror title and manages to be pretty intense even when you have unlocked new combat skills and weaponry. As your character will still get mauled pretty quickly by wild predators, some of which can run almost as fast as your bike goes, or when facing more than a handful of mutants and you know that gunshots might attract even bigger numbers or other predators.

The combination of these factors really makes a lot of difference when you play it on a harder difficulty level, as the experience ramps up through the aggressive nature of the inhuman foes, and the fairly smart behaviours of human enemies. When the game gets into triple digits for the number of enemies onscreen, it can get quite mental, and that is one of its biggest draws.

You will do quests for people and these earn you xp to unlock skills and cash to buy supplies, or maybe unlock certain things such as weapons, or resources. It also allows for crafting your own items, so exploration for the required materials is a necessity, as some things can't be purchased.

Maybe the deserted house you are checking is empty, or maybe its a nest of monsters and you'll get a massive shock as a screaming mob of bloodthirsty mutants pours out. It always takes careful consideration of the environment, as you want to loot these buildings because the challenge throughout is tough, but at the same time sh*t can easily go sideways.

Perhaps you were lining up a headshot just as a creature was about to notice you, and you miss and it screams. And its screams draw the attention of whatever else is in the area, leaving you quickly outnumbered and with no choice but to run and hide.

Your character gets around on a motorbike and the handling is superb, which makes it a pleasure riding around the expansive map. The sensation of speed is good, and it easily could be it's own arcade-y drift-y slide-y racing game, as it controls so well. When you've got a horde of 100 mutants chasing after you, and you're weaving between trees and making mad dashes down the rocky terrain, it is exhilirating.

When you add in the fact that you can run over enemies, and also do shooting whilst riding, it becomes another element that adds to the flavour. Because the game has random encounters you never know what will be around the next corner, so manually driving about (rather than fast-travelling, though it does have it too) never becomes a chore. 

You might be fleeing from a bloodthirsty mob and hear the howl of wolves nearby, then suddenly one of them is running alongside your bike before leaping up to knock you off. Now you're stuck between the wolf and your pursuers, but that's okay because they are just as likely to start fighting instead, and hey! Here's a bunch of roaming human marauders who've now stumbled into it, and they're all attacking each other.
 
As many times as this can be helpful, there's just as many times where someone will shoot at you and the sound will draw the attention of something that's most likely going to savage them and you as well. A bear will make quick work of taking down foes, but it will also soak up precious ammo if you try to take it on. Better to try and get it to do your dirty-work for you, then jump on your bike and peg it away to safety.  

Although it is nothing original or unique as an action game, or for its exploration and resource management, it all comes together for a very enjoyable, dynamic and challenging experience. When this was released on playstation 4 I remember some reviews being dismissive because of the formulaic template that apes Bethesda and Ubisoft design. 

But when you add in humongous crowds of enemies, the slick manner in which you drive around, and the intense combat, you get a title that is much more thrilling than first impressions might suggest. Albeit these elements scale up over time as your character progresses, so I too was somewhat uninterested for a long while until I finally bought it and played it.

Having done so, 60 hours later I'd had a darn good time by the end.

Even the plot is pretty well done, with a no-nonsense approach to the writing and cut-scenes that deliver the meaty drama without dragging on for too long or becoming cringe-y. It's not quite up there with the story-telling of The Last Of Us, but is better than average as it twists and turns through this grim devastated world. Its all backed up by solid performances from the cast.  

If it has a downside, it's the scale of the game. Personally I thoroughly enjoyed it, and the difficulty level I played it on fed into that cycle of exploring for supplies to craft weapons and ammo, and doing quests to get xp, so that I had the necessary skills and weapons when the next intense story set-piece occurred.

It didn't feel samey to me, as there's a variety of mission designs and the randomness of the world means 90% of the time it can descend into utter pant-sh*tt*ng chaos. But I do love games that mix up stealth (especially when it actually, you know, works properly, as this game does), action and scavenging for resources, so 60 hours in this world (on the hard difficulty) was fine with me. I hungrily ate it up. 

Obviously if you don't want 20+ hours (or more) of your time slinging a motorbike about and running over mutants / deer / wolves, or creeping about stabbing mutants in the back, or getting into gunfights with armed bandits, then your appreciation will differ.

For me, I thought it was great and absolutely worth the purchase. It looks decent, is quite impressive when you get to the point that huge numbers of enemies can be onscreen, and the controls / action / stealth are super slick. It certainly isn't original, but is the best version of all those things it is nicking, so I don't much care how familiar the premise or design is.

The end result has that X factor which made me want to keep playing it, and the story was sufficiently engaging to see it all through to the end. Happily it doesn't end on a cliffhanger for a sequel, so whilst it may not get any further entries due to a middling reception (that's not earned IMO), that's not something undermining this.

DG is not a game that will knock you off your feet, but it is a solid and polished title. I have to say that I liked the main story and the side quests, so I would say they are the game’s strong points. I will admit though that the main plot sometimes uses shortcuts and other times it is slightly naive - but not enough to be painful. As a whole it was coherent and interesting enough to keep my attention. 
One thing that I especially liked about DG is how it respected my time inside the game. For example, you instantly get quick travel. Crafting and character development are both clear and to the point. Combat is not overly difficult but satisfying. And it took me a little over 50 hrs to beat the game. All that creates this smooth player experience, which I so much like nowadays, that I do not get to spend as much time playing like I used to.
I also want to mention the protagonist, who is sort of an anti-hero. Not a guy you like instantly - probably the type that you either like unconditionally or simply cannot stand. Either way, Deacon is a well written character with an unobvious background and some demons manifesting from time to time. On one hand, he is a strong character, on the other, just by listening to how he talks, you can tell there is more to him than meets the eye. He is a character that complements the world depicted in the game and, in a way, is a mirror that reflects the state the world is in. Voice actor did a tremendous job.
As for the downsides, I would mention silly AI, or the fact that you only get to unlock the coolest weapons so late in the game that they are no longer viable. I understand you can go for NG+ and keep them, but I am not big on replaying, so it was a wasted potential. Luckily the basic weapons are good enough for comfortable play anyway. There are also some small things like when you quick travel you always arrive dismounted for who knows what reason.

I'm a hardcore gamer and have been for 20* years, and I haven't had as much fun in a long time as with this game.  I ride a motorcycle, so the story with a biker theme and riding is a blast.  My PC is a gaming rig, so I can appreciate the amazing graphics and detail the game offers in the beautiful outdoor settings.  

The game does an excellent job of making sure it isn't too easy, but yet isn't frustratingly hard either if you play it realistically (e.g. conserve ammo, and taking care not to play like you're in God Mode).  You can save your progress whenever you like near your motorcycle, so there's no reason to die in a rage because you lost item pickups, or story progress.  

The open world is so amazingly real and detailed, you could be entertained just exploring, but the zombies keep the danger and possible action always there if you get bored.  

My only small complaint, is that the game was ported, and it really should be played with a game controller, because on a keyboard, I'm constantly having to scroll the mouse to see what my character is seeing in quick direction changes.  I don't like the 'over the shoulder' view, and wish you could switch to true first person, but all the other great things about the game made it worth these faults.  

I'm now a HUGE fan of this game and hope they make a PC version of a sequel, as if they do I'll buy it for sure.,
