Okay so what do I think in order to help you decide if you should get this.

I liked it. I did, I got this for a tenner which I think is a complete bargain for what i got. There of course were some issues, but I will start with good.

It's very pretty. And we all like a pretty game. It obviously shines in the forest and snow areas, but it was very nice just riding round on your motorbike through all the various weather, it reminded me of when I use to do it as a kid in GTA San Andreas (only with zombies). 
Exploring in the game was great too. Even wondering round to find all the plants, hordes, nero intel etc felt good. It can be a really stressful or really relaxing game depending on what you're doing.
I really like your BFF in the game, Boozer, type of guy to put a smile on your face. A cutie really.
The bike customisation was good, various paint jobs and decals, wheels, lights etc. Riding it felt comfortable, the fuel consumption was decent as in it didn't drive you crazy having to constantly keep an eye on it, it felt fair. 
Liked all the guns and messing round with em, and you get some nice big ones near the end and even get some guns used by characters, so if there is a character using a gun and you think "I want that gun" know that you will end up with it one way or another.
I enjoyed most of the story. Particularly in the first half. Will admit in the latter parts of the game I enjoyed less, the later game seemed kinda rushed compared to great first 25 or so hours. 
Fighting the zombies (well Freaks) is great. Loved the hordes, fun as heck to deal with, nothing quite like accidentally running into a horde and your bike is 200m away and you're low on ammo! Ha it got me a few times.
Lots and LOTS of missions with clearly percentages so you know when a storyline is finished. You ALWAYS have something you can do in this game.
Camp mechanics of earning good rep to get better gear works good too, and with all the zombies n missions you will be doing, it is easy to get them up to max and enjoy all those good upgrades.
It's Starkiller.
The radio broadcast from Copeland always made me laugh and Deacons response to them is great, in fact Deeks response to a lot of things made me laugh. That man is TIRED.
Puppies.
Interesting collectables.

OKay the bad
It did crash a few times in the latter. This is what I mean by I feel like the second half or last third (can't really tell how far along it was story wise. But lets say 30 hours in) felt rushed and not as polished.
The radio communication between you and whoever is broken. The amount of times it would repeat itself, or it would just cut off completely, or 2 people were talking at once, was a lot. If I was getting shot that would make sense to start a line of conversation again, but not I'd just be going about my merry way and it would happen. Conversations that were clearly meant to be have BEFORE you completed a mission also happened. Id be talking about doing something I have JUST done. The radio conversations are honestly a mess.
The story is predictable. It isn't game ending, but it was like "oh yeah..kind of expected that" and had the vibes of "Maybe humans are the real monsters afterall" in some parts, which is cringe.
Really random moments in conversation would make me go "someone is just pushing their own private thoughts here". I can not imagine a man like Deacon saying all the "bad" people in the game are ex convicts. But he did. He said that the 7 million criminals in the US, whether in jail or not, are why there are people shooting at innocents in the game. Deek, i don't think a dude with a random cocaine possession is torturing people okay. So there are random moments like that which really took me out of it.
So I guess I could say not consistent writing with that. it for sure felt like there were a few voices being projected. 
Deek often just did not reload. I'd be there tapping it or the mag is out and he is just running round not reloading. It was weird.
The gun wheel would be a pain to navigate. I would pick whatever gun and something else was in the my hand. Really awkward when a Horde of 150 is running down on ya.
The gps would take me routes that I could not drive, across bridges or roads that were blown apart for example. You can just find your own way but still.
Many missions glitched where I couldn't talk to people or untie them etc and I would have to reload the save a few times to get it too work.

I do like the game. I can see why so many want a sequel, I'd be happy with one too. Though I can also see why it doesn't have one (the head guy of making the game I think has ruined it chances by acting quite rudely about people who have played). It'd be great if it does especially with the ending (make sure to 100% all the missions to get it :) )

For the £10 I got it for, very happy. Pick it up on sale I say. If you like zombies, and lots of em! Plus Starkiller, and bikes, then get it. The issues I did bring up CLEARLY weren't enough to get me to stop playing.

It has its quirks, but a cool game.  The first few chapters are a lot of picking up supplies and crafting bandages and molotovs. Story line is another "society went to shit because of...", in this case you fight mutant "rippers", cultist skinners, mercenaries, have factions with different camps. 
Game has many aspects, driving, shooting, gathering, crafting.

I had never heard of this game, but it's become one of my absolute favorites.

If you like any of these things, you will probably like (or love) this game:
[list]
[*] The Walking Dead, especially the Daryl Dixon character
[*] Sons of Anarchy
[*] Far Cry series
[*] Zombies / vampires / cannibals
[*] Beautiful, apocalyptic game worlds
[*] Violently and hilariously dirt-napping countless disgusting, rancid creatures 
[/list]

It's hard to bring anything new to the table regarding zombie-type creatures, but Bend Studio very successfully does so with the hordes in this game. It is absolutely terrifying to encounter one of these large groups of wandering Freakers in the wilderness. I'm a jaded gamer, and I've nearly **** myself several times after stumbling into a mob. 

The worst was triggering a loudspeaker when powering up a NERO center that was right next to a hidden horde. Seeing that FLOOD of nightmare fuel streaming into the camp and having to run for my life while shooting, rolling and climbing like mad to avoid a mob of screeching horrors just jumped to the top of my greatest gaming experiences. If my bike had been only a little further away... 

And speaking of the bike, your motorcycle is also great fun to ride and customize and really becomes a full character since it WILL save your life more than once. The story was decent and engaging enough to keep me wanting to find out more.

All in all, a fantastic title that should have gotten more exposure and a sequel.

Egregious amounts of forced walking sections puncuated by boring cut scenes filled with sentimental emo dialogue or endless conversations over walkie talkies.

Main story that's twice as long as it should be since it's been padded out with quests such as finding a drunken friend by crouching over beer bottles and holding E, walking behind your wife while she talks about the medicinal uses of lavender then being tasked with finding 3 bits of lavender which are all in a row around 5 metres away from you, finding a dog for someone and finding a rock for a girl that's sad.

You have to hold the action button to pick up/do anything so if you're being chased by freakers and you get to your bike you can't just jump on it and drive away, you have to stand still beside it for a second or 2 holding E before you can get on it. Same with picking up items, you stand beside them then hold E then they disappear and reappear in your inventory.  Tapping the key once isn't immersive or realistic enough, apparently.

You earn skill points throughout the game but the skills you can unlock are minor and something like extra storage space for traps and explosives takes around 7 skill points to unlock which must all be used in the same skill tree so you can't use any of them on ranged or melee attacks, just survival skills, despite seeing numerous things you could use for storage lying around the world.

Enemy types amount to zombies, child zombies, witches from L4D2 (seen 3 in total), hulk zombies (seen 2 in total), wolves, wolves with mange, bears (seen 4 in total), cultists and run of the mill survivors wearing jeans and green or black jackets. So 9 enemy types in an open world game you're meant to play for at least 30 hours. It's about a zombie virus and they could have done anything with it but that's all you get.

So glad I didn't buy it at full price. So glad there will never be a sequel.

Mind-numbingly dull, generic post apocalypse tripe. I bought it because of the glowing reviews, thinking maybe it offers a unique experience in an extremely oversaturated genre. Oh boy, what a mistake. Characters are dull, wooden caricatures of “hardened” survivors, completely devoid of interesting traits or characteristics. The story is awful. There are far too many cutscenes that overstay their welcome and only make the boredom worse, ripping you out of the gameplay. Motorcycles that ride like trash. Higher difficulties make enemies sponges, and remove the hud and fast travel, both of which are already questionable design choices in a game like this. Gunplay is awful and firearms feel weak as hell and don’t even behave realistically. Generic crafting system. Constant QTE’s.

It’s like this game was completely designed around a derivative checklist of generic zombie open world cliches and they checked literally every box. Go play The Last of Us instead. It’s a much better use of your time.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Vastly underrated game! Let me start by saying I do not like playing shooter type games where I have to aim guns. I am more of a medieval sword swinging arrow shooting type gamer. Also, I do not do zombie type games at all; I have tried to avoid them up until this point; however, I was running low on options and I needed something new to play. I ride motorcycles, so I thought I would give this a try; WOW was I in for a great ride! This was, to me, a cross between Red Dead Redemption and A Plague Tale, and I am sure there is a third game you could toss in there as well. I could not believe the fun I had with this game and that this game has been so overlooked by the gaming community. I do understand that when this first released, it was very buggy, and that appears to have been the biggest reason for its lack of fan fair; however, all that seems to have been resolved, and the game plays incredibly smooth now. There can still be a rare bug that pops up at times, as there are with every game I have played, but there is nothing that can't be resolved by a quick fast travel or a simple close and restart; there is nothing that is going to break the game or a story line in it. The story is great, the graphics are great, the game play is great. The characters and there stories are deep. I only hope that SONY will realize they misjudged this games potential and likability enough the reconsider a part two. There are so many directions they can take this.

Days Gone is one of the best video games I've ever played and I've been playing since Atari when I was a wee little lad. This game is utterly fantastic. Start to finish.

I have two very minor complaints. The stealth missions, particularly getting into the third camp, can be a bit aggravating. The other is that sometimes missions will crop up and you can't change your loadout, which can be problematic if you're specialized for something like clearing human camps and suddenly have to deal with a horde.

But everything else? Amazing. The controls are super smooth, loadout customization is awesome, the storyline is great from start to finish. For one of the first times in an open world game I'm voluntarily just cruising around instead of using fast travel. The Horde mechanics are great, and firefights or dealing with smaller swarms is a dynamic experience.

For instance, in one of the first camps I came in and cleared out the human enemies. While looking for the bunker, wolves and Freakers started coming in to eat the corpses before spotting each other, turning the post-fight search into a chaotic, glorious mess.

The dynamics of the encounters are great and add a level of strategy on top of simply handling the encounter you rode into. You have to be a bit wary at all times to stay alive, since danger is essentially omnipresent.

I can't believe I slept on this one for so long. I'm ~45 hours in and still haven't completed the storyline and I'm looking forward to 100%ing the game, possibly in Hard mode on New Game+ when I'm done.

This game has much the same content as most zombie games but puts them together very nicely. Good storyline and graphics, a few weapons, craftables and modifications with a weapon degradation system that can be tweaked to your taste with user-generated mods. There's the standard fare of individual zombie types but with the addition of zombie 'nests' and hordes. Not many jump-scare moments, but quite a lot of frantic run, dodge and shoot/smash/burn activity. Travel (and some zombie squishing) is done with a customisable motorbike that handles differently across different terrain types, screeching round corners on the roads, power-sliding on mud and dust or trying to stay upright on snow. Various factions and encampments add to the storyline and gameplay. Recommended, especially if it's on sale.

Absolutely brilliant, with relatively little of the anti-White, anti-normalcy, pro-perversion woke garbage of so many modern games, thank God.  The gratuitous interracial lesbian relationship is irritating, but not as bad as it could be, because neither participant is White.  Best of all, the strongly implied interracial relationship of your woman with a Black in the military camp, which the story hints at very strongly, actually never occurred.  When they implied that the first time, I shut off the game in disgust, and abandoned it, but thankfully I learned after a few months that the writers didn't actually decide to attack, insult, and repulse White players by including that repulsive all-too-common piece of modern social subversion, so I could return and enjoy the rest of the story.

As for game play, the Horde dynamic is amazing, and sets Days Gone apart from everything else by a wide margin.  Voice acting is terrific, and NPC motivations make sense.  Combat and travel are tense and satisfying.  I haven't paid full price for a game in decades, but if they listen to fans and ever make a Days Gone 2, I would buy it at full price, in gratitude.

I was surprised.  I expected zombies with a little more story, but instead got way more content, depth, and challenge than I thought I would get in this game.  Making the motorcycle the only transportation in post zombie apocalypse is brilliant.  You can move quickly through the world, but never overpowered enough that you can turn your brain off and run everything over.  Challenges of hordes become relative to the equipment you have available, turning the predator/prey play style a little different each time.  The story is not Oscar worthy stuff, but it kept invested enough to play through to the end, and there are multiple story lines to full this open world game pretty well.  

Honestly, I felt like a got a full game and an DLC expansion all in one package.  That aspect makes things a little repetitive towards the end, but those used to the live service experience will get a refreshing surprise here.  

It is not perfect, I encountered some glitches periodically throughout, crashed once or twice.  I feel dealing with encounters had more options I never used, making things more repetitive when I mowed things down with a LMG. Zombies are more powerful than guns, making human encounters oddly easier than melee encounters.  I like to do side quests, but even then I would run out of things to do until a radio call would come in allowing me to progress.  Some random encounters are nice, but most are not needed, and some will break your bike and frustrated me a couple times.  These issues were spaced apart and not representative to my normal experience

Purchased on sale for $17.  Got way more value than that, and I hope the director warms up to the community after the middling launch years ago.

TL;DR - 4/10, Days Gone has a lot of potential but unfortunately fails to utilise most of it. It has its high moments, but for every time I enjoyed myself there would be three times where I would find myself frustrated with poor design choices and an abhorrent amount of bugs.

Days Gone is an open world game set in a zombie infested post-apocalypse with survival elements. You ride your motorcycle through a derelict Oregon, doing jobs for various survivor camps while looking for answers regarding your wife’s death.

The game has a decent start, as you will find yourself often underequipped, scavenging for resources to ensure your survival. Enemies, both humans and zombies, pose a significant threat and one wrong move can and will get you killed. That would be about the first 10% of the game. Once you find a rifle accurate enough for you to consistently headshot with and a survivor camp with a reliable supply of ammo there is basically no challenge for the next 70% of the game. 

I played this game on the hardest possible difficulty and I was disappointed with how little opposition was thrown my way. The human enemies, which make for the majority of combat encounters in missions are, simply put, extremely stupid. If you go for a stealth approach you can breathe down their neck without them noticing you, but even if you go in loud, due to the third person perspective, you can just gun them down while being constantly behind cover. Most missions will only put maybe a dozen grunts against you and spread them out in a way where you rarely will fight more than three at once. Towards the end of the game it boosts the numbers a bit and introduces armoured opponents, but, as stated earlier, for most of it you will be shooting helpless lobotomites in their empty heads as they show close to no resistance.

In general, the game holds your hand a lot. As if gunfights weren’t easy enough, you get bullet time so you can perfectly line up headshots. Time freezes when you open your inventory and use items, so even when you do get hit you can heal yourself a dozen times before facing the risk of dying. Melee combat automatically locks onto targets so all you do is spam [Mouse 1] to beat stunlocked opponents to death. Using your sidearm while driving also automatically aims for you so, again, all you do is mindlessly click. There are two things, however, that the highest difficulty setting does well. It removes your hud, which increases the immersion and forces you to estimate or check your stats manually. It also disables fast travel, which leads to more interactions with the open world.

The zombies (called “freakers”) are a lot better than the human enemies, and are the highlight of the game. Their AI is a lot more intricate, there are multiple types of them and they can overwhelm you if you aren’t careful. They are at their full potential in the open world, but in missions, even if you already killed hundreds of them, the game will often underestimate you and throw maybe 10 or so your way and pretend it’s a genuine threat. Considering this was on the highest difficulty, I’m not sure if they even spawn at all on the lower ones.

Other gameplay elements are, for the most part, decent. The gunplay is nice and you get a rather large arsenal to play with. The driving is overall fun, however when you upgrade your speed the slightest collisions will wreck your bike and catapult you across the map, which does get annoying.

The main selling point of the game, that being the hordes, is definitely the best part. The sheer amount of freakers in one group, they way the flow like liquid when they chase you and the sound design around them is all fantastic and it’s something I haven’t seen in another game. Initially just hearing them roaming in the distance sends a chill down your spine and once you arm yourself well enough to take them on, oh man. Days Gone is at its peak when you watch 300 zombies run through a minefield you set up as you mow them down with an LMG. Unfortunately, the game refuses to play its best card and severely underutilizes hordes. By the time they are introduced in the story, nearing its end, I had already hunted down a few in the open world because, frankly, it was more fun than playing the story missions. If they cut out half the braindead goons I had to fight and replaced them with different types of hordes my enjoyment of the game would have been a lot greater.

When it comes to the open world, visually it’s great. However there’s very little substance under that pretty wrap. There’s almost a complete absence of environmental storytelling. All the underfurnished interiors look the same and contain nothing of interest except the same few crafting materials. Not once did I go into a building and think “This is an interesting find, I’m glad I took my time to explore this place.”

The story is a mixed bag. The characters themselves are mostly fine, some are really good but the narrative itself is uncreative and incredibly predictable. The twists failed to surprise me and some were so obvious that otherwise decently written characters seemingly morphed into idiots for a moment for the twists to even occur. There is also one group of characters that is significantly more poorly written than the rest. Avoiding spoilers, basically the first antagonists of the game are a cult whose entire concept and ideology is so ridiculously dumb and unbelievable that I don’t know how the writers thought it was a good idea. It’s like a really edgy 15 year old’s imagining of what a post apocalyptic cult would look like, and I feel like that’s an understatement. 

The worst part of the story by far, however, is the game’s undying dedication to wasting your time. Instead of giving you a cutscene the game will force you to stumble at a snail's pace for minutes to listen to mediocre dialogue, and unlike a cutscene, you can’t skip it. I am not kidding when I say that at some points the game will slow you down to such a crawl that the NPC you are walking with, whose walking speed the devs themselves have decided, will have to wait for you to catch up. It feels like they are taunting you and it’s incredibly frustrating. On top of that there are like a dozen stealth missions where you have to slowly sneak around bushes and listen to long bouts of expositions, and many unnecessary trips that the game makes you take. Cumulatively there are at least a few hours of the game during which nothing at all happens.

Overall, despite my complaints I saw a lot of potential in Days Gone. As you can tell by my playtime I went for full completion because I wanted to see all it had to offer, hoping it would give me something that would convince me to give it a positive review. In fact, it almost accomplished that as the game improved upon a bunch of its shortcomings near the end. There is one flaw though, the most significant one, which prevents me from giving Days Gone a positive score.

This is one of the buggiest games I’ve ever played. I could not go one mission without experiencing some kind of bug. If I was lucky it would just be a visual error, but often I would have to reload saves, reboot the game or verify game files to progress. I had no performance issues and I could find reports of the bugs I experienced elsewhere online so I know it wasn’t a problem on my end. And it wasn’t just a few of the same bugs on repeat, the game genuinely impressed me with the amount of ways it managed to break itself. Texture errors, models not rendering, NPCs not loading or spawning in walls, clipping through the floor, the camera bugging out, dialogue cutting off, crashes when approaching certain locations or starting missions, it goes on and on.

Just maybe I could forgive the lack of attention to detail, uninspired writing and underwhelming difficulty in favour of the well implemented gameplay elements but I cannot recommend someone pays a triple A price for a game that is unable to function properly.

Made the mistake of playing past 2 hours, thus I can no longer get a refund. I thought the story sucked, but the horde mechanics were enough to keep me entertained, so I kept going. Starting hour 5, the game (which had previously run smoother than butter) started stuttering like hell. I am now ten hours in, and the game is nigh on unplayable. Deacon will take three steps forward, and the game will stutter for half a second. Three more steps forward, another stutter, rinse and repeat. Sometimes, closing the game and turning it back on is enough to make it work, but it will eventually start stuttering again, given enough time. This is a playstation game--it looks good for being a console game, sure, but it shouldn't have this kind of issues on a rig that's like 10 times more powerful than a ps4. Oh, and it's filled with literal spyware, allegedly because the port was outsourced to a Chinese company that makes its money by "stealing" data (the game will ask you for your consent on first startup, so it's legalized stealing, but there's no "don't consent" option, just one where you give up a little less data. There's a literal keylogger embedded in this game. It's frankly insane that steam is allowing this game to stay on their platform, this is a new low). The funny part is that Days Gone's story is pretty right-leaning and from an American perspective, so Bend studios literally selling customer data to China shows where their real allegiance lies: money, not in any political ideology. So, yeah, skip this one.

Bonus: the zombies in this game could have gotten away with being incredibly generic, since the "horde" mechanics are pretty unique and can't really be found in any other gaming franchise besides maybe Dead Rising. Even in Dead Rising, hordes are less an organized mass of zombies moving as one, and more of just a bunch of dead guys standing about. The mechanical flair of this game was already enough to make the zombies unique. Instead, the creative director thought that they needed to be more unique in some other way, so they gave them sound effects that are eerily reminiscent of TLOU's infected. For the visual flair of the "freakers," as the game likes to call them, they decided what could make them stand out from other zombies was a tendency to shit themselves. You read that right. Throughout the game, freaker "nests" can be found, structures you have the option of burning to reduce their presence in the area, structures that are made up of twigs and shit. Yeah. Sometimes, if being original means getting literal shit in the mix, it'd really be better to be boring.

Title: Days Gone: A Riveting Journey Through the Apocalypse

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ (5/5)

Days Gone, developed by Bend Studio, is an absolute triumph in the post-apocalyptic gaming genre. From the moment you step into the worn shoes of Deacon St. John, you are thrust into a visceral and emotionally charged world that demands your attention.

The game's strength lies in its meticulous attention to detail, creating a believable and expansive open-world environment. The Pacific Northwest setting is not just a backdrop; it's a character in itself. The dynamic weather, day-night cycle, and realistic ecosystem contribute to an immersive experience that is nothing short of breathtaking.

The narrative is a rollercoaster of emotions, expertly weaving personal struggles with the chaos of a world overrun by Freakers — the game's version of zombies. Deacon's journey is poignant and filled with unexpected twists, and the character development is top-notch. Sam Witwer's stellar performance as Deacon adds a layer of authenticity to the character that enhances the overall narrative.

The gameplay is where Days Gone truly shines. The motorcycle, your trusty steed in this apocalyptic landscape, is not just a means of transportation but a lifeline. The sense of vulnerability while exploring the vast wilderness is palpable, and the constant threat of Freaker hordes keeps you on the edge of your seat.

Combat is a delicate dance of strategy and survival. Whether you're facing off against human enemies or hordes of Freakers, the variety of weapons and the strategic use of the environment add a layer of complexity that keeps the gameplay engaging throughout.

The game's attention to detail extends to its robust crafting system. Every item you scavenge feels crucial, and the decisions you make about resource allocation can mean the difference between life and death.

Days Gone is not without its flaws. Some technical hiccups were present at launch, but the developers have shown commendable dedication to polishing the game through updates. The vastness of the open world, while impressive, may feel a bit overwhelming for some players.

In conclusion, Days Gone is a masterpiece that deserves a place among the pantheon of great open-world games. Its compelling narrative, breathtaking visuals, and intense gameplay combine to create an experience that will stay with you long after you put down the controller. If you're a fan of the post-apocalyptic genre or simply enjoy a gripping narrative with heart-stopping action, Days Gone is a must-play.

I liked this game. Days Gone is an awesomely exhilarating journey through a post-apocalyptic world filled with intense battles against zombies and diverse human communities. I wholeheartedly recommend this game for its gripping action sequences and immersive storytelling. The battles against the undead are a true highlight, delivering heart-pounding moments of survival. However, as a PC player, I did find the control scheme a bit challenging at first, with the camera's sideways perspective requiring constant adjustment with the mouse. Yet, once I hopped on the motorcycle, the controls clicked and I finally got the hang of how to face the motorcycle, and effectively use the game's character movements, though unique, it added depth to hand-to-hand combat. Days Gone is a must-play title for those seeking a thrilling, immersive survival experience. I highly recommend it! 

P.S.  I recently purchases this game on a developer sale in December 2023 so I didn't pay the full price.

What a disappointment.
I've been thinking of getting this game for a long time, I really like the setting and the idea or riding a bike exploring bast landscapes full of zombies.
Seven hours in and the gameplay is a huge bore fest! 
Such a lack of detail, there's nothing interesting to do anywhere, I keep stopping on my way from point A to B as there are some buildings and houses that seem interesting, but it's just empty buildings with no one inside and a bunch of "rags" and "empty beer bottles", which is pretty much all you need to grab besides bandages. SO boring!! It doesn't even make sense how these scraps are scattered, they just lie around in random places instead of finding them in places which make sense, giving the game more realism and credibility.
Enemies can be zombies (they all look the same and do the same, damage doesn't even feel localised, just shoot or hit them a few times and they're done, always the same) or humans (which are actually too many, enough to overtake all the zombies if they'd want to!) who are fairly fun to fight but again, there's so much to do against them and it gets old super quickly. It also takes away the feel of loneliness and road movie that I was expecting from the game, I think it's a huge mistake to have so many humans in the game, and it's a big cliché in terms of story.
There's no real crafting system, just some very basic molotov and bandage from a quick menu. This is as far as 7 hs, so if it gets more interesting at any point, we have a big problem of pace here..
The Bike upgrades are not really necessary as far as I've played, it just served me to go up and down the road with not much else to do with it. Again, if there's more about it, we have a big pace problem here..
The towns have nothing to do, very basic stuff, give them some bits of monsters and animals you've killed and they'll trust you more. BASIC. BORING.
That's the feeling, everything is developed to a very basic level in terms of game mechanics and content. 
It seems like a game that would appeal to someone focused on the story, as they actually speak quite a lot, but in a zombie apocalypse setting there isn't much to be said that will surprise me, and certainly this game doesn't.
The graphics are good at least for the landscapes, but the buildings inside are uninspired and everything looks the same. Copy paste everywhere, no house looks like someone was living there, or something special was going on or happen in the past.
The characters and zombies all look the same, apart from the ones from the towns who you speak to, but these are counted with one hand. Is the first zombie game I play with such a lack in variety on enemies.
I can't stress how bland and monotone this game feels for me, I wanted to play it for so long, and I pushed myself for 7 hs to see if something develops but this seems like it.
Even if there's a big part of the map to explore for me yet, I honestly feel no interest at all to do so because if in 7 hours playing the game I didn't find anything interesting, I'm pretty sure it won't change much.
One of the biggest disappointments I ever had with videogames, and a huge mystery on why so many people are raving about it.

The sense of accomplishment from clearing swarms and nests is tangible because it actually changes the world, as you remove them travel becomes authentically easier.  The voice acting, mo-cap, and story is really good most of the time.

The rumor is that there will probably never be a sequel which is really too bad because the swarm mechanics alone are almost unique.  I know of nothing else like it and would really love to see another round of this.

I purchased this game originally on Epic Store a few years ago and bought it again because I wanted it on Steam and heck it was only $12 on sale (Totally worth it on sale and it goes on sale quite often)

I'm sad that there won't be a Days Gone 2 and will keep hopes that one day it gets picked up again. I really want to continue with the story. This is a fun single player immersive story game that has plenty of action, apocalypse theme, and fairly decent story/dialogue. 

It is not a perfect game but I have yet to find a game that is perfect. However this game runs very well for the most part, nothing game breaking, and the graphics look fantastic for the most part.

The game play also feels good in comparison to other similar third person view format. This game has a lot of content for what you pay for. Also highly recommended to play this on controller. Game's like this just feel way better on controller even if the aiming is sacrificed a bit. 

I'm not going to go over all of the minor imperfections but there are cons that stood out to me:

-Repeated voice dialog when exploring the environment, IE you finish a mission and you may have a voice dialog randomly loop again after it was just played a minute ago.

-The random blue question mark mini side missions that are mostly stupid and useless with exception to saving survivors which helps to increase camp reputation and/or credits. Sometimes the question marks just disappear as you reach to your destination and there is literally nothing there or you hear a survivor asking for help but there is no blue question mark that ever appear. 

-Stealth mode is silly in this game. I like the stealth mode a lot but the immersion gets a bit ruined because it feels like everything is blind to you when they clearly should spot you. An example of this is how the bushes provide stealth but they are so low that your character is very visible or you can crouch walk past someone only like a few feet away from you literally looking at you.

This game is for you if:

You like single player story immersion
You like exploring in open world
You like apocalypse themed games especially zombies/viral outbreaks
You like shooting and blowing things up
You like doing missions and building up reputation with NPCs
You like character progression
You like killing marauders and rippers because they are no good murders, rapists, and thieves.
Most importantly You want to role play as Daryl from TWD

For me, it's really hard to explain just how lifeless this game feels to play. On the surface it seems nice, but just beneath the surface you will see that it's actually lacking in many ways. A lot of missions are repetitive, downright boring, and very on-rails. 

Navigating on the bike and fighting the hordes are the funnest parts of the game, but everything beyond that is just a slog to play through. Freakers are totally uninspired looking. The story absolutely drags and drags and there are some missions that exist merely to pad the game out. Crafting is pretty straightforward, gunplay doesn't feel as good as it should, and the only customization you'll be doing is to your bike. Why the hell does everyone ride a motorcycle in a post-apocalyptic world? Who knows. But it's a big part of the game. While I do enjoy the hordes, they are few and far between, and most of the time freakers and other enemies can be easily cheesed. Days Gone just doesn't feel entirely polished. There is also very little to actually explore and completing objectives around the map will feel copy and pasted over and over again. There's just no substance to this game.

I really liked this game more than I thought I would, despite all the negatives and positives.
At times the game had really low lows making me almost quit, but it was worth sticking through. 

Good stuff(*Minor remarks):
The first time I saw *one* [spoiler]horde[/spoiler] at night kinda made me scared and drive my ass outta there, impressed me a lot!
The bike handling, even more so after installing a faster bike mod (Its kinda slow on base speed ngl)
Skill tree, basically all skills felt like you really want them and they really do improve your situation by a ton.
*Some skills felt like they took away from the base game and if you didn't have them stuff felt unusable. 
(For example: Melee damage is abhorrent without skills on Survival, I think bad weapons just break before they kill one Freaker if you don't have one dmg increasing skill yet)
Everything on Survival is kinda balanced by still having some sort of one shot mechanic forcing you to use all your tools.
*Not sure I was a fan of having to shoot a normal guy with a shirt 6 times (non head shots) despite this though.
Silly little Tasks strewn all over the Map make it feel alive. 
*At times this still feels repetitive though, because a lot of the time they're carbon copies of each other.
Little talks after missions make it seem more realistic and conversations with random vendors.
The survivor sense showing the mini map for a few seconds is a clever solution to not having a UI (Survival difficulty)
Story (Very eventful and long)
I very much liked the climax and [spoiler] hordes [/spoiler] peak though, was very fun!
You actually felt like you got stronger throughout the entire game.
Game length, 36 hours while doing a moderate amount of side jobs.

Meh Stuff:
Story (Kinda predictable stuff)
The emotions in cut scenes feel dated despite this game being from 2019.
Deacon kinda felt too angry at random stuff in the world for me but might just be a me thing.
Not enough enemy variety.
Repetitiveness of stuff after a while (for example opening the 500th car trunk or doing the 500th bounty mission that involves you driving into the camp, driving to the location, driving back to the camp)
Sometimes saves are really weird because they don't consider enemies, so you could just be farmed on save load by a pack of enemies.

Mods I used:
Faster bike (Survival without Fast travel made the travel a slog IMO)
Instant car trunk opening (This gets old real quick)
Lighting mod (Who doesn't want a prettier game)
*Wish I could've found a faster ladder climb mod though thats just a waste of time

[h1]7/10[/h1] Probably the only game which really focuses on the emotional aspect of surviving through a zombie apocalypse. The story is weirdly paced, especially towards the end, with some fairly predictable twists. Was surprised at how well written, although underdeveloped, even some side characters are. Boozer is a legend. The random radio calls you get will randomly interrupt other dialogue while out and about. The same character will also radio in multiple times consecutively which can make some exchanges awkward. Not much variety in mission design.

The combat is decent - it is good enough. Was not impressed with the melee combat. A good bit of variety in ranged weapons although they take a long time to unlock. Fighting humans feels good as they use cover but combat vs zombies is where the cracks start to show. Zombies pretty much run at you in a straight line. This can be a pain in the ass especialy vs hordes in the early game. The bandaid solution was to create the "focus" system allowing you to slow down time - Not great. It doesn't solve the problem and adds a system I pretty much didn't use. Later on you get more powerful tools to deal with hordes which mostly solves this issue. You are given a lot of freedom in how you approach encounters. Can set traps and use stealth.

Crafting, exploring and gathering is great, and is mostly what makes the game fun, but having limited space for crafting materials is infuriating. Running out of molotovs and not being able to craft more because you couldn't pick up the hundreds of kerosene bottles you found earlier is stupid. At least give me upgrades in the skill tree to increase the inv. space. The skill tree is pretty basic, but the abilities all seem useful. Was a bit disappointed with how linear the bike upgrades are. The bike is such a big part of the game and you basically just upgrade the engine etc. to increase some stats. Cool that all upgrades are visual tho. Ramming zombies and animals with your bike straight up feels like hitting a brick wall. Bike combat is also ass. Seems weird that they overlooked this since the bike is so key to the core experience.

There are multiple "main villains" and even though the game is insanely long, they all seem to be killed off fairly quickly and the "boss fights" are basically just melee sequences and a cutscene where they die. Felt a bit rushed.

Pros:
* Story and characters.
* Graphics.
* Music and sounds.

Cons:
* Hours of riding a bike - boring. Random encounters with zombies, wolves, snipers etc. - frustrating. I don't want that Ubisoft-style randomly generated 50 hour chewing gum, I want a decent 8-16 hour story. This is not gameplay, this is garbage play and should be considered illegal :)
* Mandatory stealth missions where you are not allowed to kill anyone because either NERO guys have bulletproof socks or just because the game tells you not to. This is lazy game design and lazy story telling, this is not some Deus Ex or Dishonored where there are actually reasons to play non-lethal.
* When you start the game, you see a message, something like "gamepad is recommended for best experience". The reason for this is that mouse is being emulated. Sometimes it becomes unresponsive, sometimes it just works incorrectly. If you hope you can speed run the boring parts because you play on KBM and will just headshot all enemies, then forget about it because your accuracy in this game depends on how long you press the RMB for and on auto-aim within your crosshair rather than on your reflexes.
* Missions. Every time someone calls you on the radio, he/she cannot just give you a briefing, instead, you are being asked to come over, so you ride to A, get mission details, ride to B then ride back to A or ride to C to get a new mission. If you want to fast travel - destroy zombie nests (who in the world would want to waste time on that?), and even if you do so, if you run out of gas, you will not be able to use fast travel, you will need to walk - this is so exciting. Moreover, the missions themselves are boring, just "ride there and kill the bad guys".
* And finally, Rikki and Addy are lesbians and Addy is fat. 1. You simply cannot be fat in a post-apocalypse world (neither can you be buff like Boozer). 2. Does the fact that they are lesbians add value to the story? No. Then why is it there? Because wokeness. Then dislike.

The game's a bit bugged in some places. But I really enjoyed the story.

Everything about the story is awful: the main character is an unlikable lying scumbag; everyone involved in the story is either stupid or an asshole, if not both at the same time just so the plot can keep moving forward thanks to their stupid decisions; it doesn't know when to end, there's always gotta be one more thing.
I was hoping this mess would end around the 25 hours mark of my playthrough but it dragged on for almost another 15... The quality of the writing was poor, but it still managed to take a nosedive once I reached the southern part of the map. The scenario is full of clichés, you can see many plot points coming from miles away and the whole thing drags on forever: [spoiler]of course that one government guy you see in the opening cutscene is alive, of course he helps you find your wife, of course she's alive, of course the shady asshole you expect to stab you in the back ends up doing so, of course he gets away and comes back to bite you in the ass later in the story, of course the leader of the evil faction knows you from times before the world ended and has a score to settle, of course the company your wife worked for was actually evil and of course the entire apocalypse was caused by research done in a secret lab in bumfuck nowhere in the middle of Oregon, right down the road where you live.[/spoiler]

The technical state of the game isn't great either.
The game can look really good at times but it comes at the cost of so much jank. Characters will look gorgeous in cutscenes thanks to motion capture, only to look at you with dead eyes and barely any sort of lips sync when giving you secondary jobs during actual gameplay. The hordes are impressive to look at, especially since they had to run on PS4 originally, but the zombies often won't play any death animation or get any sort of ragdoll when killed in large numbers at a time and will simply float in the air after dying. I also encountered a fair amount of objects who refused to load and I was stuck with their low LOD version. The last mission bugged at the end and the ground wouldn't load, forcing me to restart the game. Given that the game came out in 2019 and was then ported to PC in 2021, it's a shame to see such a lack of polish.

The rest of the game is "fine".
The open world is pretty standard and filled with the expected checklist of things to do. Combat is fine, even if the AI can be pretty abysmal especially when sneaking around. The bike is annoying to maintain for most of the game and will require constant refuel and repair until you get some upgrades. The hordes don't really bring interesting gameplay, you simply kite them around while throwing every piece of explosive you have until no zombies are left standing.


tl;dr Janky AA game marketed and sold as a AAA, should've focused on more than pretty graphics, I hope the studio got rid of their writers.

TL;DR: 

It's a mediocre game if you haven't played many games before. It's a bad game if you've played TLOU 1 and RDR 2. This game is not a hidden gem, and it was not released 'a couple of years' too late. No wonder there will be no sequel. 

REVIEW:

+ Good graphics
+ Good optimization
+ Good horde fights (tried them in challenges)
+ Some late-game elements like horde fights are okay

- The 'beginning of the apocalypse' part of this game (first cutscene) was clearly inspired by TLOU 1, and it is terrible, to say the least.
- An uninspired story that feels as if it was copied from other games
- Boring characters (inferior versions of Naughty Dog characters)
- Motorcycle gameplay (if you didn't like horses in RDR2, then try this game—it will teach you to love horse gameplay in RDR).
- Resource 'scarcity'-based gameplay, similar to TLOU, yet much worse: very hard to save ammo when zombies keep shaking their heads. Devs tried to fix it by implementing a slow-mo mechanic.
- Terrible melee combat: if you didn't manage to find an axe or machete, then good luck fighting 'melee attack sponges.'
- The world feels like a copy from RDR2, but it is nowhere near as good: in RDR2, cities were densely populated with people and activities, whereas the wilderness stayed empty for a reason. Here, if you go to the wild, you will end up seeing one zombie after another, just like in more populated locations—it feels like traveling through suburbs, not dense forests.
- The quest structure is an out-of-season April Fools' joke.
- The first part of the game is supposed to feel like you are underpowered. The problem is it sucks due to poor gameplay, an uninspired story, and boring characters. Challenges allowed me to check the 'late/end' game that is horde fights, and they are okay (but just okay).
- Dialogues are worse than in Fallout 4.
- Terrible UI and save system

I'm writing this as a form of appreciation for the Days Gone game. I played on PS and it's been a while now - over 2 years since completion. The thing is, I expected a lot and got even more. I bought a Steam version just to place this review. Also I got a physical version, despite the fact that I had the digital version on PS, so it can just stand on my shelf and shine.
It had been 910 Days Gone when I got my first PS platinum. Now I have 2 - I just don't play for the achievements, so in my case accidental platinum really means something. Even when I completed the main story and all side quests and maxed everything there is, this world still calls to me, tells its own story on every corner, every empty building and desolated outpost. I really wanted to capture it all.

My gaming background is significant, and my Steam history doesn't show it all. The reason is, I bought a lot of Steam games after playing them before, just to have them in the library, hoping to play them again sometime and get myself back to better times, but this never happens with so many chores and duties to do.

I've been a father in search of a child, soaking wet from the Heavy Rain.
I've Became Human with Kara and Marcus.
I just couldn't die, feeling Payne to the Max.
I sent a terminal patient To the Moon.
I was lurking and practiced Thievery in the Deadly Shadows.
I was Dishonored and got my honor back on Dunwall streets.
I barely survived the nightmare of USG Ishimura and Dead Space.
I was the lone survivor of Von Braun, stopping Shodan AI from making the world into its own image.
I was Andrew Ryan's puppet in the underbelly of Rapture city, bearing the whole ocean on my shoulders.
I reached Seattle with Ellie and found a purpose, whereas I had none before.
I personally witnessed how Strange Life can be.

These were some of my best titles. They left me so emotionally wrecked (in a beautiful way) and I still didn't write any review before; in fact I never did such a thing before. I wish the non existing Looking Glass Studios, makers of Thief with which I spent endless hours, got such appreciation from me, but this cannot happen anymore. I don't want to make this mistake again.

I play games for the stories, just as I read books or watch movies. There were quite a lot of them, but not all obviously left a scar. And now Days Gone, the open world game achieved that. At some point, when playing, I simply knew that nothing can break the impression made. Bend - I want to let you hear that out loud: your game (and open world games aren't usually the best in terms of telling stories) got under my skin and I didn't expect it at all. I just sometimes play OWGs as a form of escapism and your achievement kept me where I was, nailed me to the ground and it was good.

Why is that? The story has its ups and downs, it's a bit naive sometimes but still accomplishes the same what Life is Strange did for me. How Days Gone, sharing all the open world games flaws such as repeatability and bit of grind; this very same game, when it comes to the storytelling, pushes the right buttons, hits me against the wall few times, exploits me emotionally (again, in the best possible way) and stays with me after turning the console off. I'm still there, in the postapocalyptic Oregon, an empty world where almost every person is dead and those who aren't either live to survive or walk in hordes, covered in filth, sometimes wearing a wristwatch or humming songs their human self remembers. Why I cannot get back from where no hope can be found to my real life - not free from quite huge struggles - but in the end to a normal life which all of Days Gone survivors will not ever have anymore?
When I finally had put all the puzzles together, I was awestruck with the answer. It was something new to me, never felt in a game story before.

There is important stuff that adds to the story and creates the background for it. The overall ugliness of the Freakers pandemic world is beautifully balanced by nature taking the world back, weather effects, day-night cycle, rain, fog, sunrays, those little things that just sum up. They cost a lot of development effort and reveal the love put into the development - nature is simply beautiful. But that's not it.
There's also a huge amount of reminders of the world never to be the same - all the flyers, cars and things that tell little stories (like a body pinned to the wall by the car, luggage left alone ready to put inside the trunk or bloody writing on the van saying 'we went north'). There's a multitude of different environments (I just missed the big city, a place that feels like downtown): the factories, the legendary sawmill, storages, shops or houses in which you wouldn't tell, if not for the dust and trash, if they had been left 2 years or 2 days ago. This is so admirable and simply true. But this is also not it.
All open world designers compete about the amount of details, but it's not ok when the details are the purpose themselves - we are always excited about them in the trailers and during our first hours with the title and we somehow seem to forget what the games are truly for, focusing on technological achievement like it was everything. The details and attachment to the credibility of the world created is important but it's nothing without experience. Such features should only be a way to tell something more and Bend has shown how it should be done and I will repeat this to everyone: the details level tells a big amount of side stories and adds up to the main story, defining a believable world. But that's also not it..
The main story. It's great but not unique, it's not never-seen-before, however the storytelling (flashbacks and I Remember storyline!) makes it even greater. Deacon losing hope, finding it again, helping Boozer and leaving Lost Lake (I just couldn't do it easily, I rode for 2 real evenings on the north before I was ready to leave for the south) and finally Deacon finding his loved one - this is this one candle light in the mad and pointless world. But.. it's still not it.

For me what makes this experience unique is connecting all these ingredients and spicing it with something I would not think adds value, while it actually becomes cherry at the top. Devs have taken advantage of the open world games features that are usually tedious and made grinding a valuable feature. I believe it's one shot and won't be repeated for many years, however I hope I'm wrong. Why? Because it's magic. Maybe it was design purpose or maybe accidental, but for me, all this tediousness, all these tasks that Deacons burdens himself with: to bounty hunt, to burn nests, to destroy in general, all this cruising empty world is not for nothing. It's not about getting achievements and having them ticked off. It's about getting in Deacon's skin, it's about feeling an everyday empty hopeless routine, which nicely parallels my everyday, often pointless, routine. Even discovering the tourism flyers or nature viewpoint collectibles stresses the void of the new world and loss of the old one, emphasizes what Deacon's life has become when he tries to just reconcile with the fact that all is lost and at some point it makes him change, ultimately to the point when he discovers people in the freakers again.
It's been 180 Days Gone passed in-game and 910 total but I feel every one of these 730 before the story starts and this is what makes Deacon's story sound really loud. I wish to believe it was by design, not accidental. I can't imagine the other reason for putting the Days Gone counter on the game title page.

Deacon's and Sarah's story is now part of me, part of my flesh and soul and Days Gone is one of my big time titles and I wish to thank Bend for that. When I think of it, I just wish I hadn't missed the Proposal PS4 Theme that was available once before Day 731. I never knew about it and know, if I could have it enabled on my PS4 I would never ever change it. Unfortunately, it is long Gone.

TLDR - It's.... Sons of anarchy meets walking dead. Or Far cry with zombies. And a pretty good zombie open world game. Much better than the reviews would have it. Has some flaws but definitely worth playing.

Pros
- Great map and good graphics. It doesn't look much like I remember that part of the world looking, but the map is very well thought out and the scenery is beautiful. Character models were more variable though. Sometimes they looked good, sometimes not.
- Fun gun play - snappy, responsive shooting - and good motorcycle action once you get a few upgrades. The bike is a little slow to start and fuel esp. sucks - you have to refuel about every mile - but it works as a mechanic, forcing you to think about your route.
- Hordes are a great system - Getting chased down a railway track by a couple of hundred screaming, hungry zombies out for your blood never gets old. I often took a manual save and played them out a few times, trying different tactics.
- The story's a slow burner but pretty good. It's very low key - the fate of the world's not at stake, you're just trying to survive and figure out what happened to your wife. Think KCD rather than.... your average fantasy rpg. The rippers were a bit silly and militia bits variable but overall v good.
- Decent characters. Deacon occasionally veers towards yippkiyaye posturing but I thought, for the most part, he was well written and reasonably acted. I think people are so used to Mary Sue PCs who turn out to be the "chosen one" somehow destined to save the world that they struggle with playing a guy who's an average joe just trying to get by in a world gone to hell.

Cons
- The game's pacing is off; I was initially relieved not to be bombarded by quests but as time went by it felt like you're waiting for quests far too long. Reddit's advice is to "ride around for twenty minutes." I don't want to ride round aimlessly for 20 minutes in a video game.
- When they do call, they (esp Tucker) love to send you in circles. You'll be somewhere, she'll call you in for a job, then send you... right back where you were. Then demand you go back and turn in, before you ride round randomly waiting for another call, and she calls you back to camp for another job. Which is... yeah, you guessed it. Right where you were. It's a bad system. I hate fast travel but here it felt essential for sanity.
- Far too many story quests involve massive amounts of forced slow walking - and I mean old lady slow - behind characters dropping exposition, while your weps are locked and the game makes you occasionally mash a random key to do something.... pointless. Or, worse, use the crap witcher vision. It's not quite RDR2 but it's infuriating. When will devs learn this just isn't fun?
- The crafting system is shallow and you have almost no inventory space. 95% of the time, you're full up, which means that 95% of stuff you might loot, you can't. It's just bad design; there's all these cabins / mines / logging camps etc but there's absolutely no point exploring them because there's *nothing* you can actually loot. 
- The first 60% up north is much better than the stuff in the south, and the final main mission was a let down - massively overscripted, lots of forced slow walking, bullet sponge enemies, dumb shit where the MC casually strolls into obvious ambushes and possibly the worst "boss" fight I've seen in the last decade.

Overall, I got a lot of hours of enjoyment out of it -  - probably 70 hours of actual play to 100% it, incl. the epilogue - and the positives outweighed the benefits. On sale, it's a steal. There were just times when it frustrated me and, having finished the story, I'm not sure I'd want to play through all the story missions again. 

I encountered a few bugs / glitches  - blue question marks esp - but nothing major. Main issue was that some of the missions - esp. the ones using the witcher vision thing - were really janky but reloading would usually make the thing show up.

I almost passed over this entirely and I am so glad I got around to playing it.  It's a great action game with excellent exploration and survival-lite mechanics.  The motorcycle system in particular is great and this is one of the few games I've played where vehicles handle well using a mouse and keyboard.   I enjoyed using it as a means of traveling around the map and the upgrades that are unlocked as the story progresses felt meaningful and appropriately paced.  

I was impressed that nothing in Days Gone felt stale given that dystopian zombie games reached market saturation long ago.   While the story isn't unique, the characters have a lot of depth and I found myself caring about what happened to them.    Gameplay itself is satisfying and there is an excellent mix of survival and pure-action to be found.

I got almost 70 hours out of the main campaign and side missions.  They offer a NG+ mode as well, so there is even more to get out of it if you like that sort of thing.   

Its a fantastic experience all around.

Short version, Yes, absolutely yes. No ifs or maybes, get it. 

Zombie Apocalypse, ends times, certainly not new, almost thought i was sick of it but Days gone is an exception. Its strength lies in a strong focus on story/narrative and world building supported by solid game mechanics and stunning visuals.

The story might rub some gamers the wrong way, its against the current times of franchises/spin offs, references, nostalgia and general cynicism. It owns it theme but its very much about the characters. Its full of heart and sincerity, exploring classic themes of love and loss, grief and hope, of that were are fucked without each other. Sam Whitwer did an amazing job voice acting, as did much of the cast. The interactions between the characters felt organic and evolving. Also i quite liked their take on zombies and enjoyed the sinister shadow government overtones. The little touches/interactions with the npcs and how the respond to Deacon do wonders for reinforcing the themes of the game. Going to a camp the first few times its like "open up its that drifter" "Someones coming" but after you have trust its "quick open up its Deacon" "Hey Deacon". Its basic stuff but it all comes together to create a sense of building connections and community. Deacon has genuine little conversations with all the vendors, more that one! He knows there names, they warm up to each other, through tone, conversation/interaction, its great. 

Days gone is not breaking any boundaries or bringing any amazing new mechanic to the table. The game is story focused and the systems and mechanics function perfectly in support of this.  Crafting, Stat upgrades, bike upgrading is simple, adds just enough depth and sense of progression/empowerment and is often part of the narrative. Gunplay and mele is again the same, simple, responsive and feels pretty crunchy.  Stealth is the only mechanic that i think is a bit under done/utilised, its almost too simple and effective but again it works and doesnt get in the way at the least.

Both the human and infected AI isnt terrible, average honestly but i found the humans fairly good at flanking and taking cover, the infected variations posed a real threat at times, esp the infected animals and hordes - which i have to say they did do a pretty standout job on. Side activities are somewhat repetitive, clearing areas, bounties - but Deacons particular set of skills is apparent and recognised in the story, it makes sense hes making the areas safer, he is not a farmer or civil engineer unlike most zombie apocalypse games. Random encounters were actually a little bit fun, other than the npcs talking too much/loudly, which the games anticipates and shortens all random encounter npc interactions at a certain point, genus! Some encounters can be annoying but in a good kind of way and nothing motivates me to kill like being clotheslined off my bike by vagrants. 

Days gone is like a classic example of good engineering, everything is solid and it functions well. Nothing seems to be design for design sake, its all simple effective and with just a dash of flair to make it their own.

I had to talk about the bike separate from the rest of the mechanics, oh my gosh that bike. Riding in Days gone is like web swinging in The new spider-man games, id fast travel but honestly i dont want to. Riding it is a dream, it feels great to control, sounds so good and i could ride those beautiful mountain passes all day, satisfying is the best description.  Its not just a mode of transport, its your save spot, something to care for, to work on, its an extension of Deacon.  

Visually its breathtaking, bar maybe some of the npcs being legitimately more creepy than the infected but still really minor, everything else i really cant fault and that Deacon (Sam Witwer) is a handsome mother fucker even dressed like a hobo. Weather/fog is stunning.  I very rarely take screenshots in games, i do with this. Sound effects, music etc, its all top quality work - from the sounds of the forests, Infected screams, distant gunfire pops or soothing guitar rhythms its all so good.  

On top of that you get Challenges, new game+ and can reset enemy camps/hordes/nest after completing them. Oh Did i mention that it runs really well without a reliance on frame generation AI. Who knew. I play on HDR and often get my retinas blasted by the menus in HDR games, Days gone has a HDR menus brightness slider, you beautiful barstards. When you go to the visual settings in game, of which are well represented - it goes back to clear background so you can see your changes in real time, showing you metrics at the top right of the screen - gpu/cpu usage, fps. I mean even its settings are awesome, what devilry is this. 

Days gone blew me away, i didnt think this kind of design philosophy even really existed in the gaming industry anymore. Its not the best game ever but the total sum of its parts makes it in my opinion a fantastic example of this medium, why i play games really. Amazing what a creative, focused and resolute team can achieve.

Days Gone, developed by Bend Studio, takes players on a journey through a sprawling open-world post-apocalyptic landscape filled with danger, hordes of the infected, and a tale of survival. While the game offers moments of gripping intensity and a visually impressive setting, it falls short of reaching its full potential.

One of the game's strengths lies in its narrative. Protagonist Deacon St. John's personal journey in this harsh world is compelling, and the character development adds depth to the overall experience. The dynamic weather and day-night cycle contribute to the immersive atmosphere, creating a world that feels both haunting and alive.

The core gameplay mechanics, centered around motorcycle traversal and combat against zombie-like Freakers, are solid. The motorbike serves as a crucial tool for exploration and survival, and the tension of facing large hordes of Freakers is undeniably exhilarating. The game's weapon customization system also provides a degree of strategic depth.

However, Days Gone stumbles in certain areas. The pacing can feel uneven, with a slow start that might deter some players. The open-world design, while expansive, occasionally lacks the depth found in other titles in the genre. Technical issues and occasional bugs, especially at launch, also hinder the overall polish of the game.

Days Gone, despite its flaws, offers a decent experience for fans of post-apocalyptic settings and survival gameplay. While it doesn't quite reach the heights of other titles in the genre, those seeking a story-driven adventure with intense moments and a vast, atmospheric world may find enough here to make the journey worthwhile.

This game has a lot in common with "The Last of Us", in that it is very story rich, and both main characters in each game are complex characters and have a lot of emotional trauma to deal with.  Both games are almost like movies.  Like movies, whether you like the drama or not will determine whether you like the game or not, unless you just do not care about drama and only care about video game play.  I like both, and the combat system still holds my interest when the story is known and is no longer very compelling.  Basically, if you liked "The Last of Us" I think you will like Days Gone, too.

Advice:  Play the game at the easiest setting.  This is plenty challenging, even once you get experienced at it, if you also make it a rule to start the game over if you die.   That is right, no saves.  If you die, start over.  You would be amazed how much more immersive this makes the game world.   Next, if you play this using mouse and keyboard, spend a lot of time changing the keybinds so that you can do what you need to do with one hand on the keyboard, and one hand on your mouse, without looking at the keys.  It is not easy to find the right settings that will work best for you, so experiment until you can do a reasonable job of controlling  Deacon by "touch typing" like a good typist.  It takes a lot of practice, but being able to control your character is what the game is about.  You will find this out in the first minute of actual game play, when you either ride straight into a rock, or not.

Days Gone was definitely underappreciated by the Sony fandom, not to mention gamers in general but its also definitely a faulty experience with many issues. tldr--maybe wait for a sale but give this one a shot if it seems appealing.

Pros:
-great acting all around. The performances are universally great and its nice to hear a new Sam Witwer protagonist after Force Unleashed's Starkiller. He himself also wonderfully plays Deacon St. John at the line of madness. Unlike some other Sony protagonists who talk to themselves in a very straightforward fashion to tell the player what to do, Deacon rants angrily at himself, vulgarly curses those he kills, and generally thinks those around him are bullshit. Those around him are performed very admirably--even if their characters aren't well defined if at all, they remained memorable.
-looks good. not a graphical showcase but solid nonetheless, especially as the framerate stays rocksteady at 60 when a horde of dozens is on screen. I feel like the "average game look" is definitely is definitely this game: solid elements of photo-realism, a newish idea of the zombie look (this time less decayed and gross and more vampiric and feral), and plenty of world variety.
-driving model/physics and mechanics. your bike actually feels like a 400 pound bicycle, being both maneuverable but weighty, Deacon needs to carry parts on hand to fix it, and actually needs to shift his weight to minimize damage from (frequent) jumps and drops. travelling is dangerous and random; refuel stops and wrecked cars are often ambush points for enemy scavengers, wolves can keep up with the slowest of bikes, wires strung along the road and snipers hiding in the trees may unseat you from your bike, and tunnels require you to physically move cars aside to make a path. pretty much the only things that would make it better are more customization parts, a manual transmission (driving a manual car IRL makes me seek it out in gaming), and a deeper repair system requiring specific parts for engine failure, muffler damage, fluid leaks, etc, and more variety in ambushes.
-bug free, rock solid performance. It weird to have to say a great port is a pro for a game, but here we are. i noticed no hitching, dips, poorly timed frames, etc. Runs without pop in or freezing on an HDD.
-brilliant world size. This is definitely one of the hardest things to do in open world games, and this game is a perfect showcase for it. travelling from one side of the map emulates the feeling of an hours long journey without actually being that annoyingly long. environments feel realistically big while again, not being _that big._  your bike's gas tanks are perfectly suited to the escalation of the work--you start with only enough to need to refuel at _every station_ before you can travel between camps without refuelling, then eventually you can go across a third of the map without worry.

the mids
-story. at times, Deacon's personal journey is brilliant, especially when he's interacting with the NERO and Sarah storylines. Giving the player an emotional hook such as the death/possible survival of Sarah is a brilliant way to get the player invested. When people say this story is "excellent", they are referring to these two storylines. However, those particular storylines are undercut by the occasional vibe that you're being strung along and story bloat. In fact the story in general suffers from major bloat, not that its all bad. A great example is the Lost Lake storyline, which is not only undercut by an entirely unexplained history between the main character and said camp, it also introduces a plan to cut off the horde and then doesn't capitalize on it for literally _HOURS_, in part thanks to non-linear design. but mostly thanks the five+ unrelated missions inbetween. again, not that its all bad, since those inbetween missions deal with an interesting contentious relationship and realistic solutions to problems, The entire third act is way too drawn out with new settlements when you're probably not done with earlier ones. Takes 15ish hours at least to get into actual interesting story.
-gameplay. fighting the horde is great. however, fighting humans is boring and uninspired, feeling like The Last of Us but so far behind in terms of refinement. Skill point acquisition is simply too slow. Gaining camp trust takes too long. not enough bike customization (i wish it were more like Mad Max, letting you choose between like harley chassis, Kawasaki/yamaha/suzuki chassis, ducati chassic, dirt bike chassic, etc, not to mention lack of visual changes). nothing to do besides kill things.
-lore and themes. world is brilliant, but camps feel underdeveloped. you hardly spend anytime with the first two and all of them save the work camp lack identity, politics, etc. some Leaders raise interesting questions within a post apocalyptic world, have interesting political leanings, and moral beliefs but fail to explore them deeply. Deacon's own motorcycle club influenced morality is intriguing but suffers from a lack of definition and again, exploration. By the end of the game, you will still know _nothing_ about his old club aside from who was in it and who was allied and enemies with it. 
-dynamicism--this game relies on "encounters" (marked by little blue questionmarks) to source variety. following these leads to ambushes, survivors in varying states of being overrun or executed by rippers, or supplies. the problem is they have an overwhelming feeling of being spawned in around you--theres nothing natural or immersive about how you engage with these encounters.

cons
-audio glitches, overlapping conversations
-really bad melee damage output in all regards
-slow skill and trust progression
-terrible autosave system.
-most of the cons are honestly just small or relatively small elements of what makes this game good. if you don't get into it, you don't get into it, its not really the game being bad, nor is it you missing the point.
