I beat this game once on my ps4, and loved it so much I bought it again to play on Steam. I really think the Story isn't as bad as it's made out to be, I really enjoyed all the characters and branching storylines. Honestly beating the game was a cathartic experience, as you get to see the culmination of all your work and how every relationship builds up towards the end of the game. The gameplay is very good, for me personally the different approaches to dealing with large groups of enemies, balancing weapon types, scavenging materials, planning and strategizing for different encounters was all really enjoyable. The scale of the world is really good without being overwhelming, and does a good job encouraging exploration, which is made even more fun by being able to build and outfit your own badass apocalypse motorcycle. There's some minor glitches to note here and there, and some of the mandatory story missions are less fun than others, but overall a really good game (to beat twice!), plus the added challenges are their own fun experience. Definitely pick this up if you like horror/zombies/open-world/motorcycles. I just with Sony would greenlight Bend Studios to make a second entry but odds are slim on that front.

Unless you want to experience the story all over again with the tools and skills to steam roll the entire game, one playthrough is really enough. If you're looking for a kinda lengthy story of survival that isn't The Last of Us, might want to consider this one.

A Gritty Ride Through the Apocalypse

Days Gone, developed by Bend Studio and released on Steam in 2021, takes players on a harrowing journey through a post-apocalyptic open world.

One of the standout features of Days Gone is its sprawling and atmospheric open-world design. The Pacific Northwest is rendered with stunning detail, featuring diverse landscapes from lush forests to desolate highways. The dynamic weather and day-night cycle contribute to a sense of immersion, with each setting creating a different tone and challenge for players. The sheer size of the map encourages exploration, and the variety of environments keeps the gameplay experience fresh and engaging.

The narrative of Days Gone revolves around Deacon's quest for answers in the wake of personal tragedy. The storyline is well-crafted, with emotional depth and character development that add weight to the overall experience. The relationships between characters, particularly Deacon and his best friend Boozer, contribute to the game's emotional resonance. The main story, coupled with numerous side missions, creates a rich narrative tapestry that unfolds as players traverse the dangerous world.

The gameplay mechanics of Days Gone blend elements of survival, action, and open-world exploration. Motorcycle traversal is a central element, providing a means of transportation that evolves alongside the player's progress. Combat against both human enemies and hordes of Freakers is intense and satisfying, with a diverse arsenal of weapons and tools at the player's disposal. The day-night cycle influences the behavior of the Freakers, adding an extra layer of strategy to encounters.

In conclusion, Days Gone is a gritty and immersive survival adventure that delivers a compelling narrative set in a beautifully realized post-apocalyptic world. The combination of a vast open-world, engaging storytelling, and intense gameplay makes it a standout title for fans of the genre. Despite some initial technical challenges, the developers' commitment to improvement has resulted in a more polished and enjoyable experience, making Days Gone a worthwhile addition to the library of any fan of post-apocalyptic gaming on Steam.

"Nomad, another camp needs clearing. I'll mark it on your map."

When I saw the news that the game director was indignant about the 68-point review, and that it didn’t say a word about the horde, I thought: “well, the director probably wrote this for a reason, the reviewer must have actually played the entire game hour, and gave this rating because the beginning is slow and not intriguing." However, after spending 45 hours in the game, I realized that the reviewer even overestimated the rating a little.

Let's start with the very thing that the game director points to - the horde. Given his indignation, it can be assumed that this was the USP of the game, a unique mechanic on which a certain gameplay is tied, which will require the player to use cunning and which will give the player a new, never-before-seen experience. So, this is all complete nonsense. The so-called horde is not some single entity that lives as one organism and requires a special approach from the player, but SIMPLY 100-500 zombies. JUST a crowd of zombies. The usual zombies we meet throughout the game. But there are not 5-10 of them, but JUST 100-500. And they behave like ordinary zombies, without knowing about the existence of other zombies nearby, and without using any unique behavior. These are JUST 100-500 zombies that JUST run after the player. And which you JUST need to kill all of them.
How to kill them correctly? I don't know. The game didn’t teach me anything through text, examples, or level design. Around the horde, the designers simply placed barrels, tanks, bundles of trees and other things, which are located as inconveniently as possible. With a 99% probability, these objects causing damage to the horde will be useless, because the horde does not move in a single stream, but breaks up into hundreds of small rivers, and by “activating” one such object the player will kill, God forbid, at least 10 zombies. In addition, in the game no one ever fights the horde except the player himself, and there is no one to spy on options for dealing with this entity. I’m not talking about the text, this is a completely amateur approach to design, but it’s not here either.
As a result, the easiest way to deal with the horde is to find the nearest building with stairs, and shoot/burn/explode helpless zombies who do not know how to use these stairs. If it’s easier for a player to resort to abuse like this, then your design is... Well, you get the idea.

Let's leave the horde alone, they already suffer from a lack of mechanics. Let's move on to the general gameplay of the game. Do you like clearing out enemy camps? No? It’s a shame, because for some reason the developers decided that this mechanic worked best for them in the game, and they made all the side (and not only side) quests in the game in this format. Need to help a camp with bandits? Clear out the enemy camp. Has someone escaped from the settlement? Clear out the enemy camp. Need to find supplies? Clear out the enemy camp. Is someone asking you to bring something important? Clear out the enemy camp. Need to clear an enemy camp? Not this time, better watch 5 cutscenes in a row.
I think you already understand what I want to say. The game has almost no variety in missions. It was an incredible joy for me when in one of these missions, after clearing the enemy camp, a horde suddenly rained down from the floor above, everything was so monotonous. And these side tasks are arranged to advance the plot so meanly, as if the designers specifically wanted to evoke a feeling of hatred towards themselves. When, after a dramatic scene where almost everything is about to come to a head, you are already anticipating what will happen next, and you are suddenly thrown back into the open world, and they say, “Dick, I have a task here for you,” you want to tear and throw from despair . It's just... bad. The person who made the decision to do this - rot in hell, please. Just like the designer who decided that it would be fun to put a script in a mission with a cave and a horde that prevents you from leaving the cave JUST BECAUSE.

But enough about the bad. The game has some good and some good moments. I won’t go into detail, but I’ll just list:
- Acting and voice acting. The main character is voiced and filmed beautifully. The secondary ones are sagging, but overall they’re not bad either.
- Riding a motorcycle. There is room for improvement, but overall, riding a pumped-up iron horse is quite pleasant.
- General development of the plot. A couple of times I thought I knew what would happen next, but I turned out to be wrong. And this is good. I hate it when the plot is foreshadowed.
- Shooting in slow motion. Overall shooting is below average. If it weren't for the slowdown, I would have put it in the game's cons.

The result is 5/10. The reviewer was right.
I don't recommend the game. Unless with a discount of 50% or higher.

"There was a time where bad data collection policies were a bad thing, and you know what, they still are"

I finished the game. The last 20 hours of it pissed me off more and more to the point that I didn't want to play anymore, but I wanted to finish it.

1. Data collection policy. Read it. They collect all data on your computer. Argue. Ignore it. Don't even think about it. It's still there. It's still a fact, in writing, on the main screen. If you don't have a problem with it, you shouldn't be living in America. 

2. Game breaking bugs. Terrain not loading in causing missions to fail. Story items, characters or objectives glitching out or not appearing at all. This was all luckily fixed by restarting the game. But this game has been out for awhile and they still exist going into 2023. Lazy.

3. Story. I hate any story, any game, any book, anything that allows the story, in this case, the bad guys, to be driven forward by pure COINCIDENCE. And that's all the major turning point was near the end of the game. Pure coincidence that a plan failed, that the bad guys were at the right place at the right time, where all the key players were in a spot where they didn't need to be. Or the fact that they are even around at all because "killing is bad". Unrealistic in a world like this. 

4. Bullet sponge mechanics. Both the player and the enemies in higher difficulties. Never mind that the game doesn't allow you to change the difficulty settings on the fly, like most games these days. But they make it worse by never introducing armor into the game and harder enemies in the earlier stages, so they make up for it by making you the player a unstoppable force in Easy-Normal. Then turn around in any enemy above Hard capable of taking 10-15 bullets to the body on normal enemies. It is and always will be the lazy mans way of turning up the difficulty. DO NOT play on Easy or Normal if you actually want to enjoy the game. I regret playing on Normal and realized too far in that I couldn't change it, I didn't want to spend 2 days going back.

4. Mods. This game SUCKS without mods. The fact no one has heard of backpacks but a hand full of newts, is CRAZY to me. But mods fix everything but the bugs in the game. Check them out on Vortex/Nexus mods. Making Hordes ACTUALLY dangerous. Making special infected show up more than once in your ENTIRE playthrough. Making bounties actually worth it (if someone only have me $5 for a Freaker ear IRL, I'd spit in their face). Giving vendors more than garbage. Removing the "trust" system all together to favor the real life aspect of "you got money? I got stuff". And much much more. I can't recommend any game that requires so much reworking from the modding community to actually be enjoyable.

In the vast realm of video games, there are certain titles that manage to captivate players and leave a lasting impression. One such game is "Days Gone," an open-world action-adventure game developed by Bend Studio and released in 2019. Set in a post-apocalyptic world overrun by hordes of ferocious zombies, the game offers an immersive experience, compelling storyline, and thrilling gameplay. In this blog post, we will explore the reasons why Days Gone has become a fan favorite and why it deserves a positive review.

Engaging Storyline:
Days Gone introduces players to the story of Deacon St. John, a former outlaw biker who becomes a bounty hunter in a world devastated by a global pandemic. The game's narrative is rich and emotionally charged, exploring themes of loss, survival, and redemption. As players progress through the game, they uncover the mysteries of the past and embark on a journey filled with unexpected twists and turns.

Stunning Open-World Environment:
The game's open-world environment is vast, diverse, and visually stunning. From dense forests to desolate highways, players are treated to a range of breathtaking landscapes to explore. The attention to detail is remarkable, with realistic weather effects, dynamic lighting, and impressive character animations. The immersive world of Days Gone truly brings the post-apocalyptic setting to life.

Intense and Varied Gameplay:
Days Gone offers a perfect blend of action, stealth, and survival elements. Players can engage in thrilling motorcycle chases, intense gunfights, and strategic stealth takedowns. The game also introduces a unique mechanic called the "Freaker" horde, where players face massive groups of zombies that require careful planning and execution to overcome. The varied gameplay mechanics ensure that players are constantly engaged and challenged.

Compelling Characters:
One of the standout aspects of Days Gone is its well-developed characters. Deacon St. John, the protagonist, is a complex and relatable character with a troubled past and a strong sense of loyalty. The supporting cast is equally compelling, with each character having their own motivations and story arcs. The interactions between characters, coupled with stellar voice acting, create a truly immersive and memorable experience.

Continuous Updates and Support:
Since its release, Days Gone has received regular updates and support from the developers. These updates have not only addressed bugs and technical issues but have also introduced new features and content, enhancing the overall gameplay experience. This commitment to post-launch support demonstrates the dedication of the development team and their willingness to listen to player feedback.

Conclusion:
Days Gone is a must-play game for any fan of the action-adventure genre. With its engaging storyline, stunning open-world environment, intense gameplay, compelling characters, and continuous updates, it offers an immersive gaming experience that keeps players hooked from start to finish. Bend Studio has created a masterpiece that showcases their talent and dedication to delivering a high-quality gaming experience. Whether you're a fan of the post-apocalyptic genre or simply looking for an exhilarating adventure, Days Gone is a game that should not be missed.

Just when the story starts to get interesting , the game begins to give unnecessary tasks like babysitting Boozer or finding some guys MP3 player. That's why i kept losing interest in story. Also character relationships are not making any sense too. Immediately after arguing with a character, in the next mission, they continue to talk as if nothing happened. Sometimes some characters are doing unnecessary things just to make story more dramatic. And i didn't feel anything at those scenes because there is no way they would happen in a realistic story. I also have to mention that i didn't feel like Deacon which is the protagonist of Days Gone, has one main purpose that he follows. You may like the story maybe because it has a theme we don't encounter much but these are the main reasons why i couldn't like the story of Days Gone.

[u][b]A Quick Tip: Do not close the game right after finishing the story. There is 4 more cutscenes. Here is how you can get them:[/b][/u]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2953827117

[h1][i]Graphics:[/i][/h1]
  It is not hard to see that graphics of Days Gone is gorgeous. Texture quality is very good and it does feel good to look at the world of Days Gone. The graphics with music makes the atmosphere so strong which makes it very immersive to hang out in the world of Days Gone. If you love taking screenshots in games, Days Gone is the right game for you.


[h1][i]Gameplay:[/i][/h1]
  As i said before it is very fun and immersive to travel around in open world and we do that with a bike. Bike is like horses in RDR2. Although it is not a living being, you have to care for it. You have to fix it and you have to fill it with fuel when it's out of it because if you don't, you are going to walk until you found fuel. This is a good thing if you want more immersion. At first i didn't like this to much but when i learned how it works it just made the game more immersive for me. Days Gone's open world may be immersive, however it doesn't offer anything but same open world activities we have seen in so many other games gameplaywise. You have to do these activities if you want to upgrade gear, bike and unlock new skills because it is rewarding player with credit, experience and trust of the camps. The problem is these activities gets boring because they are repetitive. This is not a big problem early on but later at the game you will encounter too many hordes. Hordes are one of the few things that makes Days Gone special. They can make the game more exciting when they came out of nowhere. As you can guess it's not very easy to fight with hordes especially if you didn't invest in the right skills. If you don't want to do boring open world activities later for some skill points like me, i recommend to you to acquire the skill that improves the number of items you carry like bombs and molotov cocktails. Because those items are the most helpful ones when you are fighting a horde. Combatwise you have two options: melee and ranged. Melee is all about dodging and attacking. Yes, there is different melee weapons but gameplaywise they are all same. Only difference is their damage and durability. You can only counter by pressing a button that appears in screen when an enemy grabs them witch makes melee combat limited. Early on, another thing that makes melee combat limited is stamina management. Main problem with it that it refills so slow. Once player is out of stamina and there is a crowd of freakers, you will going to take a lot of damage until dodging and running becomes available again which is very annoying. But you will encounter with these problems only at the beginning of your playthrough. Ranged combat though is way better than melee. Variety of ranged weapons is good enough and enemies are reacting to bullets as they should even if it's not the best i have seen. Classic weapon wheel we know is named as survival wheel in Days Gone witch is understandable because it isn't only allowing you to choose weapons, it's also allowing you to craft and use items like molotov cocktail and bandage. It's very easy and comfortable to use survival wheel. 	 

[h1][i]Music:[/i][/h1]
 Music in this game does it's job well and makes the atmosphere way stronger which is more than enough. I will keep listening some songs from Days Gone in my daily life and i'm sure you will find something for your taste too.

[u][b]Here is the link to soundtrack:[/b][/u]
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EDVH-wkXfQs&list=PLPfHaI9XqTnH-umv3t0twvpgeO-KUunnX 

[h1][i]Technical:[/i][/h1]
  Game runs with 50-60 FPS with mix of medium and high graphic settings at 1080p on GTX 1650 Ti laptop. One other positive technically is i didn't see any bugs at my 50 hour playthrough so i can say that it is a very solid PC port. However don't expect an AI like MGSV. Freakers can be deadly when they attack as crowd but they are not a big danger when they're alone and that's okay because they're not suppose to be smart. Main problem with AI is human enemies. They are neither good at forcing player to get out of cover nor staying behind cover themselves.

[h1][i]Conclusion:[/i][/h1]
 If Days Gone didn't have a unique theme, i probably would give it a negative review with the fact that i didn't like the story and i'm bored of these Ubisoft style open world designs. But even though Days Gone didn't liked by the critics on it's release, i believe every gamer who is into zombies and post-apocalyptic theme should give it a chance.

under-appreciated is an understatement. days gone unfolds a profoundly emotional, captivating narrative. 

while the initial segment is executed finely, the subsequent hours may appear somewhat lackluster, shaping the initial perception of a player. however, the game steadily ascends in quality. following the introduction to the third encampment, the story gains depth, revealing the intricate layers of deacon's character.

deacon's relationships with boozeman, kouri, skizzo, rikki, and iron mike provide personal glimpses into his character. coupled with his response to the loss of sarah gives a humane nature to the narrative. additionally, his attitude towards iron mike’s encampment and the wizard island. over 9 hours of cinematically presented cutscenes, bend studio's commitment to storytelling is evident, showcasing the actors' performances.

deacon saint john, an ex-military soldier adorned in the colors of the separated mongrels motorcycle club. deacon surpasses the stereotype of a disgruntled character while grieving his presumed-dead wife, appreciating his existing mongrels brother boozeman, he navigates a post-apocalyptic oregon with a hint of purpose. his military expertise and readiness to get his hands dirty make him a protagonist unafraid to tackle any circumstance thrown at him.

sam witwer's portrayal of deacon is executed flawlessly, conveying a range of emotions seamlessly. minute details, such as deacon's trigger discipline or the tone of his voice to passengers on board while travelling via the motorcycle reflect the meticulous thought and love invested in the game's development.

the array of emotions portrayed within a single scene’s impressive. while dealing with an horde, you can hear deacon go from a calm state to a panicked state to a panicked yet confidently aggressive state.

the motorcycle mechanics strike realism and enjoyment, making the driving experience unparalleled. the relationship with the motorcycle goes beyond typical game dynamics. manual tasks like filling the gas tank add to the immersive gameplay. exploring the world manually, despite the option to fast travel, unveils unique experiences and errands through deacon's radio.

the rippers, a cult that worships the freakers as they feel they are a species who aren’t troubled by their past is a good measure of what circumstances that of days gone can do to certain people. 

while traversing the world of days gone, you can get ambushed by rippers along with marauders. whether it’d be with a tripwire completely damaging your motorcycle or a sniper bullet knocking you off your motorcycle. ambushes and damage to the motorcycle necessitate repairs whether it’d be from a mechanic or scrap found, which overall enhances the survival aspect.

hordes, a standout feature from the E3 2016 showcase, deliver an adrenaline-inducing experience. strategic planning and quick thinking are imperative when facing these massive zombie swarms. the variety of freaker types, each with distinct characteristics, further enriches the gameplay.

days gone masterfully employs lighting to accentuate its graphical prowess. oregon's diverse landscapes, from lush forests to snow-covered mountains, contribute to the game's visual allure. I really do want to stress how visually stunning days gone really is however I’m not great with formulating words in order to describe graphical aspects. I found myself hitting the road manually rather than using the fast travel feature as it allowed me to further appreciate the graphical delight that it is.

in conclusion, days gone is a must-play, with its positives far outweighing any negatives. it remains an underappreciated gem, unjustly overshadowed. the game's potential for a sequel is undeniable, and it's profoundly unfortunate how playstation denied it.

Incredibly underrated game. I was excited for Days Gone back when it was first advertised for PS4, and seriously considered getting a PlayStation just to play it, but ultimately didn't. Now years later it's come to PC and I've finally had the chance to play it. Despite my huge expectations for this game I was not at all disappointed. The game is just as good as I always thought it would be. 

It took me 62 hours to 100% all of the storylines without using any fast travel, which I'd say is a good amount of game time for the price. The challenge mode also provides some additional game time, especially if you wanted to get Gold on all of them.

The gameplay itself is great, fighting the hordes is of course the best part, but the missions, and general interactions with the world, are also very enjoyable. Riding from one section of the map to another is always entertaining as there are so many unexpected things that you have to deal with, be it a roadside ambush, running out of fuel or accidentally driving into the middle of a horde- which I did several times. 

One of the only things I'd have changed would be the impact of dying for the player. You really don't face any consequences for dying in this game, you just respawn nearby. If you lost all of your ammo, or even your guns, it would certainly raise the stakes.

In all a fantastic game that I'd love to see a  sequel for, as unlikely as that may be now.

Days Gone is fantastic. It's an open world third person shooter in a post-apocalyptic world that looks beautiful, runs at >80fps on a Radeon 6700XT @ 1440p with max settings, and has some very smooth gameplay when it comes to combat.

The story is engaging, with you controlling the main character Deacon and bouncing from survivor camp to survivor camp, looking for your wife, fighting off a freaker (zombie) invasion, and just generally causing some mayhem. There are some pretty well written characters here, and the story takes some pretty dramatic twists and turns that keep you engaged.

Combat itself is very smooth and is kind of the star of the show. Fighting freakers just feels plain old fun. You can use melee weapons (that you can find or craft yourself) or ranged weapons, as well as use explosives, distractions, and other such devices. You generally have pretty limited ammo, which at times can make situations pretty tense, and the freakers are something else. They run, they dodge shots, they flank, they cover their face to protect their head, and other awesome things that really makes the enemy AI fun to fight. You can die easily. Combat is very tense, and exploring freaker caves and dark locations really brings about a feeling of anxiety and dread. It's fantastic.

There's a level up system where you can add skills to your character, with XP earned by questing or killing enemies. Camps have a faction-ish type system where if you do runs and jobs for them, you'll gain their trust, get credits for their camps, and be able to purchase better bike parts and weapons. It keeps progression moving nicely. And speaking of progression, the freakers evolve constantly throughout the game. You wind up fighting some pretty crazy stuff. It's great. 

And then there's exploration. You'll get to explore destroyed villages, camps, small towns, industrial complexes, science facilities, and so much more. There's tons of loot for you to collect along the way, which goes hand in hand with the crafting system. Plus, the world just looks beautiful and is fun to explore.

About the only downside of this game is that the mouth animations during dialogue aren't great and can be a bit jarring at times, especially for minor characters, and that the game doesn't really have much of a choice/consequences system. There are a few minor choices you can make in the game that impact the story, but otherwise it's a bit linear. Other than that, highly recommend.

Days Gone is definitely a good game, it's generally well-made, incredibly beautiful, and its core gameplay loop is fun... for the first hour or two. That's the issue with this game; it doesn't change. The combat is satisfying and fun to engage with, but after 4+ hours of of it with no variation to be seen (not even different enemy types), it gets incredibly tedious and frustrating to the point that I found myself avoiding enemies simply because I got bored of fighting them. Then comes the story, which I can only describe as confusing; everyone is blatantly and pointlessly hostile to one another, 90% of the quests are just disguised fetch quest and usually revolve around you being everyone's errand boy, and half the time it feels like the protagonist is actively trying to sabotage himself and those trying to help him. So much of the conflict in the story is so easily avoidable it's actually aggravating, and it left me completely disinterested in the story after hours of seemingly no character progress. But, in fairness I couldn't bring myself to finish the game, so maybe it really turns around in act 3.

To paraphrase a review I read recently: Days Gone is "one of the strongest 7/10 titles in the genre." I can't help but agree. 
Days Gone is a good game. I was pleasantly surprised how invested I was from my first session with it. Let's face it: the action/adventure/shooter/survival genre can get a bit stale once you've gathered enough/get enough XP/access the choice unlocks. And while Days Gone is no exception to the rule, it still stands out as a game I'd recommend to anyone curious about it.

Why?

Because this game lives in it's story. While the writing of the dialogue is questionable at times, the quality of the cutscenes, motion capture, and voice acting are excellent. The actors and actresses deliver compelling performances, despite the writing being a bit...."wooden", at times. 

And for anyone who likes to spend time outdoors or on a bike- this game is GORGEOUS, and a real treat to explore. I never found myself getting bored of tearing around a fictionalized version of post-apocalyptic Oregon on the back of a bike. You know it's good when, like me, you opt to skip fast travel for the open road because the bike mechanics/physics/responsiveness are so good! 

And boy howdy, hordes are and absolute blast to deal with. 

It's the first "far cry formula" title I find myself considering a New Game+ and going back to complete the challenges. 

TLDR: "One of the strongest 7/10 titles in the genre.". Anyone on fence about it might be pleasantly surprised by the quality of the story and presentation. The gameplay loop, beautiful presentation, and bike mechanics were enough to keep me invested. I loved it, despite some of the typical pitfalls games in this genre tend to have.

This is a game that deserved much better than what it got, and it still delivers despite its shortcomings.

Is it broken? Still buggy, even years later? Rushed? Yes.
Does it have clunky gameplay? Repetitive missions? Cliche methods of restricting the player? Yes to all.

Is it worth playing?
Definitely.

Whatever downsides Days Gone has, are completely overshadowed, in my opinion, by the care and effort that has been put in its story and, most importantly, its characters. The writing does a great job at making every character into a personality, but it's the voice acting that takes them to the next level and makes them human.
Because that was the bottom line for me in Days Gone: this is not "just another zombie shooter", "just another open world game", "just another (insert your pick)", this is a raw and honest story about humans and humanity. The "good guys" are flawed, and carry the weight of their flaws with them. The "bad guys" have reasons for being "bad", reasons behind their actions, even redeeming qualities. Even the cartoonish over the top villains are given an explanation of what has driven them to their current state.
Another strong point is the depiction of trauma. These are broken people living broken lives in a broken world, doing whatever they can to maintain a sense of humanity. It's a story of hope, but the characters are fearful of holding that hope, simply because it can be lost so easily. There will be no knight in shining armor coming for the princess, and the princess would be shellshocked anyway, holding a knife to the knight's throat. I can't think of many games that have depicted dealing with the past and finding strength to seek the future as well as Days Gone. The story is filled with emotion, but a lot of it is suppressed and muted. Once again... human.
Moving on to more mundane opinions, two other open world games came to my mind while playing, for two reasons, namely Mad Max and Red Dead Redemption.
First reason: the game world. Beautifully crafted, and a pleasure to look at and drive through, with plenty of attention to finer details that make it feel... maybe not real, but definitely believable.
Second: the drifter bike. Just as your horse in Red Dead, or the Magnum Opus in Mad Max, the bike starts as a transportation tool, but over the time gradually becomes an extension of yourself and just as much a character as anyone with a voice.

Is it a masterpiece? No. The decisions made by Sony have left a heavy impact, and it would be dishonest to deny that.
It is, however, an uncut diamond in the rough. Bend Studio have done their best to deliver a great experience, and in my opinion, they succeeded. We can only hope they get a chance at a sequel, and the ability to tell us more.

[h1] TLDR [/h1]
[b] This is a great single player game for those who love to be immersed in a world that shows more than tells to get its story across.  Definitely worth the price especially if you get it on sale. [/b]

[h1] The Story [/h1]
The story in the game is good but falls just short of being great.  The game drops you immediately into the world and has you learning of events on the fly.  The main story is somewhat predictable at times and at other times has interesting twists, it starts off slow and at times it is hard to care about the story in the beginning but further on it had me actually invested in the characters.  I found some of the more interesting world building of the story comes from collectibles.  All in all the story could have been closer to the league of The Last of Us, if it had a bit more polish on writing, voice acting, cut scene animations, etc. but is not bad by a longshot.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
The gameplay is where Days Gone really shines through, I just finished a play-through on normal difficulty and I wish I had started on hard.  You start off in the game very weak with limited weapons and ability to deal with the dangers you come across in the world this is where a lot of the fun of the game come from.  Towards the end of the game on normal however, I felt like a super soldier.  --Will be playing through again later on Survival II.  

[h1] Bugs [/h1]
Very minimal bugs, I only experienced a couple times of things not loading in correctly in the world, only one of these was during a mission which I had to reload the checkpoint but that fixed it.

Days Gone - Biker Survival Meets Zombie Hordes and... Freaker Freak-Outs!

Alright, folks, hold onto your handlebars because we're diving headfirst into the post-apocalyptic mayhem of Days Gone, where the undead don't politely stay dead! It's like Sons of Anarchy meets World War Z, and it's a wild ride!

So, you're Deacon St. John, a gruff biker dude with the coolest name ever. He's not exactly the guy you'd pick to save the world, but hey, life's full of surprises. And when it's swarming with zombie-like "Freakers," you take what you can get.

The Good Stuff:

Biker's Paradise: Riding your hog through the beautiful, decaying Pacific Northwest is a blast. It's like a cross-country road trip but with more zombies and less scenic overlooks.

Zombie Horde Spectacle: Those Freaker hordes are like a mobile mosh pit from hell. Seriously, it's like Coachella, but with fewer flower crowns and more gnashing teeth.

Crafting & Survival: You'll be scavenging everything from nails to sterilized bandages to create some wicked zombie-slaying weaponry. It's like MacGyver with more motor oil.

The Not-So-Good Stuff:

Open World Fatigue: Sometimes you'll feel like a post-apocalyptic FedEx delivery guy, running around from one errand to another. "Hey Deacon, can you pick up my lost cat while you're at it?"

Deacon's Mood Swings: Deacon can be a real drama queen sometimes. He's all serious one minute, cracking jokes the next. Make up your mind, man!

Freaker Traffic Jams: When you stumble upon a horde, it's a beautiful mess. But sometimes they get stuck on an abandoned car, and you're like, "Come on, guys, move it! We've got a schedule here!"

In the end, Days Gone is a fun and unpredictable zombie-slaying extravaganza, perfect for anyone who's ever wondered how they'd survive a zombie apocalypse on two wheels. Just be prepared for the occasional traffic jam of undead enthusiasts and Deacon's roller-coaster emotions. Stay alive, my friends, and keep those Freakers freaked out!

A great open world, Zombie-killer game.

The gameplay loop is very well done, same as the world building, weapons, progression, audio / sound design and in general every aspect of the game is very, very, very well done.
Riding a bike in the zombie apocalypse never felt as good and the killing of hordes feels soooo right, better then I have experienced in another 3D Open World game.

It does suffer from the Ubisoft-issue of completing checkmarks on a map which turns repetitive quickly, but then again, the gameplay is so satisfying that it doesn't feel like grinding.

The story while it picks up nicely, in my personal opinion, it tries to go for too much, and you might also have the feeling that the game is coming to it's end without having time to properly close / address all it's opened topics, and you will be right.
Personally, I would still see the story, but don't expect to be blown away by it's story, mainly on the final act, it's seriously let down and ends with a "okay, I guess that's the end then". The ride there was very much enjoyable, even if it can't stick a proper landing.

Still, a great game that is easy to recommend.
Expect about 30-80 hours of gameplay depending how much you want to see (story vs complete almost every achievement), more if you plan on completing NG+ in higher difficulties / enjoy the Horde Killing.

Worth it for the riding / horde killing alone.

I'm a firm believer that Sony needs to greenlight Days Gone 2. For those who've played Days Gone on PS5, many will attest to its captivating allure, especially with its unmatched off-road motorcycle physics. I owned a 2016 BMW scrambler, and I was awed by how the in-game bike felt strikingly similar. From the gravity to the gear shifts and clutch work, it felt authentic. One of the highlights? The fuel economy system, where one has to strategically ease up on descents to conserve fuel.

The magic of Days Gone truly unfolds after the prologue, particularly when you encounter characters like Obrian and make it to Lost-Lake. As the story progresses, far from becoming tedious, the game becomes even more absorbing. The serenity of bike rides set against a backdrop of guitar tunes, breathtaking landscapes, and the adrenaline of chasing hordes is pure joy.

Despite its evident commercial success and adoration from a significant portion of the player base, the news of its sequel's cancellation, supposedly due to a handful of negative reviews, is deeply disappointing. To anyone who might have overlooked this gem because of these reviews, I implore you to give it a chance. Days Gone transcends mere gameplay; it offers an immersive experience.

Alright, survivors, let's discuss Days Gone. While it may not have received much attention at its release, this game is a real gem for those into open-world zombie survival. Let me share my thoughts on it.

The game's appearance is amazing. The bleak Oregon environment, following the apocalypse, is stunningly dark. It may not be the green, scenic open world that you would anticipate, but that's a positive attribute. The story has a gritty and worn feel that fits the mood perfectly. The realistic weather and day/night cycle add depth.

Deacon St. John, a tough biker with a big heart, tries to find his place in a world overrun by Freakers. Despite his rough edges, Deacon's character is strangely charming.

The game Days Gone has amazing gameplay. You'll love riding your motorcycle through the wilderness because it feels like an extension of you. The combat against hordes of Freakers is intense and requires strategy and resource management. It can get pretty challenging!

However, there are some issues with the game. The pacing might feel slow, especially in the early hours. There are some errors, but not important ones.

Optional quests have different levels of enjoyment, but some are entertaining and enhance the game world. The developers made an effort to fix the issues after release. Encountering survivor camps gives the game a human touch after the apocalypse, which I liked.

In the end, Days Gone may not have been extremely popular, but it is a good game and an underrated gem in the zombie apocalypse genre. If you like games set in open-world environments that have a bit of a dark side and lots of zombies, you should try this one out. It's not flawless, but it's a diamond in the rough that deserves attention from those who are willing to give it a chance.

For a game centered around gunplay and somewhat around stealth, those two mechanics are absolute garbage.

This game has WAAAY too much bloom, and even buying more accurate guns and getting the skill that improves gun accuracy barely helps. It feels like 80% of the time when the reticle is dead center on an enemy's head, the shot misses anyways. On the other hand, when I fire when the reticle is clearly not pointed at the enemy, the game frequently decides to randomly give me a headshot anyways. Inconsistent gun mechanics makes very single gunfight is insanely annoying.

When it comes to stealth, once a single enemy spots you, all enemies immediately know your exact location, and they will never lose track of you, even when the HUD tells you you cannot be seen or heard. There are a few exceptions, like dumpsters you can hide in, but they aren't available in most places. Some times, enemies also literally spawn right next to you.

Riding the bike around is usually pretty fun, until a sniper randomly spots you, and by that time it is impossible to run away/hide, so you just get shot, fall of your bike, and die. Wolves are also extremely annoying, as even when you outrun them, they'll just teleport to you, swipe you off your bike, and kill you. If god forbid you get off the bike to fight them, they'll take 15 shots to the face each before they die, running you completely out of ammo.

There are also way too many "follow this NPC" moments that act like glorified cutscenes, but bore you out of your mind by having you walk at a snail's pace or wait for some part of the environment to move. If you skip these, you lose out on important parts of the story, which I would say is the most interesting part of the game.

When the game works the way it implies it should work, the gameplay is satisfying, and the story seems to be pretty good. 
Most of the time however, these systems are just absolutely broken, leading to an extremely frustrating gameplay experience.

Yeah, Deacon won't ever shut the fuck up, and the excessive vocalized pauses make him sound like he has a legitimate speaking disorder. Sam Witwer isn't a bad actor by any means, so I can only really blame the directors for this bizarre voice acting. I know this seems like the most pedantic shit ever to focus on in a review, but it's actually pretty distracting and takes me out of the game because I'm usually laughing at Deacon instead of empathizing with him. Otherwise, it's fine. Kinda typical open world affairs but not too grindy or repetitive for me yet. [b]An Epic Journey Through a Post-Apocalyptic World[/b]

Days Gone is an absolute masterpiece, taking survival horror and open-world gaming to a whole new level. Set in a hauntingly beautiful post-apocalyptic Pacific Northwest, this game delivers an immersive experience that keeps you on the edge of your seat.

The first thing that strikes you is the breathtaking graphics and attention to detail. The world of Days Gone is so realistic that you can almost smell the decay and feel the tension in the air. Whether you're exploring lush forests, abandoned towns, or taking on hordes of terrifying Freakers, the game's visuals are nothing short of stunning.

But Days Gone isn't just about eye candy; it's also a story-driven adventure that's both emotionally engaging and action-packed. You'll step into the shoes of Deacon St. John, a rugged and relatable biker trying to survive in a world overrun by the undead. Deacon's journey, filled with heart-wrenching moments and moral dilemmas, will keep you invested from start to finish.

The gameplay is where Days Gone truly shines. The motorcycle is your lifeline, and it's a blast to ride through the diverse terrain of the open world. Combat is intense, and the AI-driven Freaker hordes will test your tactical skills as you fight for your life. The game's dynamic weather system and day-night cycle add an extra layer of complexity to your strategies.

What sets Days Gone apart is the game's ecosystem, where the Freakers and other factions interact with each other, creating unpredictable scenarios. This world feels alive, and your choices have real consequences, which makes for a truly immersive experience.

Of course, no game is without its flaws, and Days Gone had some minor technical issues upon release. However, the developers have been diligent in addressing these problems through updates.

In conclusion, Days Gone is a gripping, intense, and visually stunning game that offers an epic adventure in a beautifully crafted post-apocalyptic world. If you enjoy immersive storytelling, challenging gameplay, and a touch of horror, this game is a must-play. Don't miss out on this gem in the Steam library.

I really really enjoyed this game. 

And while i'm tempted to pour my heart out about how much i enjoyed my 100 hours of playing this game to near completion, The TLDR is that I implore anyone who likes open world 3rd person shooters with a strong central story to play this game.

Some things i really liked:

-Motorcycle driving, management, and upgrade system. You develop a huge Dependency on your bike as its a central story element and centerpiece to the gameplay. This relationship only deepens as you get to the endgame where the right upgrades can save your life.

-The game world, environment design, lore, and overall presentation. Beautiful Oregon countryside interspersed with post apocalyptic ruin, with a great deal of small and large details that provide world-building without any exposition. Graphics are awesome and at times breathtaking, and I found the overall game world enticing to explore. All of this is backed up by a solid soundtrack, that somehow mixes the themes of dread and isolation of this damned world, the openness and serenity of the landscape that remains, and the grunginess and rebellious tones that hints back to the characters' days now-gone (ha) as former members of a biker gang. Perfectly paired music and game world. Once fully unlocked, the game map is substantially large and loaded with interesting landmarks, camps, ruins, nests, some unique encounters, and more.

-zombie "freaker" infestation, encounters, and hordes. The main attraction... though the enemy designs are somewhat lackluster and not super varied. This is made up for in the actual variety of encounters with freakers, as you'll often find yourself in tense encounters - Especially when it comes to fighting the hordes. There is no greater fun than luring a horde to a bandit Camp and watching them all get wiped away while you zoom away on your bike.

-story, specifically for development of its characters. The main characters (deacon, his friend Boozer, and some of the friends deacon knew from before the events in game) have very fleshed out story arcs that lead to a satisfying, albeit mildly cheesy happily ever after-ish ending. Deacon, played by Sam witwer (Darth Maul from the clone wars) has incredible depth for a protagonist and really feels like a fleshed out character. Many have complained that the story is somewhat generic, though i felt that HOW the list of protagonists/antagonists react and change due to the story's events are what actually sold me.

-length. Surprisingly, the game is actually quite lengthy without feeling horribly drawn out. I tend to be the open world player who spends alot of time simply roaming and upgrading rather than playing the missions, but i think that speaks to the world design's strength. There were several "false" endings that actually made me think "no, i dont want it to be ending yet" that actually felt more like chapters or acts in a play than just story missions. The game is broken up into 3 (arguably 4 with the concluding chapter) that all have their own antagonist, development of the pre-apocalypse, insight into this zombie plague and its origins, and how all the characters you meet came to be who they are now - from who they used to be. 

-Performance. seeing as though this is a PC port from a playstation exclusive... this ran surprisingly well for me with practically no bugs, visual glitches, or any other errors. Played on max settings and never really noticed any framerate drops, even when horde pursuits put literal hundreds of enemies on screen at once. Rarely encountered any other bugs.

Overall, i understand some of the criticism of repetitive gameplay and "filler" side content, but when you consider that this is a well written story in a technically impressive, beautiful world with 2 entertaining core mechanics (Motorcycle usage and Horde mechanic)... all made by a relatively small scale Game studio...I'd say this is a holistically GOOD game. It has flaws, but i don't think that takes away from the good experiences that some serious effort and craft went into producing. 

I hope that anyone curious takes the chance to experience this game, as i personally LOVED it, and hope others find the same joy in it that i did.

I feel like this game gets either too much praise or not enough, so I'll try to write something that matches my feelings now that I have dinished it. I know that Bend Studio isn't a huge studio so overall, props to them for this game. But I expected a bit more, even if it was released 4 years ago.

First, the pros : 
[list]
[*] Graphics : Not much too say here, they're good enough so that you can enjoy Oregon. The map is standard, with different biomes. It's not revolutionary, but it works.
[*] Gunfights : the gun feeling is enjoyable and quite realistic, I think. It's a lot harder to aim straight when you run, you have a variety of guns and you're free to adapt your gameplay depending on the guns you're carrying, which you can also easily swap.
[*] Story : In my mind, the story is the highlight of the game. It can be a bit slow paced at first, and sometimes a bit predictible, but once you get into it it gets very interesting. The characters are well written, and the writers took their time in building character developments, for the main character as well as the secondary ones. The story is engaging, and it's the main reason I kept playing the game.
[*] Zombies : the way they move, the way the detect you, the hordes (you're gonna shit your pants the first time) can be terrifying if you're too early in the game or even if you don't have enough ammo and materials on you. One zombie is fine, two or three is okay. 4 or more : YOU BETTER RUN BITCH. Very well done.
[/list]

And now, the cons : 
[list]
[*] The bike : I couldn't really decided whether this was a pro or con, but the bike at the beginning is a pain in the ass. Once you start to upgrade it it gets better, but in my opinion you never really enjoy it (the fuel tank capacity is ridiculously small, the speed is capped so you feel like riding a skateboard,...). It gets less annoying after about 20h of gameplay when you start upgrading it significantly. Also I find the driving sensations to be off, but this seems to depend on people.
[*] The sidequests : the sidequests are as boring as the main story is engaging. It's "go there, free this person" or "go there, kill these vagrants" or "go there, get this for me". And also the fact that you have a radio that is just being used to get back to camp for the NPC to tell you what the quest is about drove me NUTS. WHY DIDNT YOU TELL ME ON THE RADIO BITCH ?
[*] The animals. In this game, you will find infected animals that can move at the speed of light, attack you without any type of warning and very little possibility to survive if you're not on your bike. It's not a dealbreaker,, but it's annoying as hell.
[*] Character animation and voices. Motion capture was used for Deacon and other characters, but on all the others, OH MY GOD. The first time I met Ada Tucker, I thought she was a screenshot ! Same goes for the survivors that you free : they have no facial expression whatsoever. The voices are also very weird : sometimes the character will almost yell for no reason, and sometimes he will whisper even though he should be speaking loudly. It threw me off several times.
[/list]

Overall, I would give the game a 15/20 that will entertain you for a good 40 hours. It's a well made game for a small studio like Bend, but it lacks a bit of polishing here and there to make it great. I would be happy to play the sequel, if there is one.

With a few self-imposed restrictions, this is quite a well balanced game that gives you a good sense of progression. In the early game you're forced to stealth and occasionally flee from enemies to avoid being overwhelmed. After unlocking more weapons and skills, you become much more capable of facing enemies head on. Even though it's a zombie game, the story is not completely uninteresting, and you end up caring for the characters despite their obvious flaws. The Oregon setting is absolutely gorgeous. The game does promote certain ideologies in a few places, and it does have a few bugs, but those annoyances are not frequent or disruptive enough to ruin an otherwise fun and immersive experience.

I don't know if Days Gone is a bad game or it just not for me, but this survival-action game that is more survival than action was a total mess, with no fun at all.

First strike was the save system that frankly I still don't know how it works. It has a manual save that sometimes it doesn't work, it has an autosave system that will lose you hours of progress and a sleep system for some reason. 

Second strike is the ammo economy. OK, I get it it is a survival game, so you're not carrying tons of bullets. I get it. But it is ridiculous to clear an entire camp of ten fully armed people and have none of them drop ammo. I'm constantly with 5 bullets in the primary weapon and 3 in the secondary. Further more early in the game there is a bow for which you can craft arrows, which is great IF ONLY I could find materials for it. 

Still in the second point, the crafting and the materials are half-baked and feel unjustly punishing. The gas of your motorbike depletes way fast, the durability of some items are joke. I even unlocked the trait to repair melee weapons, but on my first repair, I used all 7 of my scrap to repair a weapon. 

Third strike was a horde of zombies that ganked me out of nowhere when I tried to get the power on in some camp. With 3 bullets, repeated failed stealth attempts and with no way to outrun them (with the unforgiving stamina bar), I had to leave it behind. And then it dawned me how the game from the very start went full punishing on me on every corner. 

The game removes fun from every aspect of its game and that it's biggest flaw. You can't explore with the bike constantly low on gas, you can't take detours, you can't fight with the atrocious ammo and shooting system, you can't run with the stamina bar depleting all the time, you can't invest in the story with all those hindrances and the bad menu system and the storyline systems that I don't know what is their purpose.

Dying Light had almost all of these issues fixed, with a fast parkour system to outrun zombies, rooftops to feel safe, an interesting crafting system with enough materials to experiment, proper (if generic) story that wasn't all over the place. 

I know that reviewers return to this game thinking it had harsh reviews, but this game while it is good at some aspects it is fun in none. May it get bitten by zombie.

This has got to be one of the best games released in recent times, at the very least for the last 10 years. It is mostly bug free. Save the game failing to load the supermarket internals on a horde hunt(part of a storyline mission) and the ending, which required me to restart the game(was falling through the map). Beyond that, no crashes or bugs whatsoever(except when Deacon would move around an interactive object a few times until it "locked").

The story is incredible. No wonder the simpleton games journalists were so angry over this game, Last of Us 2 can only dream of being something like this. 

There was one moment with a lesbian romance that felt almost akin to the season 3 of "Stranger Things", in which the character was hitting and flirting openly to the lead, and then, in the last 20 minutes of the last episode she becomes lesbian. As if an executive from Netflix came down and told them "Make someone gay, or else!".  The same with one of the characters here, she was hitting on Deacon multiple times, then suddenly, save for a few scenes, she becomes lesbian. There were even an almost sex scene with her. Felt off... 

The racial demographic also feels very much like redneck Oregon, and not like downtown or Brooklyn New York or San Francisco. It is what you would expect. 

The graphics are amazing. The rain, and the accumulation of snow, including the footsteps, gives an immersion like no other. 

No insertion of modern day politics, save for a guy who is paranoid about the government and is a good person, but in the end about half of his points were proven true(even Deacon, disapprovingly agrees in some), and the others were just moot, as we are on a zombie apocalypse. 

But the story, the story is incredible. One of the best stories I have seen in decades! 
Bromance, and the quest to find your wife. 

This is what games should strive to be today. It made me feel my own feels! Nobody does that without a good reason! And this made it! Deacon had a code, personality, everyone, from the vet who became a doctor, to a mechanic. You cared for them all. Damsels in distress, and sometimes you were saved by a damsel(something rare these days). Everyone is in the shit, and you help many, and sometimes they help you back. 

Unreal engine is known for being utterly horrible with facial animation. It is as if their facial animations were made by an autist.  There were only a few games that I know of where they did quite alright with it. Like Remnants from the Ashes, Vampyr and now Days Gone. Their eyes are touching. 

As Rikki says, "light a candle in the darkness..."

Days Gone is a game that I enjoyed playing because it offers a unique and immersive experience of surviving in a post-apocalyptic world. The game features a compelling protagonist, Deacon St. John(hot), who is a former biker and bounty hunter. He has a gruff charm and a sweet-natured personality, which makes him relatable and sympathetic. He also has a loyal companion, his bike, which is his main mode of transportation and customization. The bike is fun to ride and handle, and it requires maintenance and fuel, which adds to the realism and challenge of the game.

The game also has a stunning and atmospheric setting, which is based on the real-life state of Oregon in the United States. The game showcases the beauty and diversity of nature, with lush forests, snowy mountains, desert plains, and volcanic craters. The game also features dynamic weather and day-night cycles, which affect the gameplay and the environment. For example, rain can make the roads slippery and reduce visibility, while night can make the zombies more aggressive and numerous.

The game also has a thrilling and satisfying combat system, which involves fighting against hordes of zombies, called Freakers, as well as human enemies, such as bandits, cultists, and militia. The game allows the player to use various weapons, such as guns, crossbows, explosives, and melee weapons, as well as stealth tactics, traps, and distractions. The game also rewards the player for exploring the open world and completing missions, which grant experience points, skill points, credits, and trust. These can be used to upgrade the bike, unlock new abilities, buy new equipment, and access new areas.

However, the game is not perfect, and it has some flaws that I did not like. The game has a long and tedious story, which spans over 60 hours of gameplay. The story is often clumsy, clichéd, and unsatisfying, with many plot holes, inconsistencies, and loose ends. The story also has many missions that are repetitive, boring, and frustrating, such as fetching items, escorting characters, clearing camps, or chasing enemies. The story also has many characters that are bland, annoying, or unlikable, such as Sarah St. John (Deacon’s wife), Colonel Garret (the leader of the militia), or Skizzo (a traitor).

The game also has a dreary and uninteresting open world, which lacks originality and diversity. The open world is mostly filled with generic locations, such as gas stations, farms, cabins, or military bases. The open world also has few activities or secrets to discover, such as collectibles or easter eggs. The open world also has many bugs and glitches that affect the gameplay and the graphics. For example, enemies can disappear or spawn out of nowhere; objects can float or clip through walls; textures can pop in or out; sounds can cut off or overlap; frames can drop or freeze.

In conclusion, Days Gone is a game that I liked because it offers a unique and immersive experience of surviving in a post-apocalyptic world. The game features a compelling protagonist (Deacon St. John), a stunning and atmospheric setting (Oregon), and a thrilling and satisfying combat system (Freakers). However, the game also has some flaws that I did not like: a long and tedious story (60 hours), a dreary and uninteresting open world (generic locations), and many bugs and glitches (technical issues). Therefore, I would give the game a score of 7 out of 10, which means good according to my rating scale.

While this game does not truly deserve a negative review, I must write a negative review to showcase why this game garnered so much silence from the community. 

The start of the game is downright awful. Extremely slow pace, uninteresting story and characters and very sluggish feeling overall. This entire feeling expands into the first two playable areas in the game (2/5), an drags on for way too long. There are no major improvements coming until the third area, where the situation slightly changes for the better, bringing in decent characters, story progression with new weapons and gear. This was the first moment I truly felt the change, and started to like the game for the first time.

After area 3 (3/5), you unlock the last two areas and unlock the ability to get the best weapons and gear. This is the ONLY time where you could feel the huge improvement in progress, which was (for me) about 25-30h in...and that is waaaay too late. While new guns and gear did feel really good, they were introduced in a little too late (about 5-8 hours before the main story ended).

Story felt very prolonged. Too much cut-scenes, too much talking when it was not necessary etc. Random chats and comments were decent, but the whole flow of the story felt way too cinematic. You have no options during the story, so its going to pan out the same way every time. Also, every single story line is predictable. Not a single twist was made, and there was not a single point where something was *mysterious or unexplained, waiting to be revealed later*. You can pretty much guess how every single character is going to end up after listening to him/her for a few minutes. 

Gameplay was very repetitive - scavenge, kill, loot, move to the next mission, repeat. Missions are also very generic - find X, kill X or save X. The only missions that actually let you do things how you wanted to do them are missions near the end of the game when you have to deal with very large hordes.

Speaking of hordes, those are the best thing in the game. Lots of enemies, very dangerous, very fast. They are still mindless and easy to manipulate if you plan out your *kill box* beforehand, or if you prepare a LOT of ammo. Definitely the most fun aspect of the game.

Zombies are very weirdly placed. Variations exist, but hordes never have *stronger* zombies in them. Strong zombies are usually just scattered around the world in places you have to visit, but are VERY rarely seen in the story-lines, which was a huge letdown. I went in expecting *They are Billions* types of zombies, but what I got in the end is the same enemy with different looks and stats. 

Your main travel tool is your bike, that you will upgrade as the game progresses. However, the fast travel and multiple other activities are locked behind your fuel capacity and overall the amount of fuel you have in your bike at the moment. This made scavenging for fuel in the early game a MUST, and made some areas way too long, just because it forces you to constantly go back for gas or risk getting dry in the middle of the road surrounded by enemies. Going back to fuel capacity, you will not be able to upgrade it much until further on in the game, so enjoy long run-backs. 

Melee combat was really...weird. In the early stages, you only have a knife and it does abysmally low damage. Later on, you can craft a one-hit-stick very easily. The weird part of it is, that you cannot get these good things until you successfully find them in the area 4 and 5, or their respectful crafting blueprints.

Range combat was good. Human enemies had horrible aim tho, and rarely felt like a challenge. Sadly, once you pick the difficulty, this cannot be increased...

Overall, a very standard 7/10 zombie/survival game. Lots of minor bugs and glitches, few crashes and reloads, lots of unused content (no eating/drinking mechanic even tho meat and herbs exist, sleeping is useless outside of skipping time, items can`t be disassembled etc.) and overall a very *it was okay* feeling at the end. 

Did it scratch my zombie game itch? It did. But just gently.

There's a game breaking bug in the quest "I don't wanna hang" - about 80-90% through the game - where a scripted event may not get triggered and will thus not allow you to complete the quest and subsequently, the game. The only way to "fix" it is to load a save going back to when you did not have the quest yet, and then hoping that it doesn't break again. Several years after release, this - and a bunch of other bugs - still isn't fixed, and one of the lead devs has the audacity to bitch about players not being willing to pay full price for it. Well, your fucking game can't even be completed unless you replay parts of it to see if your shitty code decides to wake up and do what it should, you fucking cunt.

And the game is absolutely not worth replaying and regrinding a bunch of stuff just for another coin-toss script trigger. While it's not outright bad, it is largely yet another Ubisoft-style open world game, of which there are dozens at this point, and a bunch of them better than this one. Anyways, if you are still interested, here's a short bit of info:

- as stated, it is a Ubi-style open world game, but it has some of the narrative-focus/move-style elements of modern Sony games, and it does land the cadence of content fairly well, actually - especially in regards to the open world, but a few of the cutscenes and non-interactive narrative focused parts do overstay their welcome. Overall though, the content delivery is surprisingly solid and the game does much better job of respecting the player's time than most other Sony titles or Ubi-style games
- the Horde system with groups of zombies up to several hundred individuals big is awesome, fighting a horde requires some serious preparation and the tools you can use get progressively better throughout the game, but the hordes also grow larger
- speaking about preparation, the game does play pretty heavily into the whole "surviving and scavenging in a post-apocalyptic world" and though supplies are fairly abundant in the world, the amount you can carry is fairly limited - perhaps a bit too much as far as ammunition for some guns goes, but it does create a gameplay loop with proper exciting and slower moments and rewards methodical approach
- the economy balance does require some grinding, but the activities in the open world, coupled with quest rewards, are enough to buy everything - if you want to just do the quests, or the main storyline, you will be limited in what guns and bike upgrades you can buy, but not to a degree that would make the game significantly harder - most of the difficulty comes from resource management and tactics, and also...
- bulletsponges, one of the worst aspects of Ubi-style games, are here, and their impact is even worse than most other games of this type because of the very restricted resources you can carry, and by the late stage of the game, there's quests and encounters which consist completely (or almost completely) of bulletsponges, which leads to unnecessarily long scavenging or a forced trip to the base to restock
- the narrative is good, especially in the first 2/3 of the game, but it has inconsistencies and plot-holes (for example, you posses a pretty important set of information, you get told by some person that it is important to them as well and that they really want you to provide more details to them and their associates - and then nobody mentions it ever again), the characters are pretty diverse in their behaviors and attitudes, but they are nearly all unreasonably stubborn and also secretive about things that make no sense just so that later on things happen in a convenient way, and there is a considerable amount of "modern politics" forced into the story for absolutely no reason other than it being there - it's still better than MCU writing, by a lot even, but it feels like the writers took some shortcuts, or were forced to, especially towards the end of the game
- graphics are pretty good for the most part, so is the sound, and the soundtrack specifically is very good, but it does not play most of the time which makes this point pretty moot, it runs fairly well with only occasional stutters, but the game is fairly prone - as mentioned at the very beginning - to quests / scripted events breaking and the necessity to restart the game or reload saves, the physics are glitchy enemies just teleport or fly all over the place for some reason, interactions with some objects are broken and/or underbaked - for example, there is a type of open world encounter where enemies set up a rope over a road, and even if you slow down to pretty much a crawl, or touch it while turning/sideways, it throws you off the bike as if you went full speed and hit it head on, etc. 

Anyways, developers can bitch all they want, but this game is not worth its full price - it's obviously unfinished with clearly rushed parts. Was it more polished and priced as an AA game at 30-40USD/EUR, it would have been much better received and worth it. In its current rough state, it's more of a 10-15USD/EUR game - and only if you can tolerate that you will be forced to reload/restart the game semi-regularly.

[h1]Days Gone[/h1]

[h1]"We make the world what it is, by what we do. All of us."[/h1]

[h1]Introduction:[/h1]
If any of you fellas have been following my Steam reviews for some time now, you might have stumbled upon my profile & in turn seen my list of my all-time favorite games/franchises. The vast majority of them are games that I grew up with in the late 2000s & early 2010s. 2011 is still to me considered the best year for gaming. As such the latest game to have ended up on that list was The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt & that was in 2016, for the next 4 or years no game would end up on that list until 3 very special PlayStation games would capture my heart & spoil me rotten. This is the story of one of them.

Days Gone when it was first announced took people's attention straight away. At first, it might have seemed like another zombie apocalypse survival shooter & you would be right to think that way. Even I did until the developers showed us their magnum opus. The hordes mechanic, something that wasn't possible now became a reality. On your screen, you could battle from up to 100 to even 300 or more fast-moving & furious zombies! Couple that with an addicting gameplay loop, a well-written story, a diverse & expansive world, dynamic characters, & a real difficulty scale & you have the recipe for a perfect game that will be remembered throughout the ages.

[h1]The Story:[/h1]
Days Gone takes place in the post-apocalyptic ruins of the United States. A mysterious Virus has decimated the global population & turned everyone who was infected into ravaging brutes that have come to be known as Freakers. They are kind of like a mix of the Zombies from Train To Busan & the Darkseekers from I Am Legend. They hibernate, migrate, & eat anything they can slay. Any form of governance & order is long gone, what's left of the civilian population has either retreated into makeshift camp forts, turned to bounty hunting & drifting, or turned to banditry & preying on the weak. You play as an ex-US Army Soldier turned Outlaw Biker Deacon St. John, together with his fellow biker brother William "Boozer" Gray, They make a living & survive as mercenaries in the ruins of Oregon. Deacon lost his wife Sarah Whitaker at the beginning of the outbreak. Ridden with guilt, he struggles to move on, The two lads plan to head north in search of a better life and to be rid of the ghosts of the past. That is until a black helicopter bearing the NERO Symbolc [b](National Emergency Response Organization)[/b] is sighted by Deacon, NERO was the organization that was meant to save Sarah during the outbreak, with NERO being back, Deacon regains some hope that perhaps his wife might still be alive... Your journey starts here.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
● Incredible story
● Addicting gameplay
● Good blend of survival gameplay
● Unique setting
● Living breathing world
● Dynamic weather
● Steam achievements
● Steam trading cards
● Great soundtrack
● Game length
● Stellar performance
● Lots of great guns to use
● Monstrous freaker hordes
● Mod support
● Great character development
● Brutality/Gore done right
● Lots of bike parts to earn
● Amazing photo mode
● Top-notch voice acting
● Multiple dialogue language options

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
● Lack of any unique zombies
● Infuriating Survivor glitch
● Odd Weapon Crosshair Choices
● Shrinking Weapon Crosshairs
● Proximity Mines
● Proximity Bombs & Remote Bombs are wonky and glitchy

[h1]Pros & Cons Summary:[/h1]
I hit the character limit so I’m going to be leaving a Google document where I will have every pro and con of the game summarized. If you are looking for a short but informative review that gets straight to the point then the pros & cons here should explain everything just by reading the name of it. If you are looking for a more detailed reason for each con that I listed then check out the link below that leads to the Google document.---> [url=https://docs.google.com/document/d/15U6POpUI_hC_DV9tDbIEAv9fW8FsQqcLWa63D1Fi_q4/edit?usp=sharing]Link[/url]

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
When Days Gone was first released, critics & reviewers online blasted this game with tons of hate, needless to say, I was one of the people to buy into their narrative & as such avoided buying Days Gone on launch when it came out, it wasn't until my Uncle borrowed me his copy that I gave it a go after of course, my brother did first & honestly. That was THE LAST TIME I would ever listen to reviews online & critics online because Days Gone is a game made with love & passion, I f*cking love this game! The critics online who are tasteless hacks did Days Gone dirty. This is an underrated game, a downright masterpiece, and a few years from now It will be considered a timeless jewel. I haven't loved and been addicted to a game like this since The Witcher 3 and that was back in 2016. Days Gone is an incredible zombie survival game filled with an actual zombie threat, an incredible story, an expansive world, and an addicting gameplay loop that will keep you coming back for more. Bend Games totally knocked it out of the park when it comes to Days Gone but sadly due to the critics, we likely won't ever see a sequel but that shouldn't be a reason you shouldn't explore this quality game. Very few games nowadays end up in my favorite game list of all time but I am proud to say that Days Gone is one of those games to have earned a spot in my heart and my eternal memory.

[h1]Overall rating 1000/10[/h1]

In a world filled to the brim with zombie-themed games and open-world adventures, you’d think Days Gone would be the epitome of “enough is enough”. Days Gone unapologetically combines the two, warts and all, and leaves us wondering: Why even bother?

Days Gone kept me hooked for way longer than it had any right to. When I was “done” in terms of what the game had to offer, I wasn’t really done on a personal level. I needed more.
