Wow. Wow wow wow. Took me 39 hours for my first playthrough, where I took the time to clear hordes I happened upon while on my travels from place to place and tried to unlock every single gun. This is definitely one of my favorite games of all time, and almost certainly on my top 5 favorite singleplayer games of all time. It's one of the best single player experiences out there, but not without its flaws... And here's some.

!!! [[SPOILER WARNING]] !!!

- DATA COLLECTION POLICY. If you have read some of the other reviews, this game's data collection policy is incredibly intrusive. It's to the point where it's practically a keylogger. It's that bad. Turn off your wifi, and block this game on your firewall or something so your data doesn't end up getting sold on the dark web or some shit. This is my biggest gripe with this game.

- Slow pacing. You'll only deal with the same type of zombie for the first half of the game or so, then the game just suddenly picks up pace and rapidly starts introducing new zombies. The overrall pacing of the game is just pretty slow in general, but isn't really a big deal when the game is thoroughly enjoyable throughout. I never found myself BORED while playing this game, even with my gen Z attention span 

- Taking control out of the player's hands. There are many, many instances where you'll be forced to sit and watch a cutscene in order to understand more about what you're doing, the world, and the plot. While it is for the most part interesting and worth a watch, I think the game should've made more attempts to deliver information during gameplay sections, while you're still controlling Deacon. There's also a lot times you'll be forced to walk really slowly which I just found a bit annoying. But these issues are by no means a dealbreaker, just nitpicks.

- Arbitrary limitations. Upon crossing the mountains over to the region in the south, you're locked there. This makes no sense, especially in an open world game. I shouldn't be limited to one half of the map when there's nothing that stops me from going over Thielsen pass back to the north aside from an invisible wall that teleports me back whenever I try going past it. It could've been handled more creatively, maybe by establishing some checkpoint you're not allowed to go through. I just felt like this was annoying.

- Fakeout death. Boozer crashes into the front doors of the wizard mountain fortress and fucking explodes, but then he returns unharmed in a later cutscene. This genuinely had me really sad, until I completed the level and he was revealed to be alive. These developers cannot be playing with my heart like this. 

- The beautiful graphics, lovable characters and well written antagonists, great story, incredible world, fun gameplay, well-designed UI, insanely good tension building, crazy good voice acting and animations, and fucking BOOZER. What are you waiting for?!? Fucking buy this game and play it!!

Bought this on sale with very minimal expectations. Just kinda liked the idea of a post-apocalyptic open world infested with zombie hordes. It did quite surprise me though, with it being much better than any critic or game journo told me.

First of all, the world is amazing, and much bigger than I at first thought. As you progress the story you will unlock more and more locations, which are all varied in their look and feel. You got forests, mountains, dry regions, farmlands, small towns, and frozen wastelands. The lighting, color, and graphic fidelity makes it all look absolutely beautiful at all times.
As for the traversal, it's good. Riding the bike felt pretty satisfying most of the time. Driving had very nice feedback, and and felt very responsive. Though only by the end of the campaign and a little amount of grinding can you fully realize the bike's potential through customization (though it's linear unfortunately)

The combat is not too great. The shooting, although competent, doesn't have that punch I was looking for. It's decent when you're mowing down the hordes, but otherwise it's just weak (if that's the right word) The melee is even worse. The physics just aren't there, so there's barely any feedback from anything really. Just some half-a**ed ragdolls and below average gore mechanics. After weeks of messing around in RDR2, this just felt lacking (though I get that's a pretty high bar). But I must say, the animations and responsiveness of the playable character were pretty neat, though at times pretty slow (same problem with TLOU and RDR2)

The story is not a masterpiece by any stretch, but it has its moments. It's pretty slow, so some people might not like that, which I get, and it does get monotonous at certain points (especially near the end). And by the end when I saw all there was to see I kinda wanted it to be over and done with already. I did start to care about certain characters (my man Boozeman) and the protagonist, but that can't be said about any other ones, [spoiler] except Iron Mike I suppose (RIP) [/spoiler]. At times it felt like the story was rewritten and cut a couple of times, so it made some moments feel incomplete. [spoiler] Especially that "last" mission on the wizard island, and scene with the colonel. Bro what the f*** was that? [/spoiler]. In retrospect the story was decent enough for me to carry on and even start caring about the MC, so it does its job.

The map design has "ubisoft" written on it, with all the outposts, checkmarks, collectibles and etc. Not that it's inherently bad, but it does it get tedious. The random events aren't done well. They are VERY repetitive and boring. I stopped bothering with them after the first half of the game.
Personally I do enjoy opening up the map bit by bit like in Far Cry, but some may not like that, and that's understandable.

But the zombies are the main thing here. And they are great. Alone these "freakers" are pathetically weak and are barely an obstacle, (though some types can be pretty challenging if you're playing on higher difficulty), but in hordes they are truly terrifying, especially in first half of the game. I dreaded every potential encounter with them, and when I did stumble upon their nests, seeing their the filthy and bloody surroundings, hearing their collective moaning and growling in the distance, all of it coupled with a very unnerving and ominous score, it literally made my skin crawl. But like everything, you do get used to it (though they were still making me nervous, even after killing off dozens of them, maybe that's just me). But I do wish there were more bigger hordes like the one from e3 (biggest one in the game btw), since most of them are pretty small, numbering in 150-200.

Overall the game is pretty good. I barely encountered any bugs except that one time it sent me under the map, and I had to reload to an hour long save, which admittedly was annoying. But beyond that, the game runs very smoothly on modern higher-end hardware with very rare hiccups. I had a consistent 100-110 frame rate on maxed settings. Though I must mention that the game is pretty demanding of your system, and gets heated up pretty quickly. Longer your session is the more unstable it gets. For me it was approximately 7-8 hours, so I do not recommend playing longer than that in one sitting.

Anyway, let's wrap this up.

7/10

Finished main story in 80 hours on Hard II. Looking at 160 hours or more if doing NG+ and all the side-content (collectibles, stories, etc).

Overall a great experience.

Graphics and sound design is great. Though I did experience an issue with asset streaming that occurred three-four times which required game restarts (models would be stuck at their lowest quality LOD). The map is huge with neat points of interest scattered throughout it.

Gameplay on hard II started off as very stealth oriented where caution was the name of the game. Tried fighting a Newt with a plank in the first mission and that was the beginning of many deaths. As I leveled up and got better stats, stealth became a suggestion and not being cautious didn't result in instant death every now-and-then. Eventually only the largest hordes would be a challenge and figuring out how to deal with each one is the best part about the game.

One thing I disliked were the frequency of random ambushes by human enemies in the open world. Until their camps are cleared you will constantly be clothes-lined while driving down the road and have your bike destroyed by snipers on trees. I recall killing a sniper on top of a tree, then later coming back and being shot again by a new sniper who is standing over the one I shot earlier.

Deacon's aim is extremely inaccurate long-range unless a scoped weapon is used which is strange considering his military background. There is probably a game design reason for it but at times it felt jarring being sniped by revolvers from very far away while you can barely hit a body shot from the same distance (let alone a headshot). That is taking into account skills that improve accuracy. Having pin-point accuracy wouldn't necessarily be an improvement over this but I wish that accuracy would improve even more be it by skills, standing still and (or) crouched.

Main story and side stories were all pretty interesting and engaging. Though the side jobs got repetitive eventually (bounties, clear camps). Main characters were interesting and the player character (Deacon) despite his past moral ambiguity came to be very likable, his interactions with the other characters were great.

This game seems to collect data quite egregiously from your system, even if one selects the 'limited' data collection option once the game starts for the first time (there is no complete opt-out option in-game). The way this data collection is described by other reviews makes it sound like a keylogger. So if you're worried about that try following these instructions to block the game from accessing the internet: https://www.nexusmods.com/daysgone/mods/480?tab=description

That said I have also read some posts by people way more knowledgeable about this than me that have analyzed the actual activity when the game is running and they have not identified any odd behavior. Personally I chose to block the game from accessing my connection (the game doesn't have multiplayer or other online components anyway).

Days Gone, originally a PlayStation exclusive, has finally made its way to PC, and it's a wild journey through a post-apocalyptic Oregon. This open-world action-adventure game combines a gripping narrative with intense survival elements and hordes of menacing zombies.

The PC port boasts impressive visuals and performance, allowing players to immerse themselves in the hauntingly beautiful landscapes. The story follows Deacon St. John, a gritty biker searching for answers in a world overrun by freakers, the game's twist on zombies. His journey is emotionally charged, and you'll find yourself invested in his quest for closure.

Combat is a standout feature, with dynamic encounters against both human enemies and freaker swarms. The sheer size of these hordes can be breathtaking and heart-pounding. Exploring the vast, decaying world on your motorcycle adds a unique layer of excitement.

Days Gone isn't without its quirks and occasional technical hiccups, but its strengths far outweigh its flaws. If you're a fan of open-world action games with a compelling story and a hefty dose of adrenaline, Days Gone on PC is worth the ride.

Days Gone is a work of interactive art that deserves recognition for its immersive, high-quality story and characters, its clever and polished design and its ability to circumvent open-world problems and predict the player's expectations. Like other landmark games, there's a before and there's an after you've played it. 

It leaves a strong, lasting impression, and gives you a truckload of value for the time you invest in it. This game has been the ultimate zombie experience for me, to the point where I don't feel the need to play any other, ever. This is the zombie game I've always wanted, and I got it. Thanks. 

Days Gone works hard to distance itself from the problems found in open-world games, most notably with pacing and UI improvements that go a looooong way in making it an enjoyable experience through and through. 

Fun example: Last thing I did after completing the story was hunting for a Horde, so I could end this with a glorious fight. Bought grenades, crafted some traps, filled the bike saddles with extra ammo and went on my way. On some rolling hills landscape, I found my target. It was a tough fight, explosions and fire everywhere while hundreds of Freaks were running at me. Shot the last one, smiled for a moment, but then I heard a scream. I looked left and saw a SECOND HORDE running down the hills toward me, hundreds of other Freaks, no grenades or traps left, only my trusty spiked bat and auto shotgun. In the end, I won again, and that was one of the most glorious moments I've ever experienced in a video game.  

So I recommend, even if you believe you won't enjoy another open-world. This one stands shoulder to shoulder with the bests, then surpasses them.

The game can be best described as a mix of "GTA" and "The Walking Dead". 
Pros:
- Beautiful open world with lots of random events and things to discover
- Upgrading your bike and getting better weapons and skills is fun and doesn't feel like a grind
- Good story with likeable characters
- Fighting the hordes is awesome
- Well optimised PC port and beautiful graphics

Cons:
- Relatively slow start with quite a few cut scene interruptions
- Physics bugs in PC version (haven't encountered as many in the Playstaion 4 version)
- Game crashes regularly with overlays enabled (in my case RTSS)
- Deacon talks too much during game play and he comments on almost everything, I've had him talking while quest characters were talking or during the listening of a voice recorder.

I've had a blast with that game, there's little to no political rubbish pushed down your throat and the story though simple is very enjoyable. I completed the game on the Playstation 4 Pro first and then bought it for the PC again. My first play-through on PC was on "normal" difficulty and I recommend to play on a higher difficulty if you play with mouse and keyboard, because the game becomes too easy due to the better aiming and together with the "bullet time" skill you're just too overpowered, even in the end game.

Update after finishing on difficulty "Survival 2":
This difficulty as well as "Survival" is not recommended if you are looking for a fun and challenging experience. It felt more like chore since fast travel is disabled and the quests seemed to be given in a way that sends you driving all over the huge map and throws even more ambushes and encounters in your way. That may sounds like an immersive experience, but it's just not fun after a while, because the ambushes repeat themselves too often and have no impact on the game itself. This opinion might be biased due to it having formed after my second play-through, but the "Survival" and Survival 2" difficulty settings basically drag the game-play loop like an old chewing gum, so my recommendation for the best experience would be "Hard 2", especially if you're playing with mouse and keyboard. You'll still be doing plenty of fun driving on your bike with fast travel enabled, the combat is still not hard, but challenging in a fun casual way.

TLDR: This game is great. with a lot of "but"s but its still great. Total recommendation to Zombie-Fans even though everything after this sounds bad, but I had a great time. Just some thoughts on my "cons" so you can tell if you might enjoy this as well.

It markets itself as a zombie open world game and while that is technically true its not a "sandbox" game as it might seem from the way its portrayed. Its very story driven and actually quite linear even though you have the whole world to explore. The reason for me saying this is that theres always like 1-3 story missions you need to do to one side mission and just "exploring" the open world is really not worth it.

Basically youre a Biker in a Zombie Apocalype but you got a friend thats hurt and a girl thats missing and you need to find them. And the game really wants you to care because theres a cutscene every couple of minutes, theres very little "free play" and this can really clog up your enjoyment as you go from one scene to the next and have so many radio calls you sometimes have the game bug out and have you listen to 2-3 at once..... As for the free world you can raid the settlements on the side for supplies like crafting materials but it usually doesnt matter and you just run from mission to mission with going to camp from time to time to stock up on ammo and fuel. Like in the old GTA games, you never know which missions you HAVE to do vs which missions are really side missions.

And: The game is long. Like REALLY long, Its something like 30 hours to beat the main mission with a reasonable amount of side-missions but it felt like 40-50 at a time as you would keep doing the same missions over and over again. I more than once started to play one evening and played missions (!) for 3-5 hours and felt like I got nowhere as the story didnt really advance. This is worse in the beginning by the way.

Now there are only really 5 different types of missions:
1. Go somewhere and sneak to what you need. (very limited sneak capabilities!)
2. Go somewhere and kill all the Zombies (sry freakers!) there and get what you need
3. Go somewhere and kill all the Zombies, then power up a NERO station (find 2 Items) to get what you need
4. Go somewhere and kill all the shooty-back-humans and get what you need (usually with opening a bunker)
5. Go somewhere and kill the horde to get what you need.
And yes, this does get repetitive, especially when you get a new mission and you already feel you have to do at least 3 of the above mentioned to succeed it hurts cause the game draws out it length. It would definitely have been better to have a shorter Story and more (obvious) side missions to keep the pace up.  If im completing the story and I am about to have the main camp attacked or someone I care about murdered I don't care too much about a runaway at the end of the world.

The Story is somewhere between OK to good - Its very predictably and I never though "ohhh wowwww" the big reveal about 2/3rds of the game was so obvious it was painful to cringe and the ending you can tell from about 2 hours into the game. HOWEVER there are a few smaller stories in the missions and the voice acting is superb, the characters are quite likable with exceptions so I REALLY wanted to finish the story, as mediocre as it was, and its the main reason I kept going.

The big strength of the game however, is the gameplay. Gunplay feels great. Like not good, great. Every weapon feels distinct, the power-up from upgrading your gun is big enough to not feel "nice" but "wow" and you have a lot of tools at your disposal to disperse of enemies. Riding is fun and while it gets a bit tiresome at the end, it was great fun for most of the game and the constant side-things happening next to the road kept it interesting.

One downside is that my favorite part by far were the VS HUMAN  fights, meaning when they shoot back as this was well done, the AI works, gunplay is great, strategy matters as much as aiming and its some of the most fun I ever had. But these were easy, like too easy. After a few hours you get a decent pistol, a decent MP and a decent sniper and you will clear most of the human enemies without taking a hit.
One of the worst parts (to me!) is the hordes. I know a lot of people love it. Its not often in a 1st person shooter you get to fight hundreds of enemies at once but these are often hard to unfair and you need to find your "trick" to finish them. - I quickly found that the by-far best way to fight them was shooting at the big horde (you always hit since its so many) then drive your bike a bit further and keep doing that. This really took the fun out and since traps seem to only take out 10ish enemies (in opposition to a magazine of the tommy gun which takes like 30-40 enemies) traps arent worth it. Also hordes seem to never pay out meaning after fighting a horde, you have less supplies (which cant be bought but must be scavanged!) and health supplied, need to buy more ammo than you got money. 
Luckily you can skip most of the hordes in the game.

Still consumables are nice and only really replacable by scavanging so this is your incentive for the open world. However its usually not worth it with the exception of healing items (you almost always are full of them anyway) and molotovs (you need them to burn nests and you can never have enough - BUT you wont get enough anyway.) At some point (3rd map) you have to burn like 40ish Nests (which requires a molotov) and finding the ingredients to make 40+ molotovs is just infuriating. I gave up, thankfully it really didnt matter.

One thing that also stood out for me was the atmosphere: Quite often you find yourself low on ammo, low on fuel, somewhere with a lot of Zombies and just trying to survive. At no point in the game do you really feel "safe" and you start questioning every shot you take as it basically costs you cold hard cash. I loved this. The great, desperate atmosphere with few, but well-placed jump scares (few enough to be surprising!) and the overlingering desperation made this feel like a true apocalype.

So in the end you have a game with great atmosphere and amazing gunplay, thats unfortunatly quite repetitive with a well-told but predictable story.
Still its one of the best Zombie games I played so far and if I hadnt played it yet, I definitively would play it again. 

Once again: While this sounds negative, I recommend it to anyone that likes these kind of games.

I remember looking forward to this game due to the fact that it was supposed to have a story which could be affected by the choices a player would have been able to make.

What we got instead was a game with semi-coherent/awkward dialogue that at many times won't fit with preceding or succeeding dialogue... Probably because Bend crammed together whatever recorded voice-lines they had despite many of them being meant for different story outcomes. This is seemingly an issue with Days Gone because Bend evidently decided to change directions too late and go linear pretty deep into the development timeline.

What I've mentioned above becomes evident when one notices the following:

- Characters giving you specific instructions in dialogue only to then have the scripting/coding of a relating quest force you to do the opposite (going north was fully possible, but we're instead force back south),

- Characters either being rightfully or randomly hostile within dialogue (telling you to more or less to f*ck off) only to then act in an opposite manner a few sentences later.

There's also the fact that the game has a debug menu that refers to much of the originally planned content pertaining to player choice. There's also references to a cut section of the map which in itself seemed pretty planned out since it had fast travel points for checkpoints and bases along with descriptions of locations.

We're on the other hand actually given a pretty feature-rich world. The game world/map itself is pretty big and still doesn't feel empty, this is mostly due to a pretty well developed set of possible events/encounters that pertain to humans, freakers and animals. How all of this plays out is also affected by time of day along with weather/season.

I hope that Bend goes linear with any sequel to this, that is if they ever do decide to make one... It would have been nice to have a story that were as complete as the in-game world and its itself.

In conclusion:

I'm somewhat content with what I got since I bought it on sale, but I wouldn't recommend others to buy Days Gone at full price.

[h1]Doesn't Matter When You Hit The Road, Where You're Headin' Out To, But You Damn Well Better Know Where You're Comin' Home To.[/h1]
[u][b]Initial Impression:[/b][/u] I have been playing this game for 70hrs+ and still didn't want to leave the keyboard and mouse. The world is breathtaking and very ambient. The world its self will suck you in with how lonely the open road is. You get that feeling of loneliness and desperation when out there. The lighting is dynamic, the sound tracks definitely give you a chilling isolated vibe when on your bike, being on foot will give you absolute silence at times which makes you want to be cautious when out there. Also the sound of folly sound great to the amount sound effects to make the game a bit more real. The story is really entertaining and that something ive been looking forward to.
https://youtu.be/6foYrjblqvo
[u][b]Gameplay:[/b][/u] The map size is moderate, one can easily cover long distance. The bike mechanics was so good, I rarely even opted for fast travel. The character movement is slow but thats good for me cause it feels real. The game does not force you to grind all the way through the map and also there isnt any level system which makes this a perfect choice for me. Just sit back, relax, enjoy the view, feel the story and go for a ride.

[u][b]Graphics:[/b][/u] One of the best facial animations I have ever seen, every cutscene feels connected to the player. Also the colour contrast, environment details, character details, everything is perfect. The world of Day Gone feels so alive and so detailed. It's got the detail of say The Last of Us but in a huge game world.

[u][b]Open world info:[/b][/u] I love looting and crafting and that's a huge part of Days Gone. You loot enemy bodies as well as environments. From abandoned houses to schools, gas stations, small incorporated towns to farms. The landscape is varied. For instance you can use oil filters for silencers and so on.There are a variety of human enemies that range from cultists who worship the Freakers, gangs and bandits who have their own bikes and bases of operations. Then there's the wildlife like wolves, cougars and bears that stalk the forests, deserts and mountains of Oregon. There's also deer in the game world that can be looted for meat in fact all uninflected animals can be looted for meat. You also can loot berries, herbs and mushrooms that can be used for various purposes. There's also infected "freaker" animals too. Runners which are infected wolves are massive and can can keep pace with your bike! There's crows that have large nests and will swoop down from the sky to attack you.  Then there's the Rager  bears(complete with barbed wire and posts stuck in their skin) that are pretty terrifying in their own right. 

[u][b]Zombies:[/b][/u] The best and most terrifying part of Days Gone are the Freakers. They are undead zombies either. They are in fact living humans that are infected and have mutated and sleep in nests during the day and feed at night. There are a variety too that range from basic Freakers to many or variations that I won't spoil. I can't relay the terror you'll feel when you encounter  your first Horde. It brings up a level of terror that will make you want to run in the other direction! They are manageable in small numbers but a horde especially the ones later on composed of hundreds are a different matter entirely!

[u][b]Story:[/b][/u] It has a great storyline, better than most of the games that has been released currently. I've never felt as connected to a character and invested in their story as much as Deacon St.John, and will have this game ingrained in my memory for a long time in a similar way that I do with Red Dead Redemption 2. From beginning to end it is a heartwarming, gut-wrenching and epic story without compare, it's almost like I can feel everything Deacon feels all the way through, his struggles, his frustration, his pain and his joy... It all feels real in a way that no other game does.

[u][b]Message to Devs:[/b][/u] Good job Bend Studio !!! You are all amazing and I can't wait to see what you come up with next. Thank you for making us experience the awesome journey.

[u][b]Final Verdict:[/b][/u] Definitely has a replayable value. Now palying the game in NewGame+ mode and grinding the achievements. 9/10 ez.

i played days gone on steam deck over 2 years finishing the story and all side missions excluding those that can only be tackled after the end-game.

Overall experience is the best open world zombie game you can get. there are many caveats to this tho. 

it runs amazingly on deck for the most part on medium. when it shines it is the best looking game on deck. the detail in the environments is what amazed me most, the amount of weather dynamics in each region was wondrous to play through without ever suffering performance drops. later in the game many hordes become available and the biggest ones did cause some crashes, but amazingly it was minimal and solved by lowering settings. there are however many problems with pop-in and poor textures. sometimes i would have to return to a location for the relevant characters to activate.

i played the game in semi-short 1.5 hour sessions either each day, or weeks apart. luckily, the story is so simple and surface level that it was like tuning in to a lesser season of the walking dead, with lots of filler and generic characters and plotlines. however, there is lots of love here. performances are earnest and in the main cast superb, and the light storyline made the more original plotlines grab you more. 

the gameplay was mostly very fun. the tropes with tired open world design is here, lists of missions, repeated locations and tasks, etc. the biking part can be brilliant though, when the music kicks in and youre riding along against the view of a gorgeous vista, it really sells the cool factor. the rest of it has been done before, but in the case of a zombie open world game, never quite as good.

i recommend this game to anyone who has the disposable cash to spend on something that starts off generic, and blossoms into something unique, and oddly personal. novel biking gameplay mechanics melded with light survival, traditional open world mechanics and eventually novel horde missions combine to make this world, these characters, and this game surprisingly good. its the perfect example of a game not good enough to be great, but not bad enough to be just good. 

i loved my time with it and will replay long into the future with genuine fondness.

1. Graphics/Menus - 6-7/10
Decent for the price, I would compare graphics to latest Mafia game, GTAV or Red Dead Redemption 2. Menus are a bit finicky on PC.

2. Story - 9/10
This is the interesting part of the game, it tells an original zombie movie story, which has original monsters, believable science, characters and lore. I laughed, I cried, etc. This game really should have been a $50,000,000 netflix or HBO series, it really was wasted as a game.

3.  Gameplay 4/10
Repetative, you clear a number of checkpoints which advances a story. The clearance involves shooting zombie mobs, or few people who shoot back. It mostly doesn't deviate from this formula other than the rare fetch quest. The enemy AI is very poor for the zombies, you have a sound bar and if you make sound they will shuffle toward you, if you stop or enter a bush they will forget you existed. It feels like unavoidable encounters, jump scares and raw NPC numbers was increased in order to compensate for this, but it doesn't quite work. Elements of gameplay mirror Red Dead Redemption 2 (the horse is a motorcycle, crafting etc). However RDR2 had a much greater variety of quests, greater number of quests, and was more immersive. The immersivity lacks because many quests could be completed in only a limited number of ways (usually 1), and there is almost no interaction with people, outside of scripted encounters the NPCs are all hostile mobs. At times it felt like the game was originally intended to be much, much, much larger and more developed, but was cut at the last moment leading to cookie-cutter gameplay.

4. Peeve
If you discuss issues with the game in community, they do ban you.

I want to recommend it because it does a better job of the zombie apocalypse setting and semi-casual gameplay really well.

But I just can't because there are still numerous bugs in the PC port that make missions borderline impossible without restarting over and over until the bugs go away.

I was looking for a modern version of Dead Island, and I got my fix with this game - a solid, very atmospheric, keeping-on-your-toes salvage RPG shooter, with focus on action, and not some lame story (there is some but it's not dominating or irritating). And visually the game is very beautiful indeed. If you are looking for a solid, atmospheric game version of Walking Dead or a Western version of CHERNOBYL, you got it here. P.S. I thought I would never play a single player game again but this one clicked with me.

I just finished my first play through with 57.4. There is plenty more to do and plenty more things I could of done to change the main story line. I would recommend this game, but not to everyone. If you are looking for a game that you can just pick up to play quickly, I would not recommend it. If you are looking to invest some time into a game that will leave you feeling something at the end, this is it. 

Pros:
+Openish world where you are open to explore and taken the pace of the story into your own hands. (Please note that the story lines in this game are quite linear, however you can still upgrade your character while making small to medium world altering decisions.)
+Story feels rough at first, but it truly feels fleshed out and deserved a second game, or at least a book series. 
+Combat system is rewarding and punishing.
+ Worth the price with the amount of entertainment you can get.
+ Post-apocalyptic world where taking down hordes and groups of zombies has purpose. You can choose to avoid mostly avoid big hordes or take them down and reap the rewards for yourself.
+Open world aspect feels full. Various interactions throughout the open world as you make your travels.
+Which skills you chose can drastically change the course of your game play.
+Replayable. Can continue playing at the end of the main story and carry some trust you gain with locations in the world over into a new game.

Cons:
-It is a grind
-General game play is not the problem (fighting, cut scenes, social interactions, traveling), but gaining tracks through the story lines and gaining trust throughout the world does.
- Some side missions can feel tedious.
-Minor non-game breaking glitches, aside from maybe an interior building not rendering, which was rare.
-Limited affect on the open world, your actions are mostly for yourself, getting resources and leveling up.
-Saving can sometimes be funky. I have been halfway through a side mission, saved and then had to restart it.

Overall, these feels like a fun semi-open world zombie game where the story feels fulfilling and one wanting more. The overall game play is fun, however the game can feel tedious at times and it takes some time to get to know the "shit" and how to navigate it.

This game is AMAZING. Heres why:

PROS:
- The game's score is very emotional and fits perfectly to the story and vibe. 11/10
- Graphics are possibly the best in any game ive played. The atmosphere setting is unparalled. 11/10
- Story is really good. Every character I met was interesting, Rikki is love. Deacon though stoic, has enough emotion in him to keep you invested. Good length of around 30 hours of mainquest and about 50hrs along with side stuff. 9/10
- The force feedback on controllers, even on xbox series X roller is INSANE! you can feel the weight of guns, the feel of reloading individual bullets into your shotgun, your bike travelling over rough surfaces, many more. 20/10
- Gameplay loop is top notch. Guns feel great, loot, crafting, bike management, customization, enemy variety, the HORDES AI, just top notch stuff.  11/10
- Not a lot of talk goes into this, but this game has some of the best UI animations and UI work Ive ever seen, rivalling Star wars Jedi survivor. 11/10
- Perfomance is great. Even at situations where theres Hordes of size>500 running at you, there is no frame drop. 
- Map design is top notch and was lived in and alive. Some areas actually game me goosebumps when exploring. Some outposts felt pretty similar but I dont think I encountered any place that was just copy pasted.9/10
- AI is really good. Pathing, awareness, stealth, detection mechanic are all good. Zombies AI in days gone is better than most NPC AI in 2023 games(uhh Starfield, cp2077,redfall,Immortals of aveum, etc.) 9/10

CONS: (not really)

- Story, whilst good, are rigged with fetch quests. Some can get a bit annoying but these quests are usually interesting as there is some sort of purpose to it and not braindead collect this box for me, wipe someones arse for me so i will let you know the location bullshit like Starfield.
- Some checkpoints and travelling parts felt tedious since you have to travel a lot with the bike. Initial hours of fuel management can get tricky. 
- Zombie wolfs can fuck off. 
- you cant aim for half the game unless you invest into the no recoil perk and you good. 
- Half the perks are useless
- you can handle hordes only in the later parts of the game. this is connected to story but i would have liked to fight them/ have a taste at hordes at some point earlier.(you can stumble on hordes way before, but you will just die. theres nothing you can do)

NOTES about the reviewer when the review was made:
Main Story Complete, All Encampment Jobs and Infestations done. May do some horde killing latter. ~35hr to to do, but could obviously take longer or shorter (especially if you don't fail at stealth in some of the missions as badly as me) or skip more or less cut scenes (I skipped about 20% of cutscenes and dialogue, mostly dialogue and Encampment Jobs cutscenes)

Story - Above Average/Good, obviously pacing is somewhat up to the player, the only things I would've liked to see explored more is world building. The scope of all in-game dialogue and backstory isn't expanded upon in any detail. Story has a catharsis (meaning no necessary need for a sequel), but there is room to continue the story. 

Mechanics, its a 3rd person "RPG". The RPG elements are not too heavily thrust in your face, don't expect anything nearing TES/Witcher, but its there and more importantly doesn't hinder the game experience most of the time. Survival Elements are present, but on Normal aren't going to come into play that often. Controls can rarely feel sloppy and loose, but it won't happen a lot, mostly because KB+M driving isn't the same as Sticks. Gunplay is average, it won't detract (most of the time) from your experience, but in no way will it add to the experience. And Exploration is not a main feature of this game.

Port Quality, Good, coming from Playstation it plays alright, not amazing, with control support and the bare minimum of functional graphics settings. Game has some PC optimization so mid spec computers have a good chance of a good experience. Graphically won't blow you away. Lighting engine does have issues when transitioning between well light and very dark areas, but that isn't something that happens a lot, sometimes struggles with the flashlight too.

Bugs. Minimal, but there, nothing gamebreaking on my end (bugged quests), had 3 enemies fall through the world, had some wonky physics engine iterations, but nothing like getting launched above the Karman Line by a Giant in Skyrim. 


If you are on the fence about this game, the thing about this game is heavily held up by the story. I think the cutscenes alone can total about 4hr? That may attract some people and dissuade others, but that's up to you.

This game has its fair share of annoyances. It's a rushed,  piss poor Playstation port with more bugs than a Bethesda game. It is bound to piss you off bad at some point; hordes breaking missions, series of "random" bad stuff happening in a row, physics engine bugging out, VERY BAD 3D audio, you name it. Had to reload more than a few times to un-fuck the gameplay.  I played this game for 19 hours in 2 days though, great graphics, good atmosphere, great story (so far) and it really delivers on that "Drifters Life" theme.

Audio deserves a special shit-shout; effects  are great but even the good old Serious Sam games back in 2000 had better 3D audio; you hear the sound, go towards it, and the Zed that's making the noise isn't there. You hear a Horde, go in the other direction, only to walk right into it. Kinda breaks the Zombie Survival thing when you cant rely on sound to get the jump on them. 

Graphics are great and all, but they could have used some better modeling; Iron Mike's face looks like molten Cheddar, a lot of the zed look pretty much the same with very little variation. Survivors too, I saved a lot of guys trapped in cars with Zed around them, and only saw 2 different models so far. 

All in all it's good, but never worth the full price a lot of people paid after they hyped up this game so much. Good, but get it during a sale like I did.

This game, to say the least, was not what I expected. I refunded it after playing for roughly 1 hour.

Story: Upon loading in, we were in the middle of the apocalypse. No character backstory, no zombie backstory. No character attachments made, didn't really know what was going on. The main character "Deacon", had lost his wife and supposedly it was a big part of his character. I was thrust into an environment that made no sense, with no sense of immersion, and it kind of seemed like there was no forethought or extra planning for an intro sequence. 

Game play: Definitely lacking, zombies can kill you incredibly easily, and the children zombies surprisingly aren't much different (on normal difficulty). It would make sense if maybe you got an infection or something?, but no, just them slapping you 5 times kills you. A head bash hardly slows them down. Even if you're a zombie, I'm pretty sure a concussion would effect you. If you use the knife that you spawn with, your character only goes for slashing at the chest, which would do absolutely nothing, and because of this, it takes upwards of 10 seconds to kill a singular zombie, and there's never just one. You can sneak attack zombies, and that's kind of the only way to kill them (unless you're using a melee weapon, or a weapon with a silencer). You also can't pick up crossbow bolts...makes absolutely no sense. There was an enemy settlement about a minute and a half walk away from our safehouse...I'm pretty sure they would raid our safehouse instead of lounging about. All together it felt really poorly put together. There are lots of bullets and medical supplies laying about, so it counteracts some of the issues I brought up earlier, but goes along with my overarching message, poor immersion, not realistic, and overall not a very well put together zombie game, or game in general.

Graphics: Wow...graphics are TERRIBLE. The humans hardly resembled anything I've ever seen before. They honestly kind of looked like aliens, you could tell they worked harder on some face models, like the main character and his friend, but JEEZ the other people were laughably nonhuman. Not to mention I had my graphics on high, and there were little to no details shown. It was just a blurry, and for lack of a better phrase, laughable, mess. 

Listen, if you're looking for something mediocre, go for this. It's not my taste, I was lucky enough to learn all of this while I was still able to refund it, and I'd recommend you not buying it..

Days Gone has truly captured my heart and imagination with its gripping storyline, breathtaking open world, and intense gameplay. From the moment I stepped into the worn shoes of Deacon St. John, I was immersed in a post-apocalyptic world that felt both familiar and yet uniquely its own.

The storytelling in Days Gone is nothing short of exceptional. The intricate relationships between characters, the depth of emotion conveyed, and the unexpected twists kept me hooked throughout my entire playthrough. Deacon's journey from a gritty drifter to a relatable and compelling hero is a testament to the game's excellent character development.

What sets Days Gone apart is its meticulously crafted open world. The Pacific Northwest landscape is not just a backdrop, but a living, breathing entity that plays a vital role in the game. The dynamic weather system, day-night cycle, and diverse environments make every moment feel like an adventure. Whether I was navigating through dense forests, exploring abandoned towns, or racing down the highway on my trusty bike, the world always felt alive and brimming with detail.

Speaking of the bike, the motorcycle mechanics are a stroke of genius. It's not just a means of transportation, but an extension of Deacon himself. Upgrading and customizing my bike became an obsession, as I aimed to make it both functional and reflective of my personal style.

The gameplay in Days Gone offers an exhilarating mix of action, strategy, and survival. Facing off against swarms of Freakers or rival human factions always kept me on my toes, requiring me to adapt my tactics and use the environment to my advantage. The tension of scarcity—be it ammo, resources, or health supplies—added a layer of realism that made every decision count.

What truly elevates Days Gone is its attention to detail. The haunting soundtrack, the ambient sounds of the wilderness, the graffiti telling stories of the past, and the hauntingly beautiful landscapes all contribute to an atmosphere that is immersive beyond compare.

In conclusion, Days Gone is a masterpiece that deserves all the praise it receives. It's more than just a game; it's an emotional rollercoaster, an exploration of humanity's resilience, and a testament to the power of storytelling in gaming. If you're looking for an unforgettable experience that will keep you engaged for hours on end, Days Gone is an absolute must-play.

What an absolute gem of a game.

I see that it's currently rated Very Positive, but honestly, even that doesn't do this game justice. The voice-acting is some of the best I have ever heard, in any game. The animation is smooth and fluid. The story is a heart-wrenching rollercoaster that'll have you invested as soon as you start making acquaintances, The gameplay and controls are engaging and responsive. It's all top notch stuff. The fact it took two *years* to be freed from the exclusivity deal and released to PC was an absolute travesty. The fact we're not getting a sequel is nothing short of infuriating.

Some people say it's long. Repetitive. Formulaic. But to that, I have this one simple truth: All open world games have repetition, and a formula. Explore, collect, upgrade, repeat. This game has that. The story can be a bit of a slow burn at the start, if you're like me and play cautiously. But personally? I was so lost in the world and the story that I didn't even notice. The hours flew by and I was happy to burn them playing this game. In fact, I'm frankly looking forward to my next playthrough, now that I've had some time to step back, forget certain plot points, and reflect on the game overall.

Do yourself a favour. If you enjoy third person, open-world games, and are looking for a world and story to get sucked into and immersed in, get this game. You won't regret it.

I really liked the graphics and the overall feel of this game. I really enjoyed how the motorcycles were incorporated into this game. There was a lot of small details that really help immerse you in the story - your bike and footsteps makes different sounds when riding on different surfaces, you leave footprints in snow, the variety of clothing and person design, the shop owner's unique characters and conversations, and as you kill things in the game the bodies remain there permanently during the rest of your play through. 

I liked the first half of the game more than the second half as far as the story. I honestly expected there to be a bigger game shift as he learned what has happened to Sarah, but I still think the story ramped up and resolved itself nicely.

Critiques - 
The jobs did get a little repetitive if you try to complete them all, but I also didn't play on hard modes so I suppose I set myself up for things to be easy and potentially boring in that regard. 
It would have been interesting to have to build trust with individuals instead of camps as a whole. I would have preferred that you didn't have to level up trust with camps to purchase things. I always had way too much money compared to what I could buy or wanted to buy. This was the best game I've played in a while. I love a storyline that I can sink my teeth into. And I even almost shed a tear once or twice. To be honest, I wasn't excited at all about this game. I thought it was just another cookie cutter zombie game. If it hadn't been on sale, I may never have experienced it.

   I found the main character's personality a little annoying and immature at times, (actually a lot of the time) but I guess that means that I was vested in the story. This would be a great limited series or 3 1/2 hr movie. There are a lot of missions to tackle, but they are done in a way that didn't get too monotonous or tedious. Most of the tasks were to go clear out a camp, or go rescue someone from bandits, or go find guy that did something bad. And you could very well get ambushed or sniped off of your bike at about any time while cruising down the road. One thing you might notice tho, it's the same dummy every time during those random encounter rescues. The controls were a touch wonky at times, like trying to jump on my bike wasn't always a seamless operation and can really frustrate you while trying to make a very quick get away. 

  Good graphics, very smooth performance, engaging story, well acted characters with actual personalities blended with enjoyable missions and goals made this a really good time for me. And there seems to be a lot more to do, even after I've finished the main story. 

  Overall I give this game an 9.

This is in my top five games of all time! I'll come back to a lot of the things other reviews talk about, but one thing that I didn't see enough discussion of is the emotional depth of the characters. So many characters I started out feeling one way about them and as the story unfolded ended up feeling the opposite (for better or worse), even the main character. Bend studio had some really advanced facial tracking mechanisms that I've never seen so well developed throughout the course of any other game. You pick up on how characters are "feeling" with small facial cues that we are adapt to in every day life and this adds a new dimension of emotional context to the story line. In a world of video games having weird and unrealistic relationships the relationship between Deacon and Sarah feels very natural and special despite how it lacks a lot of overdone tropes in story heavy games. My first play though took 102 hours (insane!) and I didn't complete everything. It is a very very very slow burn, but it is absolutely worth it. The game mechanics are pretty cool and allow you to play a stealth or shoot em up style with stealth being more of a requirement at some of the more extreme difficulties. I toyed around with some of the extreme difficulties and was pleasantly surprised how life like they were since many stealth or action games feel far flung and still catering to the player on harder settings, but Days Gone doesn't do this in the slightest. Lastly not enough can be said about what it feels like to be running for your life from 500 freakers/zombies at a time, they all are operating independently and  are trying to kill you. I've played a lot of horror and action games, but never have felt so engrossed in the action as when trying to kill a horde of freakers. Definitely not just another zombie game, multiple interviewing plots. pretty good open world, great game mechanics, and a really fun crafting/learning curve
Outstanding game! The writing, cut-scenes, characters are all top notch, and combine well with solid gameplay to create a surprise open world masterpiece.

I almost didn't play the game. From it being originally a PlayStation game (I have the console) to it crashing on startup. The latter was a weird wireless headset issue with the SteelSeries Arctis 7 which was solved by unplugging the receiver and playing with a different headset (thanks to IcarusV2 on reddit for the help), and the former was me just being silly about [i]where[/i] I play certain games.

Fortunately I was able to play the game, and was treated to a really good game about zombies and survival. Surviving the dangers of zombies, mankind, and my own self. Driven by his mission to find his wife, Deacon sets out and starts a chain of events that would both rock the game's world and stir some emotions. Love, loss, betrayal, this game's got it all.

Things I liked
[list]
[*] The game is gorgeous, with a vast open world full of (natural) life.
[*] The motorbike is not just a means of travel, but a part of you as Deacon. You can go places without it, but you won't last long.
[*] Keeping your motorbike fuelled is also a neat little bit of resource management.
[*] The story, while not the most engaging, was quite a memorable outing in video game fiction.
[*] So many weapons, and you can craft melee weapons which can be devastating.
[*] So many zombies at once. The hordes are not to be trifled with.
[*] The stealth missions are fun.
[*] The crossbow made me feel like Daryl Dixon from TWD.
[*] Even a lot of the side missions were fun to do, and I did feel very compelled to complete most of them.
[/list]

My nitpicks
[list]
[*] Dealing with the hordes was actually my least fun bit of the game. It's a little tedious, but I'll admit it was the conflict of my Serious Sam "run backwards and shoot" instinct which doesn't work in a 3rd person action / adventure game. Perhaps I'll go see on YouTube how others played through those bits in the game.
[*] The random encounters in which you can save some civilian NPC's are sometimes so unforgiving in their timing. Even if I notice the marker on the mini-map and immediately try to go to the ? icon I would still be too late to save them.
[*] Deacon sometimes takes his sweet time to get on the motorbike, even when there are hundreds of zombies rushing at him.
[/list]

Overall, if zombies are your thing, you should give this one a try. I'd give it a good 7.5/10.

[i]Days Gone[/i] was pleasantly above my expectations, but it does itself a disservice by having a very slow start. Give it 4-6 hours to really get moving, as characters gain depth and nuance the more you spend time with them.

It's the little touches that make this game great. The voice cast and animators went all-out on this game, and it shows. Your main character Deacon st. John reacts as people shoot at him, curses and complains when he has to fight zombies, freaks out when in danger. He is not a stand-in for the player, he's the star of a show that's about him and his relationships with others(foremost being his biker buddy Boozer, a real ride-or-die bro) as he recovers from the aftermath of an apocalypse.

I have only two complaints with [i]Days Gone[/i]. One is the slow start. Quite a few abilities should have been something you start with instead of unlocking such as Focus(which lets you slow down time and aim for headshots) and the skill that lets you outline enemies with your batman:arkham-esque find item vision. 

The second is the challenges and requirements to 100% the game. [i]Days Gone[/i] is not a particularly hard game, even on its higher difficulties, but the challenges are really grindy and having to beat the game a second time on a much higher difficulty(even with all your gear in New Game+) was more of a chore than a satisfying swan song to finishing the game.

[i]Days Gone[/i] is definitely worth your money and time, even at full price.

Don't listen to other people when they tell you this game gets better. It's very true to life in that it never gets better.  If you're <2 hours into this game and you have even the slightest feeling of being bored, stop playing and request a refund.  What you get in the first couple hours of this game is the exact same stuff you're going to get for the next 57 hours of the game.  Nothing will change.

The story is unoriginal and predictable.  The love story is overly sentimental as if they were written by someone who has never been in love themselves, but learned about it from fan fiction.  What's worse is that you're forced to watch them.  Watch them walk.  For what must have been the length of a marathon at a half mile an hour.  I'm fairly sure that 58 hours of my 59 hours of playing time is just watching scenes where people have to walk.

The game is repetitive and bland.  I entertained myself by saying "ooh piece of candy" every time I picked up a resource.

There comes a point where you keep playing because you think that the game has to be over soon...right.  But it's not.  It just keeps going, the same things over and over.  It's not possible to be held hostage by a video game, but this made me wonder "...or is it..."

I'm convinced that the developer ask their ten year old nephew for their best idea of a tough guy and Deacon is who that child came up with.  I actually really like the actor who plays Deacon, he's a talented guy who I feel was wasted on such a one-dimensional character.  There were moments, though, when the face acting wowed me.

Two nice things I will say about this game.  The environment is beautiful; it's what caught my attention in the first place.  The motorcycle has the best motorcycle mechanics I've experience in a game.  I usually dread having to use a motorcycle in a game, but this one was actually fun.  If the point of this game was to ride your motorcycle around and look at trees then A+++ they nailed it.  But after a few hours even the motorcycle riding gets tedious, especially when you're on your way to do that same thing you did 20 times before.
This game is an absolutely underrated masterpiece, one of the best zombie games ever made, period.  It's a shame there won't be a successor.

When I was thinking about buying this game I saw a big conflict between a whole lot of reviews, particularly from when it initially released, saying the game was just a kinda mediocre open world zombie game, and the steam reviews that were saying the game was amazing. As a lot of people will say, the first few hours are slow and it certainly feels like just another open world/survival/zombie game. But after a while you realise it does something a little different. My biggest complaint of red dead 2 is that the ai is entirely brain-dead and the combat is is a paint by the numbers hoard killer. Ironically, for a game all about killing hoards, this game escapes that trap. In even the shootouts with human enemies, snipers will sit at the back and shoot from cover while people with shotguns and bats will charge you, the guys with assault rifles will lay down suppressing fire and they'll flush you out of cover with molotovs. While I'm not saying the combat is quite as tactical as an out and put tactical shooter, it's better than most third person shooters at this. And that's not the main draw of the game. The zombie hoards are fun to fight, require a bit of a plan and execution and for you to use your entire arsenal. The game is also pretty and runs great on a steam deck. It's not the most original game you'll play but it executes what it does well. After the first few hours anyway.

I'm fully aware how little sense it makes to write a review after a mere 40something minutes of game, but I'll refund the game, and maybe I'll help someone along the way with it. So here we go:

- It's abundandly clear this is a console port, like so many games nowadays. On the plus side, the game didn't crash within 15 minutes as is often the case. But god do I hate the controls and ...pacing of movement. Even on highest x axis sensitivity, turning around sees you dragging your mouse halfway across your desk. Movements are very sluggish and feel unresponsive, but I suppose this is deliberate (eg Witcher 3's fluid motions to, say, Mass Effects slow execution of movement) just like aim assist and thelike. Couldn't get a feel for how great the Vehicle controls are as WSAD are just on/off switches, but ok, I willingly don't use a controller. Other games still did that better. This feels so very console-gamey in a bad way, in my opinion. From the driving to walking to shooting; all is a tad sluggish and lacks crispness. It feels like a game where you constantly stumble into enemies you can and can't see.
- I did not care at all for the story (and the prologue is all story), dialogues, characters. That's not a good sign; the worst feeling towards these narrative elements one can have is indifference in my opinion, and that's all I felt, and not because the game doesn't really give you a "why" to everything in the beginning; plenty of games do this and have me hooked from minute one.
Wish I liked the game better, there might be something for me hidden in there after more time, but my time is too precious to try much more.

After investing four hours into "Days Gone," I must admit my growing sense of ennui. The game's core mechanics constantly push players towards scavenging to craft essentials, a task made tedious due to the protagonist's limited carrying capacity for resources and ammunition. This incessant search for crafting materials can feel repetitive and breaks the momentum.

The narrative, although not entirely flawed, fails to stand out or grip the player. The prologue is particularly dreary, with restrictive gameplay elements. Players are often forced to sit through action cutscenes rather than actively participating. And when the gameplay finally unfolds, it mostly revolves around mundane and lackluster tasks. The pop-up progress notifications that can appear out of the blue further disrupt the flow, sometimes intruding during intense action sequences.

One particularly vexing gameplay element is the frailty of melee weapons. It's baffling to see something as robust as an axe breaking after a mere ten strikes. This necessitates yet another tedious search for a replacement weapon, hindering combat fluidity.

Day-to-night transitions in the game are poorly executed. Distinguishing between dusk and genuine nighttime becomes a challenge, often leaving players looking up at the sky to differentiate between the sun and the moon. The lack of an in-game clock or watch further complicates matters.

Interactions with objects, especially cars, can be glitchy. Even when an interaction prompt appears, the action sometimes fails to register unless the player perfectly aligns with the item. Numerous other discomforting elements plague the user experience.

In summation, "Days Gone" was a disappointment for me. It's reminiscent of "God of War" and "Horizon" in gameplay feel, but it lacks the polish and finesse of those titles. Instead of recommending "Days Gone," I'd steer players towards "7 Days to Die." Although it doesn't offer a central storyline, it shines as one of the most engaging open-world zombie games available.

I heard very many positive things about this game, exclusively from people that played it on a console.

I personally found the porting of the game to the PC to be very poorly done.  The main problem being that a major part of the game involves upgrading and riding a motorbike.  That in itself is not a problem, the problem is that the motorbike cannot be steered with the mouse.  Steering is done with the keyboard, which by definition are on/off switches and so don’t provide the subtlety possible with a mouse.  I did get myself a console controller to see if that would help, but being a died-in-the-wool mouse and keyboard player of several decades I found the learning curve too steep, and life too short to be bothered.

There is also the minor niggle, which seems to be fairly common with console games ported to the PC, that when restoring a save game it is often restored at some point earlier than when the save was made.  As a long-term player on a PC I found this rather peculiar.

In terms of £s per hour of enjoyment: this is by far and away my most expensive purchase ever.

Abstract:
This game has a lot of good stuff but sadly there is just an unbelievable amount of frustrating gameplay.

Pros:
- Epic story.
- Great characters.
- Hordes are really impressive.
- Cool gunplay with satisfying headshots. 
- You have a focus meter that when activated slows down time.
- Great graphics and animation.
- Great sound.
- Great world design.

Major cons:
- You cannot drive your bike for two minutes without having to refuel.
- Fast travel is limited by how much fuel you have.
- If you run out of fuel, you're going to have a bad time.
- You cannot drive 30 fucking seconds without some out of nowhere bullshit knocking you off your bike: freaks, snipers, wolves, whatever. No, you do not see them coming. This shit happens so often you are going to say out loud "fuck this game".
- All of the above tremendously slows down game progression.
- Close combat with knife takes forever to defeat an enemy.
- Some missions are hard, and if you go in unprepared you are going to have a bad time.
- Better not miss those fucking NERO sites or you're going to have a bad time.
- Close combat weapon has 20(!) hits before it breaks. If you don't repair before that, the weapon is lost and you need to find a new one.
- You can not switch difficulty mid game. I chose hard and I had no way of checking if the bullshit I had to put up with was the difficulty or the game.

Minor cons:
- It can sometimes be hard to find the loot you need.
- I completely missed the point of health/stamina/focus cocktails. I guess they give a boost or something, but I never noticed, and the entire game I was not able to get ingredients for even a single focus cocktail.
- You can not skip end credits.
- Imagine an evil colonel in a post apocalyptic setting running a militia doing leftist virtue signaling in a speech and welcoming transgenders. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ To be fair this is a single incidence in the story but it completely takes out of the experience.

Other notes:
- The music is good except for the few shitty melancholic songs.
- The game is mostly stable. There were a few bugs where I had to restart the game.

Conclusion:
All in all this is definitely an impressive game, and it is really sad to see the frustrating parts ruin the overall enjoyment - of which there is still plenty to be had. Considering the amount of effort that went into this, it feels like it would have been a relatively small thing to fix. If you are prepared to put up with it then I would say give it go. Be warned, your patience will be tested and hopefully it is not as bad on lower difficulties.

There’s no way most these positive reviews are real. The story and acting isn’t bad, the voicing could be better, but it’s so damn repetitive. Passing by a zombie nest every 20 seconds? “Gotta finish burning these down!” Refilling your bike that ran out of fuel in those 20 seconds? “I really needed this.” The MC just says the same lines over and over. The story missions have crazy-long cutscenes, then some slow walking, and maybe a fight scene. 

Wanna progress the story? Go to this location and you’re done. Go shoot this guy and you’re done. Cutscene time. Then there’s stealth. They try to advertise it as an option to the player through the o’brian missions, but it’s just painfully difficult to sneak in free roam (especially when there’s zombies near) and not get seen/heard.

In the combat, you’re just slicing and dodging- that’s alright, but the dodging is horrendous. You aren’t just moving out of the way from the enemy, you’re shoulder-rolling 3 meters (wish i was joking) in another direction, probably into another enemy waiting to hit you. 

Honestly, having an actual dodging combat mechanic would have kept me entertained, considering i mostly got this game from its selling point (the motorcycle and open world) and wanting something similar to TLOU.

It is not similar to TLOU. I wouldn’t want to get this game if it’s above $15, and am gonna mod the holy hell out of it to try and have fun.

Originally downloaded this game because it reminded me of one of my favorite games from the 90's, Full Throttle, the story of Ben Throttle, leader of the Polecat biker group.
But, Days Gone has been so much more than that game. It may not have quite the DukeNukemest humor Full Throttle had, but it more than makes up for it in original game play. Yes I am aware that there are so many great games that you have to story and fight your way to better weapons, better add-ons, better enemies, but this zombie-kick-butt genre game is so addictive. In fact, that might be the only downfall...I spend far too much time playing rather than writing...my actual job.
I will just leave the reader with this, how many games have you played recently that are so effective in lighting, game weather, sound, that when it starts to rain, you can smell the steam coming off the heated pavement? Yeah, that kind of game.

I would give Days gone a solid 7/10

The environment, immersion and tension are amazing and sometimes blew me away. The way the game handles bike upgrades and gun upgrades is great and hordes are an amazing mechanic which I wish the game introduced you to earlier and more often. The adrenaline rush this game sometimes hits you with is both frightening and thrilling.

However, the game has some issues. Movement is not always as smooth as can be causing some frustrating moments when your life is on the line. Furthermore, audio mechanics are not always great either and can really disrupt your immersion due to voices being unreasonable low in moments where it just does not make sense, sometimes ending a tense moment in disappointment.

Still a solid 7/10 due to a great story and great graphics leading to good immersion in many moments. I did not regret playing this game!

I'm going to keep this review as short as I can, I like this game. I recommend you buy it on sale.
However be prepared to be left on a cliffhanger on what happens next in the universe as Days Gone 2 is not confirmed and some time has passed, however there now seems to be hope for the sequel so many of us want. Cliffhanger aside the story is good, if not a bit too repetitive sometimes with the ambush camp and kidnapping stories.

It bothered me less over time, but for a zombie game focusing heavily on vehicles, in this case motorcycles only there is obvious lack of knowledge of the entire mechanical part. The team(s) that made this obviously had no idea what they were doing which is sad, and ruins the game in some ways. Customization was also a bit disappointing, but not bad. While I love that this game focuses on my favorite thing in the world (motorcycles) it is also weird that it's the only vehicle used in the game aside from two small exceptions, but you can't use those anyways. I'd expect cars being used in a zombie apocalypse and not motorcycles. Our character and his best friend are bikers so for them it makes sense. 
 
Anyways overall a 8/10 game for me with the problems it has. More work into this game before release, with some more motorcycle knowledge this score could easily be higher. A sequel will definitely have potential as I think the story will be very interesting.

This game is pretty good. Similar to the newer tomb raider games (gather resources, hunt animals, etc), but that's mostly a secondary grind. Combat is fun and the visuals and voice animation are great.

Good:
The game has clear mission goals, and you can fast travel to most places.
Combat is pretty fun and you can level up to make it better.
Voice acting and plot/cutscenes are smooth.

Bad:
Weapon ammo is type specific, meaning that green shotgun ammo from the guy you just killed doesn't work with your blue shotgun, etc. It's realistic, but pretty stupid for a game. You always need to buy ammo for your guns, which is cheap later on but annoying at the start. And switching guns often removes all ammo for other guns... and you can't pick up ammo for guns not currently in your inventory. And you can't save guns you pick up; only guns you buy or unlock are available in the gun lockers.

The game saves are inconsistent. During missions, even if you "save" you might wind up repeating a lot when loading.

There are several areas where you slow walk, which is pretty annoying in general, but tedious in some cases like following skizzo in the mines (with zero dialogue, just slow walk...)

Other comments:
There are quite a few guns, and the shotguns are fun, but if you actually want effective weapons it's all about the amount of bullets you can throw out. Clip size and rate of fire are all that matter... so the boring guns are what you'll mostly use, unless you like switching guns constantly (losing ammo on the way).

It feels like you need to farm camp xp/credits. If you don't care about getting every item before endgame though, the camp missions will take care of both.

This is a very weak recommend. It's got some good parts, but is unnecessarily bloated and janky, suffer from a slow start and does not stick the landing.

I felt right from the start that the open world game mechanics were kinda whack, the way the character controls, the aiming, the enemy combat animations, the arbitrarily applied restrictions on movement, the repetative side mission structures, the constant continuity errors that occur as the game tries to juggle the non linear progression of multiple simultaneous story lines, the camp trust system, the completely superfluous foraging system, the poorly executed random encounters, the nonsensical wildlife AI, the pointless collectables... I mean, all of it is half borked jank. 

The story started out very slow and meandering, and the characters felt at the same time one dimensional and inconsistent. But something compelled me to keep playing, and towards the mid game, it actually started getting kinda good. The character development started kicking in, and the story actually felt like it was going somewhere. I started appreciating (or at least accepting) some of the mechanics more as I learned how to work around the jank. The bloat was still tedious, and the writing was still shoddy, but character motivations became clear and things were moving in an interesting direction.

Unfortunately, as I opened up the last area, the game hits a turning point where the already spotty story and writing started going south for real. If the characters had been verging on one dimensional and inconsistent before, at this point they just completely fell off the edge. The writing became so juvenile and cringy as the character motivations dissolved into arbitrary contrivance that I just could not care about the characters or their interpersonal drama anymore. It still had a few good moments after this shift, but it got progressively less engaging as it went along, and by the time they rushed for the wrap up, I was kinda thankful that they were rushing it.

The game spent so much time having you run copy pasted errands, only for the ending to feel so rushed and sloppy. Some of the most interesting plot threads, around which a good chunk of the midgame was based, just fizzled out and instead we got the most by the numbers type conclusion possible, cringy ending speech and all. It's a real shame, because it actually felt like it managed to stumble into a kind of Joss Whedon-esque charm with its janky writing and was building up to something good there in the mid game.

I maintain that the game would have benefited immensely from leaving out all of the busy work that they added in just so that they could justify the open world, and tightening up the scope and narrative a bit. I'd say about two thirds of the game could just be done away with, and instead they could have spent their time polishing up the final act. If done right. we'd have an excellent 25 hour game rather than the mixed 80 hour game we got.
