Just imagine everyone left in the world chooses to ride a motorbike for some ridiculous reason when there's obviously cars available, even the people who had likely never been on one before; it's now their main mode of transportation.  It makes no sense and makes the game feel like some bad SoA ripoff, and I was not a fan of SoA.

The characters, and voice acting were very weak imo.  The story somewhat makes up for it but even that definitely has it's own problems.  The zombies are varied and interesting but there are definitely way too many of them just milling around in the middle of nowhere it makes just driving around feel like a chore sometimes, and boy are there chores.  Thank fuck for fast travel and SSD is all I can say about this game.

Really the only thing that kept me playing was the environment, just cruising around the lakes was usually more than enjoyable enough for me.  Ran very well on my rig @1440p 3700x/2080ti.

6/10 If you're a masochist.

[h1] Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5) [/h1]

[h1] Likes: [/h1]

Engaging Storyline: Days Gone weaves a gripping narrative that keeps players invested from start to finish. The emotional depth of the characters and their relationships adds a layer of authenticity to the post-apocalyptic setting.

Vast Open World: The game's open-world environment is stunning and expansive, offering players a diverse and immersive landscape to explore. From dense forests to desolate highways, every location feels unique and adds to the overall atmosphere.

Dynamic Weather and Day-Night Cycle: The ever-changing weather and day-night cycle create a dynamic and immersive experience. Survival in this unpredictable world becomes a thrilling challenge.

Intense Survival Gameplay: Days Gone captures the essence of survival in a dangerous world. The need to scavenge for resources, manage fuel and ammunition, and strategize against hordes of terrifying Freakers keeps players on their toes.

Motorcycle Customization: Deacon's motorcycle is not just a means of transportation but an extension of his character. The ability to upgrade and customize the bike adds depth to the gameplay and personalizes the journey.

[h1] Dislikes: [/h1]

Technical Issues at Launch: Upon release, Days Gone suffered from some technical glitches and performance problems. However, the development team diligently addressed these issues through updates, improving the overall experience.

Pacing in the Early Game: Some players felt that the game's pacing in the early stages was a bit slow, taking time to build momentum. However, the story and gameplay later pick up, rewarding players with an unforgettable experience.

Repetitive Side Missions: While the main storyline is captivating, some of the side missions may feel repetitive in structure and objectives.

Limited AI Variety: The enemy AI, especially the Freakers, could have been more varied in behavior to provide additional challenges and strategic depth.

In conclusion, Days Gone delivers an enthralling journey through a post-apocalyptic world, combining a compelling storyline, vast open-world exploration, and intense survival gameplay. While it had some initial technical hurdles, the development team's dedication in addressing issues and providing updates has resulted in a polished and memorable gaming experience. If you are a fan of the zombie survival genre, Days Gone offers an emotional and action-packed adventure that is well worth taking.

*(Probably no one gonna read my review but it's ok, I write for my passion and I'm happy about it)*

The whole game is amazing, set in a post-apocalyptic setting, Days Gone takes players to a pandemic that has wiped out most of the world's population, turning humans into creatures known as Freakers.

Graphics are the first impression that catches my eye, it is so beautiful, many scenes look like real life scenes. The developer takes advantage of the ambient occlusion technique very well when combined with objects such as rocks or trees, helping to reproduce "extreme" scenes, very deep in the surrounding space.

The weather system is also a visual hit in terms of graphics as well as a real-life feel. Effects such as wind, snow and especially rain all have a very clear interaction with the environment of the game screen, creating a very real and cinematic space feeling. Sometimes I thought I was watching a movie instead of playing a game. 
Those who like to be photographers will love the game's Photo Mode, which provides a lot of tools for shooting settings such as angle of view, negative, aperture, etc. game. Perhaps there are few games this year that impress me in terms of graphics like Days Gone brings.

An other impressive point is the number of story-based missions quite a lot. That's not to mention the series of familiar things that you can do in the game's sandbox world such as crafting, collecting materials for this purpose from abandoned houses, or old cars drying in the sun. day and night in the world of the game. Use them to create bandages, Molotovs, bombs or even to repair cars or melee weapons for survival purposes You can drive your bike around the environment, use it to teleport, Quick Save and much more.

During my experience, I felt that Days Gone is a game about driving a motorbike around everywhere, sightseeing, learning more about the main and supporting characters, performing the assigned tasks. It's such a wonderful feeling, the more story i played, the more interesting details and twists, helping me gradually discover a complete picture of how the Freaker disaster happened. It's not a completely new story, but the emotional episodes and the cast of characters in it, with the support of talented voice actors, give the game a depth of content. impressively.

After all, Days Gone offers an engaging open-world survival experience with an unexpected storyline, interesting cast of characters, and extremely impressive graphics. The biggest minus point of the game is probably the plot plot happens quite slowly, requiring players to be patient. Not to mention, the repeating mission system may be a minus point for some players, but in fact, very few open world games on the market can overcome this minus point. The important thing is still the feeling of experience that the game brings and the developer has done a good job of this factor

My playtime: ~45 hours (main story) + 8 hours (100% All side quest) = 53 hours Total

Days Gone is a surprisingly good game with a slow start. It probably has the best character writing and the most overall cohesive story writing in any game I've played. 

I was expecting a thin, pointless story and a bunch of zombies to kill. This game has several recurring themes in it that are subtle, but are continuously played with and picked apart during story missions. The characters really took me on a ride. I changed my opinion of about half of them as I got to know them. Sometimes I changed my opinion back later. A couple of them even changed my mind about events that took place in the game. In a world where most video game writing make no sense, the characters and dialogue in Days Gone shines above the rest.

Unfortunately, the story doesn't really pick up until you hit the third zone. The first two zones are meant to be somewhat aimless because that's how the character is at this point in the story, but it doesn't come across that way to the player until after they've played latter areas and realized this was intentional (if they ever did). Somewhere in the third zone (where the story/writing picks up) is also the point where you'll probably start to get tired of the game play. 

If there was more depth to the game mechanics and the story was just slightly shorter/more refined, this probably would have been a home run. As it is, I still highly recommend it.

My word, Sony don't half hire some fine ass developers, what a job they have done to bring the best zombie game out there, it's by far the most enjoyable open-world zombie survival game and there's quite a few out there that fail to the simple things, it's built from the ground up and the end result shone through from all the hard work that was put into this game.

The one thing that shocks me for this franchise, is they won't be making a sequel, the reason behind this was it didn't make enough money. Grab this game however way you can, it'll bring you joy and an experience I don't think I've felt before, well worth the asking price!

GAMEPLAY:
The game is set in post-apocalyptic Oregon two years after the start of a pandemic that turned a portion of humanity into vicious zombie-like creatures. Former outlaw-turned-drifter Deacon St. John discovers his wife Sarah, having been assumed dead, may still be alive and goes on a quest to find her. 

Days Gone is played from a third-person perspective in which the player can explore an open world environment. Players can use firearms, melee weapons, and improvised weapons, and can use stealth to defend themselves against hostile humans and cannibalistic creatures known as Freakers. A major game mechanic is Deacon's motorcycle, which is used as the player character's main mode of transportation.

Steam 2023 Yaz indirmlerinde çekine çekine aldığım bu oyunu yaklaşık 23 saat oynadıktan sonra bir inceleme yazmak istedim. Oyun basınından duyduğum olumsuz görüşlerden dolayı oldukça önyargılıydım. En fazla 2 saat denerim beğenmezsen iade ederim diyip aldım ve bu kadar saat sonra oynadıktan sonra oyunun aslından neden beğenilmediğini anlayabiliyorum.

Aslında oyun o kadar kötü değil ancak bir Play Station Exculesive bir oyun olarak yapmaması gereken hatalar yapıldığını düşünüyorum. PS’ye özel bir oyun olarak çıkıyorsanız yapacağınız işin çok iyi temeller üzerine kurulmuş ve iyi cilalanmış olması gerekmekte. Ayrıca oyunun çıkışında olan performans sıkıntılarından dolayı da ekstra kötü oldu. Şu oyun herhangi bir Ubisoft oyunu olarak bütün platformlara çıksaydı bugün bu kadar olumsuz bir tabloyla karşılaşmazdık ve 2. oyunu da beklerdik. 

Yapılan hatalara gelecek olursak; ilk olarak oyundaki açık dünyanın ele alınış biçimi senelerdir oynadığımız ve artık sıkıldığımız tarzda. Haydut kamplarına git, temizle ve ödülü kap gibi gibi. Oyunda bazı kamplarla ilişkilerini yükseltmek için yaptığımız yan görevler de biribirinin aynısı. Git şunu öldür veya sağ olarak yakala. Açık dünya ile alakalı yapılan güzel şeylerden biri zombiler. O zombilerin peşine düştüğü bir sekansta gerçekten diken üstündesiniz. Hele de bir sürüye denk geldiyseniz vay halinize diyeyim ben size. 

Oyunun yetenek ağacında çok gereksiz şeyler var. Hatta bazıları neden var falan diyorsunuz. Yol silah sallanmasını azalt, afetzede görüşünün alanını gelişlet, yok eşyaların ekranda belirme süresini uzat gibi gereksiz şeyler var.

Animasyonlar senaryo cutsceneleri hariç çok özensiz ve bayağı. Bazı oyun içi animasyonlar akıcı değil. Daha doğrusu cilalı değil. 

Şimdi bu kadar olumsuz şeylerden bahsettikten sonra oyunu beğendimi söylesem? Yani 100 lira gibi bir ücrete hiçte fena bir oyun değil. 🙂 Haklarını vermek lazım oyunun zombi istilası senaryosunu atmosferle güzel desteklemişler. Kamptan adım attığınız anda güvende olmadığını hissini çok iyi vermişler. 5-6 zombi aynı anda gelince eliniz ayağınız bir miktar dolaşıyor. Hatta bir sürüye denk geldiyseniz ölüm ekranını görmeniz çok olası.

Zombi istilası konseptini seviyorsanız oynamanızı öneririm. Ancak elit bir deneyim istiyorsanız başka oyunlara bakmanızı tavsiye ederim. Kötü oyun değil ancak PS Exclusive olacak bir oyun kesinlikle değil.

There is a lot to love about days gone but throughout my play through i struggled to decide if i liked this game or not, and i think i have figured out why.

Days Gone has a lot of ideas, really really cool ones such as the hordes, the biking, exploration, crafting and what not, but i was always feeling that every idea was half baked.

For Instance:
-Hordes: The hordes whilst being visually impressive, don't feel as dangerous or as complex as they should, I never found myself finding interesting ways to efficiently take down a horde compared to me just running and gunning. I also feel like the hordes being stuck to one place (understandably however due to balancing) just ruins the threat of them because i know ill be safe as long as i avoid those areas. A good improvement would be if smaller hordes could be found wandering around the map.

-The Bike: The Motorbike is a critical element to days gone, not only is it essential for survival, but it is also a key character element of Deacon. Or at least its meant to be. I found myself seeing the bike as just a way to get from point a to b rather than a tool i can make use of. The upgrades for the bike are lacking admittedly, as much as i would have liked to see offensive upgrades, non such exsist. The upgrades that are there are just bare bone performance upgrades that i only found myself purchasing for cosmetic and competition reasons rather than a actual need for them (excluding the fuel tank). I feel like this game would have benefited from having bike customisation akin to vehicle customisation from Mad Max.

-Exploration: Whilst the map and scenery of days gone is admittedly gorgeous and there are a lot of interesting looking areas, that's all that they are, good looking. Nearly every building in days gone other than ones used in missions are soulless. There is almost zero environmental story telling which caused me to not be bothered exploring areas that didn't contain an upgrade or something akin. Buildings don't contain secrets you can find or weapons that you can use. Everything looks great but feels empty.

-Crafting: Days Gone has the base of an excellent crafting system, but barely utilises it. 50 percent of the time, an item you pick up is only used in one crafting recipe. The weapon crafting is super cool and is reminiscent of dead rising or dead island/dying light, but it left me wanting more. Another problem is you get multiple crafting recipes for say a baseball modification, however, there is no difference in how crafted weapons operate other than damage, so there is no reason to craft other weapons blueprints than the meta. 

-Combat: Contrary to most reviews criticising the combat. I personally really enjoyed the ranged combat, especially against human enemies, Its simple but effective and is boosted by the surprisingly excellent AI. Its the melee combat which i have a problem with, you would think a game about a biker would have good, in depth melee combat right? wrong. The Melee combat just comes down to attack spam, roll if they dodge an attack and repeat. There are no combos and no environmental combat, and the underutilised weapon crafting doesn't help it at all. A lot of the melee skill points are also rendered useless due to you unlocking 1 - 2 shot melee weapons pretty early on. As much as i hate to reference mad max again, the melee combat is that game, is sorely missed in this one.

Now onto things i did enjoy.

-Story: The story in this game is very underrated. It is understandably not for everyone due to it being a very slow burning and grounded story, but i feel like this allowed me to appreciate every aspect of it. I wont go too much in depth as to avoid spoilers but the only thing i wish was different was the biker elements of the story, its seems like deacons background is brought up only a handful of times and is never properly explored. It would have been nice to have deacon go against rival gangs from before the apocalypse and fight old rivals. That aside the story is very good tho it does require a good amount of time dedication due to its length (It took me 36 hours to complete the main story!)

-Atmosphere: The visuals in days gone are incredible, It seems to perfectly capture the setting its based in and honestly kind of makes the end of the world pretty. From thick forests, to snowy mountains, to dry landscapes, this game has it all. 

Summed up this game is carried by its story and visuals. There is definitely fun to be had in the game play loop but it can quickly grow stale and irrelevant. I cant say days gone is a masterpiece, its far from it. But there is the base of something very very fun. Perhaps Days gone 2 (if it happens) can see the ideas in this game fleshed out, and my lord would that be one hell of a game. 

Final consensus: Mad max but with daryl dixon

I have over 300+ hrs on PS4/5 and have finished the game around 6 times and now I'm on my first PC-run. One playthrough takes around 80 hrs.

To me this game is a 9/10 but I play it so much so it's basically 10/10. If I'm objective I would say it spans from 7-10.
You must judge Days Gone for its budget. Days Gone had a much smaller team than TLOU and HZD. In the last 2 years before release they got help from HZD-devs to finish it up and they scrapped a lot of content and made changes which are the reason some stuff feels unfinished. But it's just minor things really. Hopefully, the mod scene will be able to restore and recreate some of the cut story content. 

+ On PC there's no loading times with a decent SSD.
+ Very scalable so it's playable on potato PCs!
I play it in almost locked 60 fps in 1080p full screen but I set "Scale" to "70" so it's basically 720p but with HUD in 1080p. The 1080p HUD looks great on my 4K TV so no need for native 4K.  
Graphics setting is custom and low-high on various settings. There's a great metering tool in Graphics Settings that show's in real time how much load the CPU/GPU has, so you can easily set the game to reach a locked targeted framerate  
with an i5 8400 + 1060 3GB  
+ It has full button layout support for A LOT of controllers so you can get the proper button layout
+ Photo Mode is crazy and in PC-version there's an option to capture in up to x8 times the current resolution! However, Photo Mode captures are stored in another folder compared to normal screenshots. And if you use a controller such as DS4 and would like to be able to take fast snapshots you have to set it up to take snapshots with the Share-button somewhere in Steam Settings.
+/- PC-version is a bit easier since you get access to a few upgrades earlier for free. Also you get too keep your mag upgrades in NG+ compared to PS4). 
+ Mod support which I will delve into later. I definitely recommend playing it without mods on your first playthrough.

DEFINITELY play Days Gone with a controller and I recommend the DualShock 4 because:
+ When you ride the bike, you use the analogue L2 and R2-buttons to brake and throttle dynamically which won't work if you play with a keyboard
+ The shooting/difficulty is not that hard compared to other shooters, and the game difficulty was designed for a DS4!  
+ It has better vibration than DualSense IMHO!
+ You can quickly go to map by swiping right on touch pad, check upgrades by swiping down etc. 
+ Make sure to activate Gyro Aiming and set it to a low number to be able to fine-tune aiming when sniping enemies from far!

My 2 extra pro-tips:
1. If you want to know where a nearby enemy is (it must be witihn a certain distance): 
Open Photo Mode > Press R3 on DS4 (sorry don't know KBM-settings) to switch character focus. 
It's good both for knowing where they are, and to take very cool photos! 
2. The shooting in this game might make you frustrated. Never shoot an enemy that is in melee range since the game basically nerfs your gun damage. Be sure to crouch to get more accuracy (smaller reticle), stop moving aim to get smaller reticle (more accuracy), use focus and do only head shots. And don't spray with any weapon, one shot at a time.
... for more tips, see The Days Gone Subreddit

Join the Days Gone Subreddit and Discord to get help and advice and definitely try listen to the excellent fan-podcast "The Days Gone Podcast" which has superbly made interviews with the directors, the cast, developers, fans etc, talking about a lot of things from different perspectives and it really helps explaining a lot of questios and making the DG-experience much more fun!

Ok, that's all for now.

Overall I would rate this game a 9/10. I got it on a sale and put it to the back of my playlist for a while but i was shocked when I started playing it by how interesting and fun the game actually is. 

[b]STORY:[/b] Its heavily story based with cut-scenes upon cut-scenes, so if you do not like that you probably won't like the game but the narrative it tells and the whole story in itself is really good. When I first started playing the hook did get me intrigued but the game did seem quite slow to begin with. I was fine with that but i didn't really get into the game until about a 3rd of the way in, in my opinion, that's when the story really became interesting, The characters are surprisingly well thought out and they have lots of flaws which games don't usually show off. You wouldn't say that any of the characters are truly "good" people, but that makes you like them even more. I found myself getting really attached to some of the people in the camps and wanted to protect them rather than being forced to through gameplay. The ending has a big twist at the end too which caught me off guard, but I really liked it.

[b]GAMEPLAY:[/b] The gameplay feels good and it doesnt get boring as youre progressing through the game. I like that you can get upgrades for you bike and can get better weapons and also get rewarded for completing the side quests rather than them being there just for lore. I have 100% completed the achievements so I can say the game doesnt have much replayability. In my experience I did enjoy playing through the game a 2nd time to complete ever sidequest and storyline but after that there isnt really much of end game stuff to do. There are a few storylines and loose ends that get tied up but other than that i dont really find any merit or enjoyment out of playing the game more than twice. You do have the challenges to complete but once youve completed them i didnt find much fun in doing them again. 

Overall, the game is very much worth its price, it has a surprisingly good story with atleast 1 good replay of the game. There are different ways to play the game which is rewarding in its own light (E.g. stealth or guns blazing) and each feel well worked and valuable to use in any situation so you can have any kind of playstyle you like. The game gives you a lot of freedom and allows you to complete stuff at your own pace as well as the collectables and lore are great additions to the game. I would highly recommend this hidden gem of a game.

I'm just going to be honest playing this game is a slog. This game has some of the slowest animations I've ever dealt with. Swing a weapon yourself as hard as you can and you'll see the animations are at least 20-25% too slow even if they were going for more realistic animations. Even games like dark souls which is all about being intentionally clunky has faster melee attack animations than this game.

The weapons also have the durability of wet toilet paper, hell, that's an insult to wet toilet paper. At least you could hit someone with that quite a few times rather than only being able to take down 2-3 zombies with it. This was one of the first things I stopped playing and instantly modded out of the game after the epilogue. I have no idea why game devs do this and it instantly reminded me of Dying Light 2.

I actually did not mind the motorcycle or other controls too much but damn this dude can't aim for ****. Bro, a gun is point, click, shoot. Why are you swaying so much?!?!? This game makes it as hard as possible to be stealthy. The crossbow arrows also have a drop rate that is practically 4-5 times Earth's gravity. The entire point of a crossbow is to give you the same strength as an actual archer without needing to be one. It was essentially like the invention of the gun, it was created and had the function of making it so less training and skill would be required to use the weapon yet, it feels like you're shooting a friggin bow. Just go look at pro-bowmen competitions. They aren't shooting or even angling in the air to hit a target even 75 feet away from them because the arrow has that much velocity. I can go on and on and on about how stupid and how fast these bolts drop. I swear I am also staring at the arrow and it's hitting their head and not counting as a headshot either. The hitbox has to be jacked up.

The skill tree is also not even remotely innovative. I took one look at it and all it does it make the game slightly easier. That's it, and that's all you're going to get from the skill tree. This looks like one of the easiest "stay at level one and complete the game" challenges someone could possibly do because the skills are just that meaningless.

I actually don't mind the story or the build up at all. My main gripe is the mechanics of the game are horrible. Hell if I play tested the game for the devs I would have mentioned these things right away and that they needed to fix them for the game to actually be enjoyable. No, this is not dying light where you should be able to swing your weapon willy nilly, but am I some fat dude who can't do anything to save his life? 

Oh and don't even get me STARTED on that god forsaken non-existent stamina bar. Even my fat ** can run for a good 2-3 mins and I have asthma. This dude can only run 5-10 seconds. How the hell is he even still alive? This game is just frustrating to play. I'm not even looking for a power fantasy, just a game that is enjoyable to play and experience. If we take dark souls as another reference, the game itself is actually rather fair most of the time. It's not even frustrating to play you just need to pay attention and adapt. I've never played dark souls and thought "that was really unfair!" My thought was almost always, okay, I screwed up, I need to do X here, this enemy is here, etc. Here I feel like I'm playing a tub of lard who can't do jack right and somehow is one of the last survivors in a zombie game. Around 40 hours in I can safely give a review. I'm not done with the game, but here's my impression so far.

NARRATIVE

Days Gone is like The Walking Dead the way it should have been made. The first major part of the game has by many been described as "boring", but I honestly don't understand what they are talking about? There is a huge shift 2/3 into the story where the narrative "jumps" and goes from great to absolutely amazing. This part would not have the impact without the first part.

Days Gone is like a TV-series where you need the background before going forward. 2/3 into the game the narrative is remarkably secretive about what the fu*k happened to the world. You only know it was massive and very, very quick. The first 2/3 of the game is all about surviving in this world and figuring that world out. It is 100% a great way of doing it.

The fact that the game seriously don't spoil anything 40 hours in is amazing. A very unique style and a bold decision.

CHARACTERS

The protagonist is great, has a sense of humor and good friends. Most of the side characters are awesome, and when you get to the various "Twists" you really feel for them. There are certain points in this game I find absolutely amazing because of the characters. The writing is so darn good it just hits you like a ton of bricks.

GAMEPLAY

The gameplay is very reminiscent of a mix between
- Far Cry 5
- Horizon Zero Dawn
- FEAR (in a minor way)
- Mad Max

It uses the open world looting, base camp takeover and has its own "horde" mechanic which it kind of "saves" to later even if you can do them early if your really want. The ammo count feel balanced, the upgrades great and just the number of things to do feel balanced whereas in for instance Far Cry 3 it feels a bit bloated (too many friggin camps in that game).

The mix between shooting, using melee and various items is great - but again there's no real uniqueness to the style, but that is perfectly fine. If you have played the aformentioned games you will feel right at home.

There is a crafting system for the motorcycle which reminds me a lot of Mad Max, but done in a much better way. The general crafting system is really good and I never feel that I have "too little" stuff. I like the fact that each camp has its own credit system and uniqueness with motorcycle and weapon upgrades. It means that you can safely upgrade your weapons without fearing that you will run out of money for upgrading your bike.

PERFORMANCE and GRAPHICS

I play this game at Max settings with a 3060Ti. It runs flawlessly, 60 FPS all the way - very similar to Horizon Zero Dawn. It has similar mechanics of "Stealth" like hiding in bushes like Horizon. The game looks fantastically beautiful and the locations are very fun to explore - made better with the collectible upgrades and collecting items for crafting.

FLAWS

The upgrade mechanic has one minor flaw which is that items collected and carried double at a specific upgrade point, there are no steps in between like there is with the motorcycle. 

I also don't like that getting that "level 3" trust level at camps is so damn hard. It does feel like a game that would be cool in a New Game+ mode (and, yes, there is such a mode). I've done every side quest and didn't reach that point yet in any of the camps.

The bike's fuel tank is severely limited, but gets much better by the end. The fueling tanks don't run out though and always spawn at the same location which is a much better system than in Mad Max. The layers of upgrades for the bike feel very well balanced and I never have too little cash to upgrade, it's all about the "trust level" requirement and I never feel bad for buying the rather cheap ammo for the weapons.

There are a bit too few weapons and you can only "store" the weapons you buy, not the ones you loot. The good weapons are locked behind the trust level system. This mean that I still only use 2 sets of weapons so far in the game (40 hours in), again I do look forward to a New Game+ just beacause of that. The weapons I have along with the crafting are damn good though and fun to use. 

VERDICT
I'm yet to dive deep into the final part of the game, but damn... this is one good game, one of the top 5 open world games I've played and should be enjoyed by everyone!

The writing is so amazingly good it surpasses any writing of any game I have ever played. The length is great and I will most likely be around the 65h+ mark when all is said and done which is very good value for the €16,49 I paid on Summer Sale.

The fact that IGN/Gamespot gave this game abysmal ratings is F**king travesty. This is one of the best games I have ever played.

At one of the enemy camps there is a pass through a mountain that got blocked by untextured terrain, a similar thing happened in a rescue mission where whenever i would enter the enemy fort I would get trapped by a literal cage of untextured terrain. I fixed both of these by verifying game files, the blocked off tunnel came back a while later but once again I verified game files and it was gone for the rest of my playthrough. I also had the floor not load in one of the last missions, but I fixed that by saving and loading again. I also only had 1 game crash my entire 50 hour playthrough which is pretty solid.

Days Gone gets a somewhat lackluster rep for its flaws, but if you can get past those... it's a good game.
It's a mix of Mad Max and World War Z with even a dash of The Last of Us. 

If you're reading this and those reviews, chances are you're wondering if this game is really for you, so I'll start by naming the negatives, if any of those are deal breakers, you may want to pass.

-Story is poorly told. It's not that it's a bad story, it's just so poorly told that sometimes you kinda laugh it off. Thankfully, it eventually picks up. But at first, I thought it was gonna stay awkward the whole game long. Not to mention how few characters manage to keep your attention. Even the protagonist seems to be completely oblivious to the fact he's screaming his head off half the time. It can and will break immersion. 

-Early on, the game will feel like you're out of everything and barely getting by. While later on, you'll feel like you could take on an army on your own. The early game can turn off impatient players and the endgame may turn off players that liked the survival aspect of the game. But if you can stick it out, you may find yourself enjoying the ever increasing challenges.

-The bike is both a pro and a con. I did enjoy having the option to fast travel, save anywhere I wanted, and to carry extra ammo on it. I did NOT, however, enjoy forgetting the refuel and ''walk'' my bike for 15 minutes, but you know, I should have filled my tank up.

The pros; well it's everything else. 
-The gun play is good and feels right, though I gotta admit it seemed that the reloading key did not always register.

-The bike controls feels right. Kissing a tree at full speed does not.

-The exploration is rewarding enough, from recovering permanent upgrades, finding survivors and sending them to camps for big trust points.

-Graphics are nice. Like MG V nice but with lots of greens. You'll see enough variety in the landscapes that it'll never feel repetitive. Weather will also have a decent effect on how everything looks, and unless I'm nuts, I'm pretty sure that the roads every so slightly change as you progress through the story.

-Hordes are also... ''nice''. Why were they not introduced earlier on in the game is a mystery to me. It's a major part of the game and some players must have lost interest of 2/3 of the people by that point.

Get it on sale if you're not sure.

Overall I would recommend this, especially on sale. Great PC port from Sony, runs extremely well and smooth with lots of options for customising the experience on PC. If you like zombies and open world games with some crafting/scavenging/survival elements then this is an adventure worth having. The main character isn't great, but overall I don't mind the story too much, even with some of the biker stereotypes which I usually don't care for. It is good enough, nothing incredible, but definitely enough to be interested in seeing how things play out.

Gameplay is really where this game can shine at times though. Hordes of zombies. Fixing up your bike + finding fuel for it. Stealth approach vs. humans is very possible. AI is "not terrible". Lots of good set pieces as well as emergent gameplay moments where everything comes together perfectly. 

The setting is also an extremely beautiful world, taking place in the Pacific Northwest / Oregon, it is not the most typical place for zombie games but it suits this one perfectly. The developers and art team really did a fantastic job with the world. One of the better open worlds I have played in.

I'm not so sure this game was worth the full asking price on release, probably for some people. I am only 7 hours in at this point but it feels like the game is finally "coming into its own" now. Bit of a slow start but by hour 4-5, once you're out in the open world and have finished off the tutorial missions, it becomes a great laugh with some pretty intense moments.

Bit of a learning curve at the start, but once you are accustomed to it you may want to play on Hard if looking for a challenge as Normal gets rather easy once you've upgraded the character a bit and have a good handle on scavenging, crafting, and knowing what weapons to use at what times.

A solid 8/10 for me.

EDIT after 72 hours:

WOW! Over the past few weeks I have become addicted to this game's gameplay loop. And it can be a LONG game if you do all the missions available (main story missions + camp missions + nests + ambush camps + bounty hunter + NERO checkpoints/research sites + hordes). I am not done the story yet, but am definitely very close to it now. The more you play this game, the better it gets. I mean, once I complete the story, I do not see myself going for New Game+ or anything, I have a lot of other games to play, but what I mean is the first few hours the game is very iffy, then hour 5 - 15 its like "OK, this actually is pretty great and oooh I want this upgrade and that gun and more stamina to fight hordes etc." hour 15 - 30 you get to the 2nd map and realise how much more there is to the game. hour 30 - 45 you get a 3rd map, which I did NOT realise existed (I had heard people speak of a "2nd map" which presumably actually is this one, the 3rd map, it took me over 40 hours to get to it and I thought when the first map opened up more that was the 2nd map haha! Wow. By hour 45 I realised what a package this game really is, and how long it is playing the way I am playing. Now, I have finished the main story and almost all of the side content except some hordes and the NG+, which I don't think I will bother to do, it was a great game but I am done with it for now at least, maybe pop in to it once in a while to take down a few hordes though! The story ended quite well I thought, it kinda got better and better as it went on. It started out ROUGH, but by the end I was enjoying it a lot. 

Now I change my score:

Days Gone has mediocre mission design that's carried by the beautiful world, writing, and pacing. The game's set in the pacific northwest in an open world setting where you travel on your motorcycle between camps. The world design, paired with the fluid motorcycle controls, leads to unforgettably scenic moments. The most impressive feat of Days Gone is how you truthfully only do one type of errand/fetch quest on repeat for the entire game but it's still fun and interesting. Hordes are the highlight of the game and you encounter them in various environments, from pitch black caves & mines to a farm & city. Your motorcycle can be upgraded and utilized similar to the car from Mad Max (PC 2015), and the game includes a "Challenge Mode" missions which if you complete to Bronze/Silver/Gold score level which each add a patch to your vest in-game for increased stats or bonuses. The story is a slow burn at first, but once it picks up pace it's some of the best writing and character design of this genre.

[h1] Days Gone - 2023 review [/h1]

Days Gone is an open-world zombie shooter who lets you play Deacon, a biker looking to survive, and hopefully find his long-lost wife. Dive into the landscapes of the pacific Northwest with your motorcycle, help your fellow survivors, and live to see another day. Here's a detailed list of the pros and cons of this game, which I've fully completed, and whether I recommend it or not.

[b] Pros [/b]
[list]
[*] The graphics are beautiful and super immersive, and there's a particular attention to details. It's without a doubt one of the best looking games I've ever played.
[*] The gameplay is also great. The guns feel snappy, your arsenal is varied and interesting, there's different types of enemies, riding your bike feels smooth, and the hordes, although difficult, are balanced.
[*] The soundtrack is amazing. It suits extremely well the game and the overall situation you're put in.
[*] The performances were great 99% of the time, hitting high FPS (around 90-100) with graphics maxed out. I was definitely impressed, even though I have a high end rig, since the same level of graphics can be found in Cyberpunk and I barely hit 60 fps while playing it. [/list]

[b] Neutrals [/b]
[list]
[*] The story is decent, but it plays a little too safe in my opinion. It's not a bad story at all, and it gets pretty emotional here and there, but since the game revolves around key narrative points that are mostly predictable, it can get a little boring at some point. The ending felt straight out of a Walt Disney movie too. The characters are however really well developed and easy to get attached to.
[*] The level design is also decent. Even though the world is beautiful and diverse, there's no core locations that really stands out, aside from the camps. Unless you're killing the hordes or grabbing the collectibles all around, there's no point in exploring that much.
[*] While the zombies are programmed perfectly in my opinion, the human AIs can sometimes leave a little to be desired in some cases. It wasn't a burden enough to put it in the [i] Cons [/i] though. [/list]

[b] Cons [/b]
[list]
[*] The game has quite some bugs. I was wondering whether I would mention this in the [i] Neutrals [/i] instead, since they are mostly minor bugs, but given the fact I've had to restart my game and reboot a save three times in total due to quests being bugged out, or being attacked by invisible enemies, it was annoying. I've encountered a numerous amount of bugs, and although the majority of them aren't terrible, they can break your immersion easily.
[*] The game drags on and on, until it feels too long. The story takes around 40 hours to complete if you're focusing the main quest, and the pace was a bit too slow for me. But this isn't the main issue: the side quests are. They're tedious, extremely repetitive, and they try to fill a void created by the somewhat empty world, but miserably fail to do so. I've played a lot of Ubisoft games, known for their terrible side quests, and I can say confidently that Days Gone also stands on that level.
[*] Following my last point, fully completing this game is also incredibly boring. It's mostly a ''grab collectibles, complete bland side quests'' formula, taken to the extreme, since it can take up to 70 hours to reach full completion for your first playthrough (you also need to do a NG+ in the hardest difficulty to unlock all achievements). I wasn't a fan of it. [/list]

[b] TL;DR [/b]
A beautiful zombies open-world with satisfying and impressive third-person gameplay. It has its issues, and it drags on for too long in my opinion, but it is still a rewarding and fun experience overall. If you like zombie shooters similar to World War Z or Left 4 Dead 2, you'll most likely enjoy this game too, but I cannot guarantee it will be for everyone.

[b] Rating: 7/10 [/b]

Days Gone is an exceptional game that instantly captured my attention with its post-apocalyptic world. From its stunning visuals to its gripping story line and immersive game play, it's a masterpiece that deserves high praise.

 The graphics in Days Gone are breathtaking, showcasing lush forests and desolate urban areas with remarkable detail. The open-world setting allows for freedom and exploration, making every excursion feel like a genuine struggle for survival. The dynamic weather system adds realism, intensifying the sense of danger lurking around every corner.

 Playing as Deacon St. John, a tough bounty hunter, we dive into his personal journey through this cruel world after the pandemic. The narrative skillfully weaves together the themes of survival, loss and redemption, forcing players to be involved from beginning to end. Well-developed characters and emotional narration made an indelible impression.

 Combat in Days Gone is intense and satisfying, especially when facing hordes of zombie-like creatures known as Freakers. The game offers a variety of strategies and weapons, allowing for adaptability in different situations. It's a thrilling experience that keeps you on your toes.

 One of the aspects that really distinguishes Days Gone from other games in this genre is the connection that has arisen with Deacon's motorcycle. It goes beyond simple transportation, becoming a reliable companion in the midst of chaos. Customization options and attention to detail make the motorcycle look like a lifeline, symbolizing survival and freedom in a harsh world. These unique relationships give the game depth and emotional attachment.

 While the cancellation of Days Gone 2 is disappointing news, it doesn't take away from the incredible experience the first game offers. Days Gone will forever hold a special place in my gaming memories. If you haven't played it yet, I highly recommend immersing yourself in this thrilling post-apocalyptic ride.

P.S. Have a nice game to everyone :)

Days Gone is an exceptional game that seamlessly blends heartwarming storytelling with a dark and immersive open-world experience. As a former console gamer who has transitioned to PC gaming, I am grateful for the opportunity to enjoy the Port. However, I would love to see more titles  ported to PC

From the moment you step into the shoes of Deacon St. John, the game's protagonist, you are engrossed in his quest for survival in a challenging post-apocalyptic world. I won't spoil any surprises, but the main story is incredibly fascinating and kept me engaged from beginning to end.

The gameplay in Days Gone is undeniably badass. The highlight is undoubtedly the exhilarating hordes of zombies that you must face. However, it's not a task you can simply jump into. You must progress through the main story, improve your skills, and prepare strategically to take on these terrifying masses of undead. The experience of facing a horde is heart-pounding and demands both courage and intelligence. Few other zombie games come close to delivering the sheer terror and intensity that Days Gone offers.

What sets Days Gone apart is the perfect blend of stealth and action. You have the freedom to choose your approach to combat, and the game rarely forces you into a specific playstyle. The developers have skillfully crafted a balance that avoids the frustration often associated with forced stealth sequences.

The music in Days Gone is exceptional, enhancing the emotional impact of the game. It wisely uses songs with lyrics sparingly, reminiscent of the approach in Red Dead Redemption 1. The inclusion of Lewis Capaldi in the end credits is a delightful surprise, as his talent as a singer adds an extra layer of enjoyment to the game.

Days Gone is an incredible game that has found a special place in my heart. While it may not be suitable for those who dislike open-world repetitiveness, the core story and the thrill of zombie killing make it an outstanding experience. The character of Deacon St. John is morally ambiguous and realistically portrayed, fitting seamlessly into the post-apocalyptic setting.

The game's landscape is beautiful, weapon variety is terrific, and the enemies are diverse and challenging. The hordes in particular are terrifyingly realistic, reminiscent of the zombies in World War Z, with their ability to climb over one another and fill doorways and hallways. The bike riding mechanics are satisfying and fun, although occasionally a bit slippery. While some minor bugs and occasional crashes were present, they did not detract significantly from the overall enjoyment.

Days Gone's PC port is well-executed, running smoothly for the vast majority of the game. Occasional frame drops and stutters may occur, but they are infrequent and do not significantly impact the experience. The game's quality and immersive gameplay make it well worth the purchase, even at full price.

In conclusion, Days Gone is an underrated gem that takes a few hours to find its stride but quickly becomes an extraordinary experience. The progression of the player, the bike, and the weapons is noticeable and rewarding. The setting is stunning, voice acting is excellent, and immersion is top-notch. Although the game has some flaws, such as certain unappealing characters and a slow start, its positives far outweigh the negatives. Days Gone tells a tale of loyalty, brotherhood, and staying true to one's values, making it a truly remarkable game that holds a special place in the hearts of many players.

Pros:

    Noticeable player progression, empowering the character and the bike.
    Beautiful setting, immersive world, and impressive voice acting.
    Exciting gameplay combining stealth and action.
    Engaging story with twists and turns, centered around a morally ambiguous protagonist.
    Satisfying bike mechanics and a wide variety of weapons.
    Terrifying and realistic zombie hordes that provide a unique challenge.

Neutral:

    Gas management can be tedious at times, but it adds to the realism.
    Resource distribution feels unbalanced, with some being overly abundant while others are extremely rare.
    Crafting system and commerce are a bit inconsistent and underdeveloped.

Cons:

    Some characters may not be well-liked by players.
    The game has a slow start and could benefit from trimming its length.
    Early game weapons lack excitement and may feel underwhelming.
    The drip feed of content can feel too slow at times.

Despite these minor gripes, Days Gone is an extraordinary game that delivers an unforgettable experience. Its flaws, although present, do not overshadow the game's overall quality and the enjoyment it provides. I highly recommend this game to anyone seeking a thrilling third-person action story set in a post-apocalyptic world filled with intense zombie encounters.

My first playthrough was a great experience - fantastic story, good amount of content to find, the graphics and the soundtrack. A very compelling and addictive open world game. 

Now, the NG+ has actually exposed to me many aspects of the game which I find annoying and poor. I would like to list them out very briefly in hope that a sequel will be a huge improvement and will take it on another level. And I do want to see and play a sequel, I believe Days Gone deserves not only a sequel but several spin-off titles based on the same zombie franchise. 

So, my main complaints about Days Gone are the following:
- the number of interactive keep-going-forward type of cutscenes: I'm a true hater of such moments in any games and I strongly believe that a game is a game when you actually play it, not when you are forced to follow another character or drive them on your vehicle, being forced to listen to some dialogue (even though the game allows you to skip all cutscenes and some in-game moments as well like the Copeland's radio speech). Those moments when you simply have to go from point A to B and then from B to C (and cannot leave the area because otherwise your checkpoint reloads) might have been not such an issue during my first playthrough, but they are a real pain in NG+ and I hate them. The same goes to the retrospective stories with Sarah - the game is forcing you to follow your GF, pick up 3 flowers for her in like 6 ft area or in another "mission" you only drive her around, that's rediculous. And there's no way to skip that, no matter how much you want to. This stuff is for movies, not for games, and I just don't want to play an interactive movie with no decision/action elements, just holding the joystick forward, this should be rather a cutscene to watch. 
- infinite amount of fuel during the interactive cutscenes: whenever one of those moments during which all you have to do is to drive to point A happens, your bike for some reason stops consuming fuel and the fuel consumption icon disappears. This breaks immersion in my opinion and confirms the fact that all you're supposed to do is to participate in an interactive cutscene, just following another character with no option to do anything else like refueling.
- lack of interactions with deeper waters like lakes: this is actually something I'd love to see in a sequel, and doesn't mean I need my character to swim. I just would like to see some vehicles like boats, kayaks or pontoons with a good reason to use them (e.g. to avoid some dangers on the road or to get somewhere faster). 
- lack of character customisation. 
- glitches (which game doesn't have them, right?): occasionally I'd encounter a raider who just got  idle on his motorcycle, sitting and not driving. They wouldn't react to me shooting at them, nothing. That happened only during my NG+ playthrough.  

Overall I truly recommend this game to everyone and I did enjoy every hour spent playing it. I'm especially a big fan of any dev who can create an excellent product without X number of DLCs or payable add-ons.

An Epic Journey Through a Post-Apocalyptic World

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

Days Gone is an absolute masterpiece of a game that left me enthralled from start to finish. Bend Studio has crafted an unforgettable experience set in a post-apocalyptic open world that kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire journey.

The storyline of Days Gone is a rollercoaster of emotions. As Deacon St. John, a former outlaw biker turned survivor, you're thrust into a world overrun by Freakers (zombies) and various factions fighting for control. The narrative is expertly written, filled with compelling characters, and features numerous twists and turns that kept me engaged from the very beginning. I felt a genuine connection to Deacon's struggles, his search for his missing wife, and the choices he had to make in this unforgiving world.

The game's open-world environment is breathtakingly beautiful and diverse. From the lush forests to the desolate highways and abandoned towns, every corner of the map is meticulously designed and teeming with detail. The dynamic weather and day-night cycle further enhance the immersion, creating a sense of realism that is second to none. Exploring the vast landscape on Deacon's trusty motorcycle is an absolute joy, and the sense of freedom it provides is unparalleled.

Combat in Days Gone is intense, visceral, and incredibly satisfying. Whether I was facing hordes of Freakers or engaging in firefights with rival factions, the gameplay mechanics offered a wide range of options. The crafting system allowed me to create and modify weapons to suit my playstyle, while stealth and strategic planning played a crucial role in survival. The AI of both enemies and allies was impressively realistic, adding an extra layer of challenge and immersion to the combat encounters.

One of the standout features of Days Gone is the breathtaking attention to detail. The game's developers have clearly poured their hearts and souls into creating a world that feels alive. From the stunning graphics to the atmospheric sound design, every aspect of the game comes together seamlessly to create an immersive experience like no other. The level of polish and care that went into crafting this world is evident in every frame.

Moreover, the game's post-launch support has been outstanding. The developers have continued to release updates and improvements, addressing player feedback and adding new content to keep the experience fresh and engaging. It's commendable to see a studio so dedicated to their creation and the community that supports it.

In conclusion, Days Gone is a must-play game for any fan of open-world adventures and post-apocalyptic settings. Its compelling story, breathtaking visuals, immersive gameplay, and attention to detail combine to deliver an unforgettable experience. Bend Studio has created a game that sets a new standard for the genre, and I can't recommend it enough.

Days Gone is one of the best immersive zombie survival video games I have ever played. Easily my top 5 games of all time (next to Red Dead 2, Ghost of Tsushima, Last of Us, God of War, and Spiderman). I am more into graphics than the story, but after playing days gone, I got the best of both worlds (especially on my high-end pc). Days Gone is a breath of fresh air in a world of greed and cutting corners to release unfinished games. Days Gone visuals are from a different world and always amaze me. The story is very engaging and leaves me wanting to play more missions out of anticipation. I don’t always finish single-player games because of the developer's lack of work ethics and personal life responsibilities. However, I am honored to give 50 hours and will recommend it to my friends. A must-have for enthusiastic gamers that love adventurous single-player games and want total immersion. I recommend blocking out your schedule for 4–6 hours (or more) per weekend (or on your extra days off) to truly engage in days gone culture (life first, then video games).

I must say, "Days Gone" is a testament to the sheer excitement and immersive experience that the gaming world offers. From the moment I dove into the desolate world of Oregon, I was instantly hooked on the gripping narrative, intense gameplay, and stunning visuals that unfolded before me.

The first thing that struck me about "Days Gone" was its beautifully crafted open-world environment. The landscapes are breathtaking, ranging from dense forests and abandoned towns to treacherous mountains and desolate roads. The attention to detail is remarkable in every aspect, making this post-apocalyptic world feel truly alive.

The storyline of "Days Gone" is another standout feature. Players assume the role of Deacon St. John, a grizzled biker and former outlaw tasked with surviving the zombie-like "Freaker" horde that has overrun the land. As Deacon, players are taken on an emotional rollercoaster, navigating through a dark and unpredictable narrative, filled with unexpected twists and turns. The depth and complexity of the characters I encountered along the way made me invested in their journeys and added an extra layer of immersion to the game.

Combat in "Days Gone" is both thrilling and challenging. The hordes of Freakers I encountered throughout my journey were relentless and required careful planning and strategy to overcome. The game offers a vast arsenal of weapons, traps, and explosives, which made every encounter an adrenaline-pumping test of skill and creativity. The dynamic weather and day-night cycle further added to the intensity, creating a harrowing atmosphere that kept me on the edge of my seat.

What sets "Days Gone" apart from other post-apocalyptic games is its emphasis on survival and exploration. The game encourages players to scavenge for resources, upgrade their motorcycle, and follow various storylines and side quests. This freedom to roam and explore the world at my own pace allowed me to fully immerse myself in the game, uncovering hidden areas, encountering unique characters, and truly shaping my own experience.

Furthermore, the voice acting and sound design in "Days Gone" are exemplary. The performances were so convincing that I found myself emotionally invested in the characters, feeling their pain, joy, and desperation through their voices.

In conclusion, "Days Gone" is a truly captivating post-apocalyptic adventure that delivers on all fronts. From its stunning visuals and immersive open-world, to its compelling storyline and intense gameplay, the game offers a thrilling experience from start to finish. If you're a fan of action-packed, narrative-driven games with a touch of survival and exploration, "Days Gone" should definitely be on your must-play list.

"Sons of Anarchy meets The Walking Dead" makes for an excellent thrill ride that is Days Gone. The story centers around the actions of Deacon St. John as he confronts the horrors of a post-apocalyptic, freaker infested world while searching for the whereabouts of his wife Sarah. Deacon's determination, lethal skills & somewhat cynical nature makes him both an endearing & memorable protagonist.

Pros:
+Great Story: The story does an excellent job portraying both the mental & physical struggles of Deacon as he fights for survival in a post-apocalyptic Oregon while searching for his wife Sarah. The details of the deadly post-apocalyptic virus outbreak, various factions & their relation to Deacon & Sarah are revealed as progress is made through the main story-line & its side quests.
+Excellent Graphics: Post-apocalyptic Oregon looks simply beautiful from its snow-capped mountain peaks to crystal clear lakes. This makes for some breathtaking scenery when not taking on menacing freaker hordes or patrolling the grim remainder of human settlements scattered throughout the map. 
+Great Combat: The combat makes great use of Deacon's melee weapons, guns, throwables & traps when clearing out enemy encampments or taking on freaker hordes. This helps to complement your play-style whether its stealth or going in guns blazing. The skill tree is well implemented which enhances melee & ranged combat along with survival.
+Good Controls: The game's controls are simple and responsive when in combat or burning rubber through the back roads of Oregon on your motorcycle.
+Great Soundtrack: The somber yet at times menacing soundtrack definitely complements the look & feel of the game.

Cons:
-Some quests tend to follow a generic rinse & repeat formula, especially when clearing out hordes or ambush camps.
-Lack of cosmetics. While you can customize Deacon's drifter bike to some extent. There is no way of making the character uniquely yours by way of altering Deacon's appearance, at least without the use of mods.

I want to start off by saying there is a very good reason this game is rated overwhelmingly positive on steam, and the reason is simple. It's a damn good game, and I can say that and mean it. What blows my mind is that there are people who give this a bad rating, from what I can tell people are gonna bitch no matter what. Honestly, I feel it's been years since I've come across a game that's just refreshing to play and it actually "sorta" reinvents what we know as the zombie genre. The reason I say sorta is because it's kinda a cross between World War Z, RDR and Far Cry but with IMO a much better story and voice acting. Let's get down to brass tacks shall we? 

Pros
* I want to lead off with this: riding a motorcycle in this game is a real pleasure, sooooo many games have screwed this up but Days Gone, wow. I've hardly used the fast travel thus far and I've already logged 30+ hours. It feels good, your bike reacts when you go off road, hit a rock or run into some wildlife. It's as good as riding a horse in RDR2, but less buggy. 

* Not a massive map like RDR2, I'd say it's closer in size to maybe Far Cry 3, but none the less there are plenty of things to see, little events to do and collectibles to find. 

* Game looks gorgeous, I don't know how it looked on PS, but it looks wonderful on PC

* Voice acting is pretty darn good too, great dialogue with an entertaining story (you are also able to skip any minor dialogue, just in case you get a annoyed by certain characters)

* While there isn't a huge selection of guns and loot, the game does a nice job letting you find or buy better guns as you progress through the game

* There are 3 different leveling trees for Deacon (main character), I haven't leveled them out but each one seems to vastly improve your abilities whether that's hunting, collecting food, or maybe just helping with your stam and shooting (I'm not sure, but I don't think you can max out Deacon's stats from just one play through, I could be wrong)

* Getting to fight hordes of enemies in Days Gone is a challenge but very fun, this is something fairly unique to this game. I'm sure you've seen it in the trailers. But I don't recall or haven't played a game where you deal with a horde of enemies before, not like this at least. It 100% adds authenticity to what Bend Studios was trying to do with Days Gone. Which is, might I add, to feel completely and utterly overwhelmed. 

Cons

*One aspect of the game is you constantly need gas for your motorcycle, makes sense right? Well, you can't take an extra gas can with you so you have to look around for it. As you progress in the game it becomes quite a chore to get gas if you don't have money or you aren't around any places that have gas cans. It especially becomes annoying when you have to travel from one side of the map to the other, you cant cross the map with the first 2 gas tanks you can unlock for your bike. So be prepared to look for gas on your longer trips. This is okay for the first few times it happens, but as your missions seems to send you further and further away, this becomes obnoxious quick.  

* I wish there were more wildlife. I've seen bears, wolves and deer. I also wish they had expanded on the hunting and gathering portion of this game.

* Stealth could be improved as well, sometimes when you are hiding in a bush or tall grass you are easily seen by enemies and other times you can quite literally disappear in front of them. It doesn't make sense.
 
* I wish there were more side quests, like I mentioned there are little events you can do that pop up on your mini map as blue question marks, but most of the time they don't really yield you anything useful. Sometimes you'll find someone needing rescued, but that's not that often and the reward is minimal. 

* Funny enough, I did mention wishing there were more side quests but on the flip side what is a bit annoying is you can't just do the main story line quests without having to do a bunch of annoying side quests. I only mention this because the story is damn good, but people may not want to do all the extra stuff and in Days Gone you are stuck doing side events to advance the plot.

* Kinda drives me nuts you aren't able to change your clothes in this game. Cosmetics aren't always important, but it's just missing from this game completely, excluding your bike cosmetics. I know it's a minor thing, but the game does take course over weeks or months. There is a night and day feature and a counter that lets you know how many days have gone by. Idk seems weird to me to not have that feature. 

* I also wish there were more bounties to collect, not just from freaks but for enemies as well. It seems like after you've done certain missions for camp rep, there won't be anymore to do. Which is kinda sad, I have fun hunting down so and so, because he is a piece of crap rapist etc. 

Truth be told, the cons are pretty minor. If they do a second Days Gone they can expand of some these topics I mentioned. But other then that, you are really going to enjoy Days Gone especially if you enjoyed the other games I referred to during the review. This means 2 thumbs up and if I could raise my big toes like thumbs, I'd do that too! Feel free to buy at full price, you'll get your money's worth.

Days Gone is the story of Deacon St. John, a deeply disturbed individual who is always rambling to himself as he murders opposing camps of survivors in the zombie apocalypse. “You guys are murderers so how would you like it if I murdered you” he screams as he stealthily kills an entire camp of apparently deaf bandits. That might not be an exact quote. But it’s close enough. I love it. Finally, a protagonist we can relate to.

Deacon’s sort of a murder hobo, going around the world on his motorcycle and doing missions for various groups of survivors while never settling down. Then his bro gets hurt and he finds evidence that his wife survived the apocalypse, and he must get all invested in society again. Lame. Always sucks when you have a good thing going and the plot ruins everything.

So now Deacon’s going around beautiful open world rural Oregon killing zombies (including child zombies which may be the first time I’ve seen that in a game), upgrading his bike, and scavenging for collectibles in between homicidal rampages. You know, the usual open world stuff. 

There are basically two things that stand out about Days Gone. The first is the zombies. You can run into ginormous hordes of them. Hundreds of them are trying to chase you down. Tense stuff. Then there’s the motorcycle. At first its pretty annoying. You’ll have to scrounge for gas a lot in the beginning (and you do not want to have to do a lot of tedious walking in this game). Eventually, you can upgrade it and the bike becomes less “busywork” and more “pleasant sightseeing tour.”

I liked it a lot and recommend it highly.

I love this game. This has to be my favorite game. I understand theres alot of people who didnt have a good experience with the game. And I can see why. But its hit a checkbox for almost every feature I could want in a game.

1. Zombies (My favorite genre of horror) With a newer/interesting take, I love the idea of being able to find unscripted hordes. Like, hordes you just find, not that are secluded to being in certain missions. I love running into hordes that are 50 zombies big, its terrifying and gets my blood pumping.

2. A neat uncommon feature that is actually important to gameplay without being overbearing, in this form the motorcycle. Its the perfect balance being able to play with and without it. 

3. The story, 8.5/10 feels more personal and emotional than most zombie games. Almost all the characters are very well written, dialogue feels fluid and not choppy (most of the time)

4. The Open World. Its huge, its vast, and its engaging. Theres so much to do and its been alot of fun exploring. Its made better by the encounters with enemies you can have (hordes, marauders, etc) I havent had a single moment of boredom so far.

5. survival mechanics/gameplay. the crafting, looting, and combat are all great. Its intriquite while not being overwhelming, theres a ton of weapons and its fun to use them. Melee combat has been my favorite so far. Finding new melee weapons and switching out your old ones in a pinch is smooth and the combat is even smoother. Enemies dont feel clunky and everything feels very fluid.

I know thats not alot to check off, but I havent found a game thats balanced all these aspects as well as Days Gone has. Im loving the game and I cant wait to play more. 

Would Highly reccomend.

Days Gone is one of those games where it makes a lasting impression, although it does start a bit slow. The story was done so well with this game that you will always remember it, although it is a romance story really so some may not find that appealing. All of the voice acting was done well too, you can hear the emotions in the character's voices. They did a great job with the open world and really made it seem and feel like an actual zombie Apocalypse, the only down side is that night time is not really dark at all and i think that was a missed opportunity, if they would have made nighttime actually realistically dark to were you are forced to use your flashlight/bike light at night it would have brought so much more of a fear/difficulty level to the game. The zombies them selves for the most part look pretty good and there are different types as well. There is a pretty good amount of content with this game along with it's pretty long main story line. You should get at least 50+ hours out of this game if you take your time with it and don't just rush through the story. There is a player skill tree that will allow you to unlock different abilities along with a health/focus upgrades that you can find and use. There is a decent amount of guns to find/buy that can be semi modded by putting a silencer on some of them or even a extended meg. You can also get 2 different types of crossbows and of course there are also melee weapons that can be found/modded into something better. You can buy upgrades for the bike you have to make it better and better in different ways, You can also customize the appearance of the bike as well. This game does offer fast travel points once you start clearing out nest's to unlock said fast travel location, but honestly i never really use them i enjoy exploring by just riding around.  The map for this game is actually much larger than i thought it was going to be so that's always a plus. Graphically the game is pretty good looking and still runs smooth for the most part with minor frame loss when riding around on the bike. The only negative things about this game that i can think of are honestly just nit picky stuff, for example even though the dialog for all the characters in this game are well written they do tend to radio into to you a lot and it can become a little annoying at times, also your charter that you play as does a lot of commentary on things that you do when just out and about and it can also become a little annoying. There are some minor visual glitches that can occur along with some small bugs that i did notice on my 2nd play through of the game but it was never anything game breaking. As i stated before there is a good amount of content in this game but some of the side content  that can be done like burning out nest's or clearing out zombie hordes can start to get a bit boring after doing so many of them since it is doing the same thing over and over just in a new location. The aiming/shooting guns in this game could have been a bit better in the sense of accuracy, what i mean by this is sometimes you will be aiming right at a persons chest area or even the head but for whatever reason it completely misses the shot almost like the game did not register the hit marker. Other than those things there really is not much else that i would consider to be a con in this game. Overall this is a wonderful game and in my opinion i do think it is worth the asking price. Sadly though once you finish the game that's it, i don't think the people who made this game are ever going to be making a squeal :(

I choose to recommend this game, but it does come with a word of warning. I've got a feeling I'm about halfway done with the game and while the game play is amazing, the story kind of drags it down. The writing in this game feels like it was done by several different people and none of them checked where the others were at before writing their lines. Characters will go from angry to sad to in the middle in the span of 3 lines of dialogue. There's a character who looks to be a teen, but talks like she's 6. Every time I managed to break away from the story and go do some exploring on my own I get sucked right back in. You'll quickly learn that the dialogue is bad because no one in this game ever stops talking. Deacon could be in the process of sneaking up behind a zombie to take it out quietly and will decide to loudly talk about how it's always raining, or trying to infiltrate a ripper camp and start yelling out about how he's going to get every last one of them. It's a big disconnect between what the player is trying to do and what Deacon is saying/doing. The story is uninteresting, but I keep finding myself coming back and slogging through it just to get to more of the gameplay.

The bike is a wonder to ride, the guns are equally fun to shoot, and the zombies are well zombies. The human enemies aren't great as enemies but they get the job done. The only actual criticism I have of gameplay is that gun ammunition aren't interchangeable, meaning if you have an assault rifle, but it's different than the assault rifle the enemy has then you cannot pick up the bullets that an enemy drops when you kill them. I get that in real life they have different ammunition sizes, but the game doesn't specify this. When you pick up ammo in the world, it's just classified as "assault rifle/pistol/shotgun ammo" but the shotgun shells that fit in my sidearm won't fit in my primary and the AK rounds won't fit in the MRS. Slightly annoying but on the normal difficulty the game gives you enough materials that you'll rarely be fighting tooth and nail for some. 

I did manage to get this game on sale, which would probably be the only time I'd purchase it.

[b]Looks:[/b]
This is really a beautiful game (much of it looks far better then Red Dead Redemption 2) with great characters that not only feel real (well, most of them) but also have their own character / unique way of moving and expressing themselves. I've never seen anything like it and it truly is wonderful. 

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
But more importantly, the game itself is a lot of fun. Is is perfect? No, some pieces are slow and -for instance- continuously fueling up the (apparantly grapefruitsized) tank of your bike is a grind that I could do without. Not sure why that is even a thing in the game. 
Another gripe is characters refusing to give you a mission even when you know they got one... to only 'message' you that they have a mission AFTER you drive away from their camp. And then they don't even give you the mission... oh no... they tell you to come to them in person. BUT I WAS THERE 5 MINUTES AGO AND CHECKED YOU FOR A MISSION. Now you make me come back and I happen to need to perform your mission at the place that I JUST WAS WHEN YOU MESSAGED ME?
But again, apart from above frustrations the game is still a lot of fun to do. I guess I just have an itch for killing zombies that I can't fulfill in real life ;-). Fights are fun, hordes are fun, skilltree is... OK. 

[b]Bugs:[/b]
Is it bugfree? In my personal playthrough I didn't experience any "real bugs", the only weird thing is that sometimes when your... eh... victims die their body ragdolls 3m in the air for some reason. Definitely not game breaking... maybe immersion breaking for some but to me (=stickler for immersion usually) it was more comical than anything else. 

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
I love this game and I'm a bit sad it's over. I can only hope Sony reconsiders and makes a part II, because this tastes like more.
