As a passionate gamer, I recently embarked on a thrilling adventure through the post-apocalyptic Oregon in Bend Studio's masterpiece, Days Gone. This open-world action-adventure game had me hooked from the very beginning, immersing me in a world overrun by hordes of infected creatures known as "Freakers." Join me as I share my detailed review of this captivating game, highlighting its strengths and weaknesses.

Pros:

1. Engrossing Storyline: From the moment I assumed the role of Deacon St. John, I was instantly drawn into the compelling narrative of Days Gone. Deacon's journey through loss, survival, and redemption kept me emotionally invested throughout the game. The complex and relatable characters, along with the exploration of profound themes, added depth and resonance to the overall experience.

2. Expansive Open World: The post-apocalyptic Oregon is a breathtaking setting that never ceased to amaze me. From dense forests and abandoned towns to treacherous highways and snow-covered mountains, the world of Days Gone felt incredibly vast and diverse. The developers' attention to detail, coupled with dynamic weather effects and a day-night cycle, created an immersive environment that I loved exploring.

3. Thrilling Survival Gameplay: Days Gone masterfully blends various gameplay elements to deliver an intense and immersive survival experience. The constant need to scavenge for resources, craft essential items, and manage my motorcycle, affectionately named "my trusty steed," added a layer of realism and urgency to the gameplay. Every encounter with hostile humans or ravenous Freakers demanded strategic thinking, and the vast array of weapons and traps at my disposal allowed for a variety of playstyles.

4. Epic Horde Battles: The adrenaline-fueled horde battles in Days Gone were nothing short of exhilarating. The sheer scale of these encounters, with hundreds of Freakers swarming relentlessly, left me on the edge of my seat. Planning my attack, utilizing the environment to my advantage, and witnessing the chaos unfold as explosions rocked the battlefield were some of the most memorable moments in the game. These intense battles truly tested my skills and provided a sense of accomplishment when successfully overcoming the odds.

5. Stunning Visuals and Immersive Sound Design: Days Gone's visual presentation was simply stunning. The attention to detail in the environments, character models, and atmospheric effects left me in awe. The post-apocalyptic landscapes were hauntingly beautiful, and the grotesque yet intricately animated Freakers added to the sense of danger and unease. The game's haunting soundtrack and meticulous sound design further heightened the immersion, creating a spine-chilling atmosphere that kept me engaged from start to finish.

Cons:

1. Slow Pacing in the Beginning: While Days Gone ultimately delivers an unforgettable experience, it must be noted that the game starts with a relatively slow pace. The lengthy prologue may feel somewhat tedious, as it takes its time to establish the story and introduce the mechanics. However, I urge players to be patient, as the narrative picks up its pace and the game gradually unfolds into an engrossing adventure.

2. Repetitive Side Missions: Although the main story missions in Days Gone offered unique and engaging experiences, some of the side missions and activities suffered from repetitive objectives. Clearing out enemy camps or rescuing hostages often felt like variations of the same tasks. While they provided opportunities to further explore the world and gain valuable resources, the lack of variety in objectives occasionally became monotonous.

3. Occasional Technical Issues: During my playthrough, I encountered a few technical hiccups. Although Bend Studio has worked diligently to address these issues through updates and patches, occasional frame rate drops and minor glitches did momentarily disrupt my immersion.

Honestly, I tried this game when it launched on PS4 on a PS4 Pro. It didn't capture my attention right away. No riveting story right off the bat, the controls seemed clunky and it seemed like every other open world, third-person, zombie game. The graphics were decent but the PS4 Pro didn't do it justice. This game was Graphically advanced, more so than what the times would allow on consoles. 

Fast forward to the PC launch. After seeing the game on sale multiple times. I finally bought the game for $20 bucks when i saw the reviews were overwhelmingly positive. I felt as though I was missing out on a gem and I hadn't given it a fair shake or maybe this is its better form. Regardless, I do not regret my purchase. I would have gladly paid full price. This game has tons to do. Some tasks are repetitive but much like the Outposts in Far Cry. Each one is unique and fun, although they are the same tasks. The game is quite lengthy too. Game play is actually really tight. Motorcycle controls are stellar, too. 

3 big things that made this game for me. 

1. The story is unpredictable in the best way. I will be watching a cut scene, anxious about what might go sideways for Deacon. But sometimes, things do go exactly as planed. It's a nice shake up from literally EVERYTHING going wrong all the time. The dialogue can sometimes feel in-cohesive or out of pocket. After playing the game and learning the personalities of the different characters, you start to understand that they don't communicate as though someone wrote the script. It seems more ad lib or natural. Like how real people, with no script, talk and communicate. Not gonna win an Oscar but it's a really nice change of pace. 

2. The Hordes. Frankly, they are incredible. 100-200 Freakers, rushing at you. Relentlessly chasing you down. Attempt the Hordes early on, in my opinion, for the most fun. They do become softer targets when you progress into the late game. Massive amounts of fun and there are a lot of them to do post game as well. 

3. The graphics and the Porting quality, especially after experience The Last of Us gave us, are top tier. This game was meant to run on PC. Unlike a lot of PC ports, there isn't an overwhelming amount of graphics options but the game looks and runs beautiful. I do have a really high end rig but very few crashes and very bugs. 

Bend Studio, if you all see this, I know its relatively implausible, but if y'all can make a 2nd game happen, please do. 

If you have hesitations, take a risk, wait for it to go on sale if you have to. Give the game a few hours. It's definitely a late bloomer.

I bet you're asking yourself "What is the one resource I need to really hoard in the event of a zombie apocalypse?"

Well my friends, I have the answer.

Is it isopropyl alcohol? Kerosene? Gunpowder? Spark Igniters? Gasoline?

Nope.

It's [b]Cans[/b].

Yes, you heard me right. Cans.

As this game clearly demonstrates, all those other things will flow from the heavens like rain. What you really want to focus on for you survival kit is cans. They will apparently be in such short supply, that virtually no kitchen, house, campground, or otherwise will have them. They will become incredibly rare. So rare that just finding [b]one[/b] can will make you feel like you've just hit the survival-apocalypse lottery.

No, don't thank me. Thank this wonderful game for enlightening us all. Thank you Days Gone... thank you.

Days Gone is a very interesting and immersive take on the zombie shooter genre. It keeps a reasonable balance between challenge and fun throughout the majority of the story.  As one would expect from the promotional material, the game has a big focus on fighting a few massive hordes rather than many skirmish scale encounters, though smaller scale fighting is present in some capacity.  The combat is pretty good, and unlike other similar titles, actually has meaningfully diverse set of tools available to the player. Admittedly, players who decide to complete all available side activities will inevitably have their character become the usual late game Gary Sue, but it does take a fairly long time to get to that point. On the topic of characters, they are decently well written. The main character falls under the painfully generic bastard with a heart of gold archetype, but that being said, he is still interesting. In contrast, the supporting cast are very unique, with vastly different personalities. Most importantly, they all serve an actual, meaningful purpose in the story that goes beyond just being interesting. The game takes between 40 and well over 100 hours to complete depending on how much hordes, bandit camps and side quests you can complete before your eyes start to glaze over. Overall, the game is definitely worth picking up if open world zombie shooters are your thing.

Days Gone is an exceptional game that instantly captured my attention with its post-apocalyptic world. As a gamer of 50+ years, I can confidently say it's one of the best games I've ever played. From its stunning visuals to its gripping story line and immersive game play, it's a masterpiece that deserves high praise.

The graphics in Days Gone are breathtaking, showcasing lush forests and desolate urban areas with remarkable detail. The open-world setting allows for freedom and exploration, making every excursion feel like a genuine struggle for survival. The dynamic weather system adds realism, intensifying the sense of danger lurking around every corner.

Playing as Deacon St. John, a rugged bounty hunter, I became invested in his personal journey through this brutal post-pandemic world. The narrative skillfully weaves together themes of survival, loss, and redemption, keeping me engaged from start to finish. The well-developed characters and emotional storytelling left a lasting impact.

Combat in Days Gone is intense and satisfying, especially when facing hordes of zombie-like creatures known as Freakers. The game offers a variety of strategies and weapons, allowing for adaptability in different situations. It's a thrilling experience that keeps you on your toes.

One aspect that truly sets Days Gone apart is the bond formed with Deacon's motorcycle. It goes beyond mere transportation, becoming a trusted companion in the midst of chaos. Customization options and attention to detail make the motorcycle feel like a lifeline, symbolizing survival and freedom in a harsh world. This unique relationship adds depth and emotional attachment to the game play.

While the cancellation of Days Gone 2 is disappointing news, it doesn't take away from the incredible experience the first game offers. Days Gone will forever hold a special place in my gaming memories. If you haven't played it yet, I highly recommend immersing yourself in this thrilling post-apocalyptic ride.

TL:DR review - 
--------------
Super fun open world zombie survival game with brilliant gameplay mechanics and zombie hordes(like hundreds of them. And they sprint at you).
Decent story, excellent audio. Beautiful open world with lots of things to do and places to explore. Must play.
 
 Long review:-
 ---------------
 Remember when AMC's walking dead TV show came out in 2010 and it was so good and fresh because it was something people hadn't seen before. Following that, every
 year there have been countless zombie based movies and games. Some good, some bad and some very very generic. But only a handful of these captured the magic of the
 original AMC's TV show(the 1st season atleast). Days Gone manages to do that beautifully.
 
 The opening 3-4 hours of this game is nothing short of exceptional and is an excellent hook. Towards the middle of the game, there is a bit of a slowdown because you get 
 some search and rescue type missions/clear camp missions which might put some people off. But then it picks up again and there is a slowdown again before the final act of the game.
 This is quite a long game(took me around 55 hours to complete) and I love doing most of the side missions and stuff in games like these so I did most of it. Skipped some stupid questlines like\
 clear out 42 zombie bird nests(like...no,thank you).

 Pros:-
--------
 1.) Opening act - The opening 5-ish hours of the game is just a brilliant experience and is a great hook for you to completely immerse yourself in this world.
 2.) Audio - Excellent audio design. Intense music which raises your pulse while fighting hordes, suspenseful music while exploration, upbeat music in combat. The only place where audio was a bit meh, was where there was a speech cutscene and you could hear the background character's chatter over the lead person giving the speech. Minor mixing issue.
 3.) Open world -  The open world they have crafted here looks amazing and it feels even more thrilling exploring this world with its abandoned complexes, tunnels,caves,jungles. The environmental design is quite honestly phenomenal. Brilliantly captures the post apocalyptic vibe with immobilized vehicles, destroyed barricades, abandoned rescue camps, derailed trains  etc. Its really enjoyable to explore and I loved
 every minute of it.
 4.) Environmental Design - Brilliant. As good as environment design in Last of Us.
 5.) Hordes - This is one of the most exhilarating experiences in any zombie game ever made. Imagine a pack of 50-500 zombies running at you full sprint and you having to outrun, shoot, manage stamina, use the environment to guide them into choke points, blow them up while not getting cornered or pincered by the pack. Think Dying Light 1's night zombie chases but on steroids. It is absolutely insane fighting hordes in this game.
And there are some hordes which you cannot tackle early game at all simply because you don't have the resources to do so. Yes, you can cheese some of them through youtube video techniques but that cheapens the experience imo. 
Anyway, hordes in this game -> Insanely fun experience. Fun, Tough and gets your blood flowing.
 6.) Enemy Variety - Wolves, Infected Wolves, Infected crows, Bears, Infected bears, humans(unarmored enemies in early-mid game to armored enemies late game), normal zombies, tougher normal zombies, screamers(calls other zombies to your location),newts(kid zombies annoying af), brute zombies, runner zombies etc. Good enemy variety. Did not have any complaints with this. 
 7.) Characters - The protagonist is basically a dude being shoved into leadership positions when he clearly isn't a leader. And that is fine, there are people in the world like this and its okay for a game to have a character who isn't an uber macho perfect born leader leaking testosterone out of his eyes. But yes, there are quirks to his character and he does grow somewhat throughout the game(though not as much as I would have liked). The side characters are good too.
While they too aren't perfect, they are extremely believable characters. You have the idealist camp leader dude, the conspiracy theorist camp leader dude, the slave labourer camp leader lady, the sleazy scumbag
"bro" character who lies while smiling and shaking your hand, you have the bisexual badass chick who is interested in you, the religious nutjob, a militant with a gob complex etc etc. Very nice, believable characters.
The world isn't perfect and neither are the people in them. 
 8.) Gameplay - As Tuco Salamanca said.. " Tight! Tight! Tight!". No seriously, inventory wheel, weapons, gunplay, character movement felt fine and well done. Would have preferred a bit more variety with melee but thats okay.
 9.) The Bike - While this is also technically, gameplay, I'm making a separate point for this because with the amount of effort and maintenance you put into the bike it is basically a character in its own right.You start off with a real broken down mess of a gas guzzling fragile vehicle which you upgrade throughout the course of the game and end up with some really nice wheels(for an apocalyptic world) by the end. It serves as your mobile quicksave station, your limited ammo refill station(if you have bought saddlebags for the bike). The bike can run out of fuel and you can get stranded at someplace with no fuel pump or fuel can nearby. Very nice mechanic with the bike and how the devs have integrated the vehicle in the gameplay. 
 10.) Goes to some difficult places - There are some missions which tackle really difficult societal and philosophical topics like drug abuse, loss, sparing someone through death etc. That was a nice touch.
				
Cons:-
1.) Deacon's Code - The protagonist, Deacon St.John lives by a code which is reinforced again and again through the game that he doesn't like people who "kill unarmed women". Though it is never explained exactly why he has this very specific code especially as he kills probably hundreds of female goons over the course of the game(most of them are armed but hey some of them he sneaks up on). This feels like a character just having a code to live by for the sake of having a code to live by as a protagonist because thats the cool thing to do. This felt jarring and out of place to be honest.
2.) Some specific missions - There are a few missions where you have to go check up/talk to certain characters and they just say one line like "I'm fine. I have to go."/"Get outta here. I have work to do." and the mission just ends. This felt incredibly annoying and ridiculous but thankfully there are only like 3 or 4 of these missions in the whole game.
3.) Pacing issue - Before midgame and post midgame the game is bogged a bit by some pacing issues mostly due to camp clearing missions etc. 
4.) Irrelevant choices and No choices - There are some choices you make early game which result in basically...nothing. And some choices you make early game seem like they would be available again later in the game but you never get that option again in the game in similar scenarios. Fairly linear game in terms of story progression which is completely fine but then why have us making choices in the first place? Seems like a bit of a missed opportunity here. Mid-late game choices basically boils down to you rescuing survivors and deciding which camp they go to based on which camp you are trying to max out or need reputation/money in. They could have done so much more with the camps.

Overall, a very very fun and engaging experience and a must play.

TL;DR
Buy the game, with or without sale because it is definitely the most underrated game of all Playstation Studios games released on PC.

Having seen some of the gameplay from the original launch on console, Days Gone instantly became one of those games that i wished one day would come to PC, so i could get it, although at the time it didnt seem likely.

You can imagine how happy i was when Sony announced the release of the game on PC, even though i took my time to buy the game and after buying it, then i took my sweet ass time to finish it (completionist curse, i knew the game would immerse me) and surprise, it most certaintly did.

This game is a true gem and very immersive once you get the hang of the gameplay. The story itself is really great if you give it a chance and dont just give up like some woke reviewers lol. 

Yes, it starts slow but once it picks up steam and you start putting the pieces together of the various storylines in the game by not just following the main story quests but also exploring the side quests and going after the collectibles in the regions, you will find that most of the characters are multi layered, interesting and their backgrounds shape who they are in the post apocalyptic world.

Specially the main character, he maybe seem boring and generic at first, but believe me, there are so many layers to this dude that i think its worth actually reading through the storyline entries and just seeing how he changes throughout the game to see that he is probably one of the most complex and real protagonists in a video game.

Plus there is a ton of meaningful and engaging side content, activities and collectibles for the all the completionists out there, that will be sure to keep you entertained with the game for a long time, i clocked over 100hr, because i would sometimes be AFK with the game open or just scouring the map for hordes (you will enjoy them), but still you definitely get your moneys worth either way.

The entire gameplay and UI, the combat, the characters, the animations, the AI and the map design and attention to details puts Days Gone on a level of quality that i feel that the reviews didnt give it justice.

In conclusion, i fully recommend you getting this game and let yourself be immersed in this world and its characters, you will surely have hours of pure fun and adventure.

Now, all that remains is for us to wait for Sony to wake up and deliver justice by giving us a sequel to the game, because the developers at Bend Studios worked their asses off and surely deserve it.

Days Gone isn't the first game to have an unlikable protagonist either... Alan Wake, the Last of Us 1 and 2. Morally complicated characters are more interesting, that's it.

Time to go in. Spoilers ahead.

The story in this game is outright atrocious. It very clearly has intent, but its like 10 writers were given a story board, all individually made their own ideas, and never talked to each other to smooth things out. 

We play as Deacon, a character we know nothing about but slowly learn more about through the story and, in a weird way, turns out he kinda sucks as a person. He has a vibe of compensatory masculinity and attempted edginess, with a hint of "men don't talk about their feelings" to avoid any real character depth. On top of that, his past is never really clearly explained. This could be forgivable, if it wasn't used as a major plot point. The first real bad guy you find in the game, Carlos (Jessie), is an old biker buddy of Deacon and Boozer, and apparently you two and some guy named Jack held him down and burned off his back, which is why he hates you and wants revenge. Why did they do this? I never really got an in-game explanation. There are answers on the wiki, but I saw plenty of blog posts of people asking the same question; so my guess is it's not included naturally in the story telling. Either way, a confusing bit of the story, although the least offensive. 

Some other examples of terrible writing is the the relationship between Rikki and Addison. Rikki is a character which Deacon has a history with (of course no detail or depth is given) and is in a relationship with Addison. The game seems to put in work to create a dramatic situation between the three, as Rikki likes Deacon, Addison is becoming jealous as Rikki's behavior is changing, and Deacon's best friend Boozer was just saved by Addison. Seems like the recipe for a juicy camp conflict or some external/internal character conflict. What happens? Nothing. Rikki flirts with deacon once, Deacon shoots her down, nothing happens. Deacon doesn't even give a reason for why he shoots down Rikki. Does he still have hope for his wife? Still feel committed to her? Does he feel guilty about betraying the woman who saved his best friend? Is he his own cock block? (yes) We don't know and nothing ever comes of the situation. However, this is one of the reasons why I said there was clearly intent before. At the scene where Rikki flirts with Deacon, we get a camera shot of Skizzo (a sleezy untrustworthy guy) seeing us from outside the window, and what appears to be a set up for him having blackmail on us, or just the ability to start trouble if he wants. This scene was literally pointless. It's inclusion means nothing, it's never touched on, and as far as I'm aware was left in by mistake because they decided to axe the love drama.

Two more writing examples and I'll move on. Deacon and his wife, Sarah. Deacon has been morning her to a point of being suicidal. When he gets a lead on her potentially being alive, it absolutely enlivens him and (understandably) becomes his main focus. He eventually finds her after two or so years of thinking each other is dead and we get... nothing. A "Wow you're alive?" A kiss. Then "here's a clipboard, go risk your life for some flowers or some shit." Deacon and Sarah never really talk about things even when given opportunities, Sarah never expresses some internal conflict at sending her husband to his potential death over and over again, and Deacon seems cool with his wife having become a completely different person from who he remembers and takes her "I don't want to talk about it" as sufficient. The characters in porno have more personality than this. At least I could believe Dee Williams might be someone's mom. I dont think Sarah even knows shes married.

Lastly, the research center. An apocalypse utopia. Running water, farm land, electric fences. You'd try to move right in, right? At least claim it? Nope. Lost Lake gives 0 fucks. Deacon literally radios them about the place. Nada. Dont hear anything about them going to harvest the corn or any banter about "we should probably move in to that fortified building with solar panels and is self automated that would be a dream to live it." In fact, when Deacon calls Rikki about it, she literally sounds sarcastic cause she's still bitter he went and found his wife, I guess? "Hey Rikki I found the jackpot that is really gonna help the camp" "Oh yeah? thats soooo cool but I don't care to talk to you." Like damn bitch sorry I'm too busy "lighting candles" with my wife, loser. Go spit metaphors at the veterinarian you tried to cheat on and quit judging me.

Aw shit. I said that last paragraph was last for writing.. which it is. But what the fuck happened to that little girl you saved? She really did go and fuck off huh? Same with O'Brian. Fuck me for being interested in any of these characters I guess. My fault for wanting story in a single player game.

On to annoying mechanics.

To start, dialogue. It was not uncommon for me to miss out on some seemingly important dialogue. Regularly, when going with an NPC to a location, the dialogue the characters share is twice as long as it takes to get there, so if you want to hear it you'll have to sit and park (very fun gameplay btw). There are also many times someone would call Deacon, and that call would then be interrupted by another voice line or the starting of a mission, so the call would cancel itself and I'd never hear it again. Sometimes a call would start when you're already mid conversation so your balancing listening to two people at once. Maybe this is where the important explanation of Jack and Jessie happen, and I missed it.

Helping survivors. This really shows the refinement (or lack there of) of the game. I helped about nine survivors. I saw two player models. Pretty pathetic. There was even an event that happened on the bridge of Lost Lake, where a guy was being held by bandits (Lost Lake really didn't seem to care about the guy outside screaming for help). I free'd him, and told him to go to Lost Lake, he says thanks, and then he runs in the opposite direction where I watch him despawn in ten feet.

The sniper ambushes. Fucking fuck these shits. These guys could snipe a specific sperm in a sea of jizz faster than Hawkeye can get cucked by The Hulk. No matter how fast you go on your bike, or if their laser is even pointed in your direction, your bike will be one shot and you will fly off. When I see the laser I literally cant stop fast enough to get off my bike before this random teenager with a Faze scholarship 360 no scopes me. It's not a "challenging mechanic" it's just annoying.

I could go on but this review is long enough and I'm tired. If you read this far you already know if you want the game or not. Thank you for reading my rant. The game wasnt a complete waste of time, but again, only recommend if you're really looking for another zombie game. I give it two kids in a wheelchair out of five.

I agree with everyone who says it was underrated or unfairly panned by gaming press at launch, but I also didn't have to deal with launch bugs. It's fun and stable now, with only a few minor visual and audio bugs experienced during gameplay-- with the exception of a fast travel that spawned me well underneath the map terrain at the very end of my playthrough. 

Sam Witwer is again a VG lead (I think he was the lead char in Force Unleashed?) and there are some really idiosyncratic and even strange acting choices here that run through the whole game. Overacting, inconsistent volume and delivery, and straight up weirdness in a lot of the open world voice work. But put Deacon on screen with other characters during cinematics and some moments are brilliant. He carries the game well and the actors around him hold up to that level of performance. The cinematics and the open world performances don't always coincide well but it's a minor gripe.

The story is standard zombie fare, no real innovation here. Some consipiracy theory nonsense, anti-Government sentiment (those damn Feds at FEMA, I mean NERO, they made the virus! LOL) are sprinkled over the by-the-numbers zombie narrative layer cake of hunt for the maybe-dead-wife while you survive in the humans-are-the-real-monsters wasteland--tropes that are so time worn its basically a smooth pebble of a premise. But like most zombie properties, if you do the human stories right it can prop up the aging genre stuff enough to work, and I feel like it does here. Boozer's great, and Deek is fun to inhabit even when/if you don't completely sympathize/empathize.

If I have a major complaint it's the pacing of the story and gameplay. It's really uneven. Some of the best weapons won't unlock until endgame or after, and you won't be able to fight hordes and track them on the map until you get through a big chunk of story. The story is at times too slow to develop, skills feel too slow to unlock, and if you're a completionist you will be dealing with some repetition that causes a dip in the middle of the game that might cause folks to put the game down. Once the story picks up, it's well worth it, so I say if you commit to it it pays off. It would've been better to have intermingled the main story with some side stories in a more organic way, or to unlock horde fights earlier or scatter them around the early game in a more interesting way. 

There are some really cool emergent encounters that pop up, and once you kite around entire hordes you can destroy them in creative ways. Sometimes. Other times the hordes are just plopped on the open map and you don't have any choice other than kite them around.

Looking at the later weapons that unlock, it makes me wonder if there were DLC plans or store plans that got scrapped and the items were sort of peppered into the late game. Uncertain, total conjecture. It just feels a little microtransaction-y even though they're not that. It's frustrating to be almost completely done horde hunting and/or completely done with the game and then they drop a cool new weapon on you. I guess it could be bait to try NG+ as well, but I think there are better ways to time out unlockable upgrades than what they settled on.

Upgrading the bike is satisfying, riding is mostly a pleasure save a few instances of *ridiculous* and unintentionally hilarious terrain/geometry collision. I think the game devs could've increased their sales and player retention by adding this one thing, this one simple thing:  [i] Let us strap a single-use gas can onto the back of our bike. [/i] It would be helpful to have a lil extra gas for when you get caught in the middle of nowhere or you fast travel a little too much without calculating cost. I didn't mind the gas resource or scrap resource otherwise, though it does take a little too long to upgrade them to the point where you feel somewhat free of the mechanic. But knowing to coast downhill to save gas and the ability to coast downhill silently on the bike is a glorious thing, one of my favorite mechanics in the game. If you can get above your objective, you can sneak up really close to them and have your bike, with its ammo sacks and quicksave ability, right nearby. Very cool. And some missions force you to advance from below or find a way around, forcing you to leave your bike behind. It's great. But sometimes you lose your bike and want to recall it and it's like "bike is too far away," like, bish, I know it's far away that's why I'm trying to recall it! And every now and again a mission pops up that says "you must have a working bike nearby" so you go and get your bike and then it's like "your bike doesn't have enough fuel," like, okay, this will be a chase mission you have spoiled all surprise AND now I have to go get gas. Pfffft. Why not just have the gas stop being spent during that lil side mission, they do that for the story missions so it's already part of the game to suspend gas usage for certain moments. But no I have to leave and come back with more gas. Boo. Only happens a few times but still.

Late game resources get way too scarce (you will use tons of resources to smash hordes). It would've been great to open up a shop that sells kerosene or growlers near the endgame so you don't have to scavenge as much. I get why they didn't, but keeping me out scavenging on hour 10 is very different than forcing me out scavenging on hour 50-- so why not save me some time? They put a trunk out here and there where you'll get some ammo and mollys but starving for growlers right after you unlock the thing feels like forced scarcity to stretch the game out.

I don't agree that it's a masterpiece because of the pacing. There are moments that feel artificially drawn out or like they wanted to stretch the content and that's my biggest complaint. For a AAA open-worlder you can do worse and you can do better-- but will there be zombie hordes and will you ride a motorcycle? This game has that hook and it works. After finishing the story I kept going to clear some missions and finish things up-- I felt like I wasn't quite ready to leave the world of the game as I'd found it fun. That's a good measure and ultimately it makes me feel like, yeah, pretty good game. Pick it up on sale and enjoy.

Days Gone is an adrenaline-fueled post-apocalyptic adventure that takes players on an emotional rollercoaster. 🎢💥 From the intense motorcycle chases to the heart-pounding encounters with hordes of zombies, this game delivers a truly gripping experience that will keep you on the edge of your seat. 😱🧟‍♂️

The open-world environment in Days Gone is absolutely breathtaking. 🌄🌿 Exploring the vast and diverse landscapes of the Pacific Northwest feels like embarking on a true adventure. The stunning visuals and dynamic weather effects further enhance the immersion, creating an atmospheric world that is both beautiful and dangerous. 🌧️🌲

The storyline of Days Gone is compelling and emotionally charged. As players follow the journey of Deacon St. John, a rugged and relatable protagonist, they become invested in his struggles, losses, and triumphs. The game explores themes of survival, love, and the bonds of friendship, adding depth to the overall experience. 💔🚀

The gameplay mechanics in Days Gone are top-notch. The motorcycle serves as both transportation and a crucial aspect of survival, as players need to maintain and upgrade it to navigate the harsh world. Combat is intense and varied, with a wide array of weapons and tactics to choose from. The encounters with the zombie-like Freakers are genuinely terrifying, and facing off against hordes of them is an adrenaline-pumping challenge. 🔫🏍️

The attention to detail in Days Gone is remarkable. The developers have created a living, breathing world with its own ecosystem and dynamic events. The interactions with non-playable characters are authentic, and the side missions and activities offer a wealth of content to explore. The day-night cycle and the impact it has on the gameplay adds another layer of depth to the experience. 🌓🔍

Furthermore, the post-launch support for Days Gone has been commendable, with updates and improvements that have enhanced the game's performance and added new features. The dedication of the development team to the player community is evident, and it ensures a continuously enjoyable experience. 🔄👏

In a nutshell, Days Gone is a thrilling and emotionally charged adventure that will captivate players from start to finish. With its stunning visuals, intense gameplay, and immersive storytelling, it is a must-play for fans of the post-apocalyptic genre. Strap on your motorcycle helmet and embark on a journey through the unforgiving wilderness of Days Gone—it's an experience you won't want to miss! 🌅🏍️💀

 In the dark, grim future of a parallel world, human ingenuity, perseverance and spirit have died. Most of the surviving people now live in concentration camps. Those outside of the camps are outlaws, who can be killed on sight.

 You play as Dick Johnson, a (N.E.R.O.) genetically deformed biker, who earns the favor of the camp tyrants by murdering other outlaws and destroying infected people, called freakers.

 His life purpose was serving his wife, but now he is just trying to get by, one day at a time. Join the servant of Sara in this exciting post-corporation world where the main enemy of mankind are not the hundreds of millions of infected, but a Christian man leading a couple of hundred people.

Title: Days Gone: A Gripping Journey Through a Post-Apocalyptic World

Rating: ★★★★☆

Days Gone offers a gripping and immersive gaming experience, blending an intriguing story, unexpected plot twists, and rich game world content. From the moment you embark on this post-apocalyptic adventure, you'll find yourself captivated by its narrative and drawn into a world teeming with danger and mystery.

One of the standout aspects of Days Gone is its engrossing story. As players assume the role of Deacon St. John, they are thrust into a world ravaged by a deadly pandemic, where humanity is on the brink of collapse. Deacon's personal journey as a former outlaw turned bounty hunter is filled with emotional depth and nuanced character development. You'll find yourself emotionally invested in his quest for redemption and survival, as he navigates through a desolate landscape filled with both human adversaries and the relentless Freakers.

What sets Days Gone apart is its ability to keep you on the edge of your seat with unexpected plot twists. Just when you think you've unraveled the secrets of this unforgiving world, the game throws unexpected curveballs that challenge your assumptions and keep you guessing. These twists not only add excitement but also provide a deeper layer of complexity to the narrative, ensuring that you're always eager to uncover the next revelation.

The game world content in Days Gone is vast, diverse, and incredibly detailed. The Pacific Northwest setting is beautifully realized, with sprawling forests, abandoned towns, and decaying structures that create a hauntingly atmospheric backdrop for your adventures. Exploring this world on Deacon's trusty motorcycle is a delight in itself, as you encounter breathtaking vistas, encounter dynamic weather systems, and stumble upon hidden secrets that add depth to the lore.

Furthermore, the game world is populated by various factions, each with their own motivations and conflicts. These factions provide engaging side quests and missions that further enrich the narrative and give you a glimpse into the struggles and survival instincts of the remaining survivors. Whether you're helping a struggling community or facing off against hostile enemies, the game world content keeps you engrossed and offers a sense of purpose beyond the main story.

In conclusion, Days Gone is a game that excels in delivering an intriguing story, unexpected plot twists, and rich game world content. It invites you to embark on a journey that will test your survival skills, challenge your assumptions, and leave you hungry for more. Despite its minor technical flaws, the game's immersive experience and captivating storytelling make it a must-play for fans of post-apocalyptic adventures. Prepare yourself for an unforgettable ride through a world that is as unforgiving as it is fascinating.

A decent open-world game.  I am not particularly fond of the zombie genre, but I actually liked this one.  While the zombie aspect is a part of the world and plot, there is really more of a human v. human struggle.  Some of the missions got repetitive (like rescuing so-and-so who was kidnapped by marauders, etc.), but that's OK.  

The gun-play was good, I thought.   A good selection of realistic weapons are available gradually, and each camp has a slightly different set of offerings (obviously the better guns are later).  There is some crafting of weapons and health items, but it is kept pretty simple (which I liked).

The world/map is designed well.  The initial section is my least favorite:  the dense forest gives a creepy, claustrophobic feeling.  I preferred the more open atmospheres of the later parts of the maps.  Graphically, it looks nice.  

Play on normal difficulty was reasonable.  There were a few missions that required several attempts, and you are offered the ability to lower the difficulty if you fail a particular mission many times.  

I only experience one spot with a glitch....after a particular piece of NPC dialogue played, the game would crash.  I can't remember what I did to get past this, but whatever it was it wasn't a big deal.  Otherwise, the game played fine with no other technical issues.

In all, I was happy with this game.  I finished the main story in about 50 hrs playtime, although I certainly didn't do every side mission.

+ This game is about the story. Flashbacks, dialogues, mission cutscenes etc. Take it as a story based game with zombies, not a shooter with few story elements. It's not L4D type of game.

+ You can find crafting materials (bodies, cars, open spaces) and make bombs, melee weapons, healing items.

+ You can use stealth or assault approach in combat. There are bombs, mine, shotguns, crossbow, silencers etc.

+ Skill system. More damage for melee weapons, stamina gain in combat etc.

+ Health, Stamina and Focus upgrade via NERO injection.


[h1] Bad [/h1]

- Protagonist can't swim...

- Bike drains fuel too fast.

- No hunger, sleep or thirst system. Survival is limited to materials you collect for weapons and fuel.


[h1] Final [/h1]

Days Gone is an exhilarating and captivating journey through a post-apocalyptic world. As I completed the game on PC and achieved 100% completion, I can confidently say that it was an incredible experience from start to finish. The open-world setting is beautifully crafted, providing a vast and immersive environment to explore on my trusty motorcycle.

The story-line is rich and engaging, keeping me invested in the fate of the protagonist, Deacon St. John, as he navigates the dangers of the pandemic-ridden world. The game's narrative is complemented by well-developed characters and surprising plot twists, making every interaction and mission meaningful.

Combat in Days Gone is intense and satisfying. Facing off against hordes of Freakers or hostile human factions required strategic thinking, resource management, and skillful execution. The variety of weapons and the crafting system added depth to the game-play, allowing me to adapt to different situations and experiment with different play-styles.

One aspect that truly stood out was the dynamic weather system and day-night cycle. It added a layer of realism and immersion, impacting both the game-play mechanics and the overall atmosphere of the game.

On the technical side, the PC version of Days Gone performed admirably. The graphics were stunning, and the controls felt responsive and smooth. I encountered minimal bugs or issues, ensuring a seamless and enjoyable experience.

Overall, Days Gone is a must-play for fans of open-world action-adventure games. Its compelling story, challenging game-play, and immersive world make it a standout title. I can confidently say that Days Gone delivered an unforgettable post-apocalyptic adventure that kept me hooked until the very end, and I would hope to see it have a well deserving sequel :D

Truly an underrated game that deserves more recognition. The story is definitely well-written for a zombie game and the action is intense especially on late game. For some reason, this game reminds me of RDR2 but with zombies and that is in a good way.

PROS:

* Immersive story with interesting characters
* Zombie hordes will no doubt give you that video game adrenaline
* Bike customization is cool
* The skill tree is fair but I wish there are post-game content where you'll become OP
* The way that the missions are designed is really good. You'll be given the option to choose which story mission you want to complete first. I wish more open world games adapt to this in the future so we can have more freedom

CONS:

* Just like in RDR2, there will be a lot of missions where you don't have any choice but to ride along an NPC from point A to point B without any choice but to listen to them talking. The good thing is, when you're alone, you can fast travel to the objective
* Expect some open world bugs. Majority of them are hilarious but there are some that can be frustrating. The good thing is there are no game breaking bugs
* Looting can be tiresome. You'll run out of materials quickly so you'll have no choice but to stop by some nearby house to collect supplies
* It's hard to 100% the game's achievements. There is a challenge mode where you'll have to spend a lot of time memorizing the layout of the area and supply locations
